componenttextpreview: Well, it's kind of difficult for me to comment on that specifically. I mean, the bottom line to it is, is that I'm going to repeat 2 things, and that pricing was consistent with our expectations. And at the end of the day, in order for us to be able to do
componenttext: Well, it's kind of difficult for me to comment on that specifically. I mean, the bottom line to it is, is that I'm going to repeat 2 things, and that pricing was consistent with our expectations. And at the end of the day, in order for us to be able to do what we need to do, we have to have pricing that's competitive with the industry. Whatever that means in terms of what price declines are is whatever it means. But at the end of the day, we did not see anything particularly unusual, and remember that the margins in that business carry higher margins. I mean, we're comfortable in general with where we're positioned in that regard.

componenttext: Fair enough, it was worth a shot. And then just as a quick follow-up. Your average capacity was up 24% year-over-year. componenttext: I mean, we could. Obviously, as Steve indicated, we saw a big increase year-on-year in exabyte in the capacity enterprise. If I look at the rest of the business, performance enterprise growing low single digits and the rest would be pretty much stable year-on-year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so we're kind of tying it back to the point that I was making earlier, as more and more of our business is deployed against non-PC applications, generally speaking, those are higher mix products, whether it be branded products, it be surveillance, it
componenttext: And so we're kind of tying it back to the point that I was making earlier, as more and more of our business is deployed against non-PC applications, generally speaking, those are higher mix products, whether it be branded products, it be surveillance, it be on the enterprise space. So as our mix transitions from an overall business perspective, we're going to get a nice bump in terms of the average capacity point shipped.

componenttext: Steve, you acknowledged hard drives will lose share within the PC category, and we've kind of seen that accelerate exiting the year. So kind of assuming your expectations of low single-digit declines for PCs, is the current trajectory in your client units, which is down 7% or 8% on a year-over-year basis, is that a good kind of guesstimate or barometer going forward of what the trajectory will be?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we expect -- well, we anticipate -- again, we'll see what Toshiba publishes, that we lost a little bit of share in the notebook space. And that was primarily because -- which has kind of happened over the last couple of quarters. Some of that may ha
componenttext: Well, we expect -- well, we anticipate -- again, we'll see what Toshiba publishes, that we lost a little bit of share in the notebook space. And that was primarily because -- which has kind of happened over the last couple of quarters. Some of that may have a little bit to do with gaming and then also that's where margins tend to be lower. And so that may be some of the area where we just choose to not participate in some of the business. So I would say that, that decline is steeper than what the industry is seeing.

componenttext: Yes, as I indicated in my remarks, we've got some, I hate to call it sample units, but we've got some customer applications running in test units and that kind of thing and positive response so far. Our customers are very pleased that we actually know how to construct a subsystem for them given that we've been a component supplier for so long. And so we're encouraged, and I think it's fair to say that our customers are encouraged as well with some of the progress that we're making in that area.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And when you guys say you'll be moving up the enterprise stack, is this an example of that? And will some of that be more obvious down the road? Or is it just mostly going to be things that happen behind the scenes?
componenttext: And when you guys say you'll be moving up the enterprise stack, is this an example of that? And will some of that be more obvious down the road? Or is it just mostly going to be things that happen behind the scenes?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is an example of that. We're going to have to see how all of that evolves. And we will look at opportunities to intelligently move up the enterprise stack, and we'll do our best to do that, which we have done so far in a collaborative fashion wi
componenttext: Yes, this is an example of that. We're going to have to see how all of that evolves. And we will look at opportunities to intelligently move up the enterprise stack, and we'll do our best to do that, which we have done so far in a collaborative fashion with our customers. Our goal is not to compete with our customers but to figure out a better way of enabling them so that they can extend their value proposition to their customers, whether that be through other software services or other kind of offerings. So that's what our base strategy is. Any more questions?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's third quarter financial results for fiscal year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. Sir, you
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's third quarter financial results for fiscal year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. I want to mention as we begin that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response to your questions concerning, among others, our position and opportunities in the growth of data and the storage ecosystem; the grow
componenttext:
Thank you. I want to mention as we begin that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response to your questions concerning, among others, our position and opportunities in the growth of data and the storage ecosystem; the growth areas in storage, our management or short-term market dynamics, our focus on long-term value creation, our product capital allocation, exabyte shipment, macro economic conditions, optimization of our infrastructure and restriction of MOFCOM, our ability to meet any unexpected increase in demand for our demand outlook and our financial performance, including our financial results, expectations for the June quarter. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially, including those listed in our quarterly report on Form 10-Q filed with the SEC on January 10, 2015. We undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect new information or events. 
In addition, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the historical non-GAAP measures we provide with this call and the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. The non-GAAP forward-looking guidance we provide during this call excludes amortization of intangibles related to the acquisition of HGST, sTec, VeloBit, Virident and Amplidata. Because we currently cannot fully qualified future months for these excluded items, we are unable to provide guidance for or our reconciliation to the most fairly comparable GAAP financial measures. The impact of these excluded items may cause the estimated non-GAAP financial measures to differ materially from the comparable GAAP financial measures. [Operator Instructions] I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investors section of the Western Digital's website following the conclusion of this call. I will now turn the call over to President and Chief Executive Officer, Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our March quarter performance and our outlook for the June quarter. For the third fiscal quarter, we reported revenues of $3.5
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our March quarter performance and our outlook for the June quarter. 
For the third fiscal quarter, we reported revenues of $3.5 billion, non-GAAP gross margins of 30.1% and diluted earnings per share of $1.87. I'm satisfied with our execution and results in light of the PC demand challenges that were largely driven by weak macro economic conditions. 
We delivered a solidly profitable quarter with continued strong cash generation and proved average selling price and healthy gross margins. Overall, our storage shipments for the March quarter were 61 exabytes, up 14% year-over-year. 
We continue to carefully balance the management of short-term market dynamics with a strong focus on long-term value creation. This is reflected in our balanced approach to capital allocation. 
Fiscal year-to-date, we returned $1.1 billion to our shareholders and share repurchases and dividends, while continuing to invest in high-growth markets opportunities. We continue to make strong progress on several strategic growth initiatives. Our Enterprise SSD business was accretive for the quarter and grew revenues by 67% year-over-year to $224 million. 
We also launched our new Ultrastar solutions in the enterprise space, addressing the industry transition to standards-based PCIe solutions. We surpassed 1 million Helium hard drive deployments and are now ramping our new 8-terabyte PMR HelioSeal drives. 
We shipped our first Active Archive System, a new category of high-value-added archival storage product addressing a market of approximately $15 billion. 
We completed the acquisition of Amplidata, a key building block of our vertical innovation strategy for Active Archive systems. We expanded our line of purpose-built drives for the fast-growing surveillance video recording space. And we launched 4 new models of high-performance NAS system for the SMB space. 
These initiatives provide revenue expansion opportunities for our company as we leverage our capabilities and resources in a rapidly changing storage ecosystem. 
Turning to our outlook. We continue to see growth in exabyte shipments during calendar 2015 and beyond. However, we anticipate that global macro economic headwinds will persist in the short term, further impacting PC sales. Given this, we are cautious with regards to our near-term outlook. We believe this is prudent in the current environment and consistent with our focus on long-term value creation. That being said, we are fully prepared to meet any upside in demand that may occur as we progress through the June quarter. We are optimistic that the demand environment will improve in the second half of the year. 
We will continue to optimize our infrastructure and related investments to the current demand profile. That being said, our ability to respond to changing market dynamics is affected by the MOFCOM hold separate restriction. This is one of the central arguments that I continue to make in our regular interactions with MOFCOM. Lifting the hold separate restriction would be beneficial to consumers and our customers by promoting innovation and enhancing the competitive environment. Olivier will now provide a summary of our March quarter performance and outlook for the June quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephen. Our revenue for the March quarter was $3.5 billion. We shipped a total of 54.5 million hard drives at the selling price of $61. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 30.1% and operating expenses totaled $591 million. Tax expense for the March
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephen. Our revenue for the March quarter was $3.5 billion. We shipped a total of 54.5 million hard drives at the selling price of $61. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 30.1% and operating expenses totaled $591 million. Tax expense for the March quarter was $28 million or 7% of pretax income.  On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $441 million or $1.87 per share. 
Turning to the balance sheet. In the March quarter, we generated $684 million in cash from operations and our free cash flow totaled $534 million. Our CapEx totaled $150 million or 4% of revenue. We repurchased 2.2 million shares for $240 million. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share. 
We closed Q3 with total cash and cash equivalents of $4.8 billion, of which approximately $880 million was held in the U.S. 
I will now provide our guidance for the June quarter. We expect revenue to be in the range of $3.3 billion to $3.4 billion. Excluding the amortization of intangibles, gross margin percentage to be around the midpoint of our business model of 27% to 32%. Operating expenses of approximately $590 million. Accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share of between $1.50 and $1.60 for the June quarter. 
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question, if you could just review your perspective on the TAM for us in terms of how you see that progressing in the June quarter relative to 125 million and any other comments. You said you were optimistic on the second half of the year. Then h
componenttext: My first question, if you could just review your perspective on the TAM for us in terms of how you see that progressing in the June quarter relative to 125 million and any other comments. You said you were optimistic on the second half of the year. Then how do you foresee that TAM unfolding? And then I'll ask my follow-up, please.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Keith, let me give a little bit of color on the demand environment. So you're right in terms of fiscal Q3. We think that -- we haven't seen Toshiba's numbers published as of yet. But we think that the TAM for fiscal Q3 was about 125 million units. Comi
componenttext: So Keith, let me give a little bit of color on the demand environment. So you're right in terms of fiscal Q3. We think that -- we haven't seen Toshiba's numbers published as of yet. But we think that the TAM for fiscal Q3 was about 125 million units. Coming into the quarter, we would've expected the TAM to be something in the range of 135 million. The weakness that we saw during the quarter was entirely attributable to weakness in the PC market, largely driven by weakness from a broader global macro economic perspective. As I indicated in my prepared remarks, we expect that those headwinds from a global macro economic perspective are going to persist going into the second quarter, again, affecting PC sales. And we think that the TAM will be something in around 120 million unit range. Now one other point to indicate. From an enterprise demand perspective, whether that be enterprise demand for traditional customers or more cloud-related customers, demand there continues to be healthy and came in pretty much along our expectations, both from an industry perspective and as well as a from a company perspective. And then going into the second half of the year, we are optimistic that the demand environment will improve, primarily due to a few things. One, we do expect that PC sales will pick up. We are optimistic in that regard. We'll begin to see a seasonal uptick related to gaming units. I mean, we'll also see a seasonal uptick from the demand perspective in terms of things like our branded business, those more consumer-oriented segments, coupled with continued strength in terms of the enterprise market.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Well, let me ask my follow-up, if I could, Steve. Your employment levels in Q3 FY '12 post deal were about 106 -- a little over 106,000. The information sheet you put out this afternoon said your employment levels were about 81,000 total head
componenttext: Okay, great. Well, let me ask my follow-up, if I could, Steve. Your employment levels in Q3 FY '12 post deal were about 106 -- a little over 106,000. The information sheet you put out this afternoon said your employment levels were about 81,000 total headcount. How is it you've been able to take headcount down so meaningfully over that period? And if you could just reiterate the incremental -- if, in fact, you're granted MOFCOM release, the incremental cost reductions you see once released, if release is granted?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So keep in mind that most of our headcount from a total headcount perspective is concentrated in our factories. We have worked that headcount level down over time, primarily through attrition. And so not replacing workers that decide to move on for f
componenttext: Yes. So keep in mind that most of our headcount from a total headcount perspective is concentrated in our factories. We have worked that headcount level down over time, primarily through attrition. And so not replacing workers that decide to move on for further employment. And if we go to the question on MOFCOM, what we have said and we continue to say is that we expect that from an operating expense perspective, that we would realize approximately $100 million of OpEx savings a quarter. We have not quantified the savings that we would anticipate on the cost line item. But we have indicated that we would expect that to be meaningful.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.
componenttext: The next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I do have a follow-up as well. First, looking at the outlook, when we look at the midpoint of your gross margin guidance and then also in the context of your expectation of enterprise remaining relatively healthy. I'm just trying to bridge the expectation
componenttext: I do have a follow-up as well. First, looking at the outlook, when we look at the midpoint of your gross margin guidance and then also in the context of your expectation of enterprise remaining relatively healthy. I'm just trying to bridge the expectation of the declining gross margin down into the 29.5% range. What's the underlying drivers of that? And why wouldn't mix shift towards enterprise offset some of the weakness we're seeing in the PC actually be a positive on gross margin?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me take this one. The margin decline in the quarter is going to be mainly attributed to absorption impact. That's the main driver. And as Steve has indicated, we expect the margin to pick up in the second half of the calendar year at the back of th
componenttext: So let me take this one. The margin decline in the quarter is going to be mainly attributed to absorption impact. That's the main driver. And as Steve has indicated, we expect the margin to pick up in the second half of the calendar year at the back of the PC market and then also some increased demand in the enterprise segment.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up and related to the enterprise business. It looks like you guys were down a bit more so relative to your closest competitor, which I think was flat sequentially. Can you talk about the competitive landscape, whether or not you
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up and related to the enterprise business. It looks like you guys were down a bit more so relative to your closest competitor, which I think was flat sequentially. Can you talk about the competitive landscape, whether or not you've seen any kind of changes in pricing in the enterprise market or any reasons why maybe you might have underperformed your competitor in that space?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So one thing to keep in mind in terms of one, overall share in particular overall share, if things are going to -- share is going to shift a little bit quarter-to-quarter. And in particular in the enterprise space, I hate to use the word lumpy becaus
componenttext: Yes. So one thing to keep in mind in terms of one, overall share in particular overall share, if things are going to -- share is going to shift a little bit quarter-to-quarter. And in particular in the enterprise space, I hate to use the word lumpy because it tends to be a little overused. But it tends to come in bigger chunks in terms of we can have a customer that we're particularly strong with that may provide a little bit of incremental volume or the flip side could be true of our largest competitor. And so share can move around a little bit more quarter-to-quarter from an enterprise perspective. But the important thing to keep in mind is there's a few important things to keep in mind. One is that we are very comfortable with our product positioning in that space and also very comfortable with the positioning from a customer perspective. And then the last comment that I will indicate is that we've got to also keep in mind that unit share is 1 indicator, but it is not the only indicated. You also have to look at revenue share as well as margin share. And in that regard, we're particularly pleased with how we performed in the last quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Richard Kugele with Needham & Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Richard Kugele with Needham & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just -- if you could talk a little bit more about the SSD business. Strong growth there this quarter. And Steve, you had mentioned, I think, in previous calls that you expected during the first half of calendar '15 to see particular growth maybe even on t
componenttext: Just -- if you could talk a little bit more about the SSD business. Strong growth there this quarter. And Steve, you had mentioned, I think, in previous calls that you expected during the first half of calendar '15 to see particular growth maybe even on the PCIe side in that business. So can you just elaborate a little more on what you're seeing in SSDs and where that revenue is comprised of -- or is comprised of?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rich. Most of our revenue today is coming from our enterprise -- or the fast enterprise SSD offering that we have that we codeveloped with Intel. We continue to see strong receptivity to our product and good traction there. As I had in my prepared r
componenttext: Sure, Rich. Most of our revenue today is coming from our enterprise -- or the fast enterprise SSD offering that we have that we codeveloped with Intel. We continue to see strong receptivity to our product and good traction there. As I had in my prepared remarks, we've recently announced our PCIe MVME [ph] offering. And what we're seeing in that space, which we have been anticipating for a while, is a move away from proprietary base PCIe solutions to, call it, standards-based solution. We'll begin to see the impact of that from a revenue perspective as we will move through the balance of 2015 from a calendar year perspective. And so as of right now, that is not meaningfully indicated at least our revenue performance over the past quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Would you expect the SSD business to remain profitable over the balance of calendar '15 or has that moved on now?
componenttext: Would you expect the SSD business to remain profitable over the balance of calendar '15 or has that moved on now?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll even go further than that, Rich, that I would expect our profitability level would improve.
componenttext: Yes. And I'll even go further than that, Rich, that I would expect our profitability level would improve.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from James Kistner from Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question comes from James Kistner from Jefferies.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess one quick clarification here. You talked about MOFCOM and getting your script you made another strong case for why you should be able to integrate. Is there any update at all on the feedback you're getting from MOFCOM right now?
componenttext: So I guess one quick clarification here. You talked about MOFCOM and getting your script you made another strong case for why you should be able to integrate. Is there any update at all on the feedback you're getting from MOFCOM right now?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me provide a little bit of color on that. The -- so we continue as I alluded to in my prepared marks, we continue to have frequent communications with MOFCOM. That includes myself so -- and members of the management team. On the positive side, I
componenttext: Sure. Let me provide a little bit of color on that. The -- so we continue as I alluded to in my prepared marks, we continue to have frequent communications with MOFCOM. That includes myself so -- and members of the management team. On the positive side, I am encouraged by the frequency of those communications and the substance of those communications. Where I am not pleased is with regards to the pace of decision-making or the transparency of that decision-making. And so one of the things that in a constructive way, we continue to push is to help us understand exactly what the decision-making process is going to be and the time frame associated with that. So that's where the frustration is. It's just the timing and the nature or process surrounding that decision-making.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. And just a follow-up. You guys have been saying on occasions that your visibility with hyperscale is you're getting better. Is that still the case? Do you anticipate you could see a pretty meaningful uptick in hyperscale in the back
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. And just a follow-up. You guys have been saying on occasions that your visibility with hyperscale is you're getting better. Is that still the case? Do you anticipate you could see a pretty meaningful uptick in hyperscale in the back half?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So relative to hyperscale demand, we feel pretty comfortable about our visibility right now through the balance of calendar 2015. And again, as I alluded to in my prepared remarks, we're expecting to see strong petabyte growth, particularly in the hy
componenttext: Yes. So relative to hyperscale demand, we feel pretty comfortable about our visibility right now through the balance of calendar 2015. And again, as I alluded to in my prepared remarks, we're expecting to see strong petabyte growth, particularly in the hyperscale accounts. The one question, which I talked about on our earnings call last quarter, is the question is how will that specifically impact our unit demand, which is a function of the deployment of new capacity points as well as the acceptance of these new capacity points on behalf of our customers. So for example, as we deploy an 8-terabyte drive, what would be the take rate on that by our customers. And obviously, if you ship an 8-terabyte, you don't need 2 or 4-terabyte. And so the impact on our units is the one that is a little bit more variable. But what is we do feel very strongly about is continued growth in petabyte growth in hyperscale deployments.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question follow-up as well. I guess, Steve, when I look at your OpEx number there's a long-term target of 10% to 12% that you guys have. You're running at about 16.6% or so right now. I think half of that is attributable to the MOFCOM number you
componenttext: I have a question follow-up as well. I guess, Steve, when I look at your OpEx number there's a long-term target of 10% to 12% that you guys have. You're running at about 16.6% or so right now. I think half of that is attributable to the MOFCOM number you talked about. But I'm curious what do you think helped you realize the other half of the 300 basis points of the operating margin? Is that leverage, is that mix? And how are you going to achieve this all, the targets I guess as you go forward beyond MOFCOM?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We -- you're right. I mean, a large portion of that delta is due to lack of synergies from related to the whole separate situation. The other thing is which is I don't mean to sound as a cop out because it may sound like a cop out. But keep in mind t
componenttext: Yes. We -- you're right. I mean, a large portion of that delta is due to lack of synergies from related to the whole separate situation. The other thing is which is I don't mean to sound as a cop out because it may sound like a cop out. But keep in mind that our OpEx model was set back in September of 2012. One of the things that we need to do as the composition of our business changes and our investments change accordingly is a resetting of that model appropriate. I'm not suggesting that it is or it is not. It's just something that we would have to contemplate. But clearly, one of the things that we're going to have to do as we move forward is look at ways at optimizing our expenditures. And we talked about that in terms of managing short-term dynamics with longer-term value creation. And that becomes a bit more challenging, as you see -- as we did in this past quarter, a faster deceleration in the PC market, largely driven by temporal factors.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And if I could just follow up. Could you just touch on pricing dynamics? There was a big discussion last quarter. But what are you seeing on the pricing side both on enterprise in the PC side and as that changes again in the June quarter.
componenttext: Fair enough. And if I could just follow up. Could you just touch on pricing dynamics? There was a big discussion last quarter. But what are you seeing on the pricing side both on enterprise in the PC side and as that changes again in the June quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have not as I said last time on our earnings call and just -- it was very consistent. We -- pricing was within our expectations. We did not see anything that was outside of our expectations. I will add one thing that as we look at this quarter fro
componenttext: Yes. We have not as I said last time on our earnings call and just -- it was very consistent. We -- pricing was within our expectations. We did not see anything that was outside of our expectations. I will add one thing that as we look at this quarter from a demand perspective, and anytime you do a demand forecast, the only thing that I know is that the demand may be higher or lower than what we expect. Right now, we are taking cautious view because it feels like the risk factors associated with a lower demand environment are greater than it being a higher level of demand. And we believe that is prudent because we all know what happens when we happen to oversupply the industry.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Joe Yoo with Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question comes from Joe Yoo with Citigroup.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I want to ask about inventory levels if I could. There has been some recent data points suggesting that distributors, especially in Europe and Asia, are bringing down the level of hardware inventory due to currency. What's your view of inventory in
componenttext: Steve, I want to ask about inventory levels if I could. There has been some recent data points suggesting that distributors, especially in Europe and Asia, are bringing down the level of hardware inventory due to currency. What's your view of inventory in the channel and the ODMs relative to normal levels?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So a couple of comments on that. Generally speaking, when we look at inventory levels, we think that they are within manageable ranges. That being said, one of the comments that you indicated, when we look at our distribution business, our distributi
componenttext: Yes. So a couple of comments on that. Generally speaking, when we look at inventory levels, we think that they are within manageable ranges. That being said, one of the comments that you indicated, when we look at our distribution business, our distribution business was down pretty meaningfully in Europe. And that is largely driven by the effect of stronger U.S. dollar. And so we're sensitive to that. We've tried to do manage our business and manage those inventory levels. But as our customers in Europe are seeing a compression on their business-driven by the U.S. dollar, that clearly puts pressure on our business as well.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up on the SSD business. I mean, it's well known that SanDisk is struggling. It's one of your meaningful competitors on the SAS side due to qualification issues. How much of your -- the acceleration you've seen on the business on SSDs was a
componenttext: And as a follow-up on the SSD business. I mean, it's well known that SanDisk is struggling. It's one of your meaningful competitors on the SAS side due to qualification issues. How much of your -- the acceleration you've seen on the business on SSDs was attributed to share gains as opposed to the actual market accelerating?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a pretty strong share position in the SAS market for a while. I would not attribute our strong performance in this past quarter in any material way to any missteps on SanDisk's part.
componenttext: Well, we've had a pretty strong share position in the SAS market for a while. I would not attribute our strong performance in this past quarter in any material way to any missteps on SanDisk's part.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I was hoping you could provide a little more detail on your view as to why the second half will improve from a PC perspective? And also maybe some commentary on the enterprise side. Just wanted to know if you're hearing anything from customers that
componenttext: Steve, I was hoping you could provide a little more detail on your view as to why the second half will improve from a PC perspective? And also maybe some commentary on the enterprise side. Just wanted to know if you're hearing anything from customers that suggest they also think demand will improve in the second half? Or is that driven by Windows 10 or what that belief is based on?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just not to mince words, but we're optimistic that the demand environment will improve. Obviously, we'll have to continue to keep an eye on that. The reasons that we're optimistic is we do believe that the PC market will improve -- well, we are op
componenttext: Yes. So just not to mince words, but we're optimistic that the demand environment will improve. Obviously, we'll have to continue to keep an eye on that. The reasons that we're optimistic is we do believe that the PC market will improve -- well, we are optimistic that it will improve, I should clarify that. We will see seasonal uptick in demand from the gaming segment. And we continue -- we will continue to see or expect to continue to see strength in the broader enterprise market. I don't know if I would characterize the enterprise -- enterprise market has been consistent with our expectations. I don't know if I would say that I'm inspecting an acceleration of that in the back half of the year. I think that we're expecting a continued strong demand environment in the broader enterprise market, including hyperscale.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jayson Noland with Robert Baird.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jayson Noland with Robert Baird.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on that last question, regarding the potential impact of the Windows 10. Intel suggested that there were some channel reduction in front of Windows 10 and the channel sale in the back half. Would that play a role in an optimistic vie
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on that last question, regarding the potential impact of the Windows 10. Intel suggested that there were some channel reduction in front of Windows 10 and the channel sale in the back half. Would that play a role in an optimistic view on the second half?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jayson. We will concur with that.
componenttext: Yes, Jayson. We will concur with that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, a follow-up question on Active Archive. If you could talk a little bit to the financial profile competitive dynamics there and any potential sales and marketing investments? Just curious to see your thoughts there on how that should play out h
componenttext: Okay. Well, a follow-up question on Active Archive. If you could talk a little bit to the financial profile competitive dynamics there and any potential sales and marketing investments? Just curious to see your thoughts there on how that should play out here?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So one of the things -- there's really a few things to keep in mind, Jayson, on the Active Archive product. I mean, really we're going after a bit of a greenfield opportunity, where we're seeing data that today maybe isn't stored because it's not eco
componenttext: Yes. So one of the things -- there's really a few things to keep in mind, Jayson, on the Active Archive product. I mean, really we're going after a bit of a greenfield opportunity, where we're seeing data that today maybe isn't stored because it's not economical or it may be stored on other media, for example, tape and that sort of thing. And so we're sort of blazing some trails there from a market perspective and doing that in a way that we believe is synergistic with our existing customer base. From a financial perspective, I don't believe that we have at present indicated specifically what that financial profile would look like other than to say that it would be accretive to our existing gross profit profile. And so far, in terms of customer reaction, we have shipped units. And customer reaction so far has been very positive.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Mehdi Husseini with SIG.
componenttext: The next question comes from Mehdi Husseini with SIG.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And going back to your guide for 120 million TAM units for the June quarter, I'm just curious, what kind of consumer PC assumption do you have built in. And are you expecting units to be up, flat or down in June compared to the March quarter?
componenttext: And going back to your guide for 120 million TAM units for the June quarter, I'm just curious, what kind of consumer PC assumption do you have built in. And are you expecting units to be up, flat or down in June compared to the March quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We would expect the client business to keep declining. Putting a number behind that will be difficult, probably less precipitous to what we have observed in the March quarter but some level of decline.
componenttext: We would expect the client business to keep declining. Putting a number behind that will be difficult, probably less precipitous to what we have observed in the March quarter but some level of decline.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So similar to Intel if month of June turn out to be better than earlier in the quarter, you could see some upside and you could see upside to the TAM units, fair?
componenttext: Okay. So similar to Intel if month of June turn out to be better than earlier in the quarter, you could see some upside and you could see upside to the TAM units, fair?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct. And that's why we indicated again in my prepared remarks that if demand ends up being better than we expected, we'll be there immediate.
componenttext: That's correct. And that's why we indicated again in my prepared remarks that if demand ends up being better than we expected, we'll be there immediate.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, one other question I have is regarding the enterprise. I'm kind of surprised having seen any acceleration growth in the overall server investment in advance of the operating system expiration, there are 2 that are coming up. Is there som
componenttext: Got it. And then, one other question I have is regarding the enterprise. I'm kind of surprised having seen any acceleration growth in the overall server investment in advance of the operating system expiration, there are 2 that are coming up. Is there something that you think has already played out or has yet to pay out or is not really going to have much of an impact on the hardware procurement?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We haven't really seen that one way or the other. So I don't think it's had much impact. If we look at demand for storage products or storage components in server-based systems. It's been pretty steady. So not a really big increase one way or the other or
componenttext: We haven't really seen that one way or the other. So I don't think it's had much impact. If we look at demand for storage products or storage components in server-based systems. It's been pretty steady. So not a really big increase one way or the other or decrease. So I don't think it's having much of an impact.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Nehal Chokshi from Maxim Group.
componenttext: The next question comes from Nehal Chokshi from Maxim Group.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the data gives us the ability to look at price per terabyte, which was down a healthy 80% year-over-year on effectively flat gross margins. So cost reductions are in line with the price per terabyte reductions and that's very good. Can you help tease o
componenttext: So the data gives us the ability to look at price per terabyte, which was down a healthy 80% year-over-year on effectively flat gross margins. So cost reductions are in line with the price per terabyte reductions and that's very good. Can you help tease out how much is due to mixed shift to new line versus the inherent like-for-like cost decline that you're seeing right now? And then I will have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Most of it -- more in line share that is growth in -- it's mixed up. It's most of that.
componenttext: Yes. Most of it -- more in line share that is growth in -- it's mixed up. It's most of that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: It is indeed mixed up.
componenttext: It is indeed mixed up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely.
componenttext: Yes, absolutely.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Now the advanced storage technology consortium, which you guys are part of recently released a 10-year road map shopping room for 10x increase in areal density. Now I understand that there is going to be increased unit cost to Hammer's as well as the patt
componenttext: Now the advanced storage technology consortium, which you guys are part of recently released a 10-year road map shopping room for 10x increase in areal density. Now I understand that there is going to be increased unit cost to Hammer's as well as the pattern medium. But I would think that that still implies at least 7x cost [indiscernible] decline over the same time frame or basically a 22% per year per bit decline, significantly faster than your current trend and potentially faster and further the NAND Flash can't accomplished. Do you have any pushback on that assertion there?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, honestly that's a lot of data to sort of out straightaway. We a little bit further analysis. But we continue to believe that from a competitive positioning standpoint, we will remain particularly in the enterprise space, we'll remain cost competitiv
componenttext: Well, honestly that's a lot of data to sort of out straightaway. We a little bit further analysis. But we continue to believe that from a competitive positioning standpoint, we will remain particularly in the enterprise space, we'll remain cost competitive in terms of any other solution. So generally speaking, I would say, yes, I agree with your assertion.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: My assertion is likely a lot more aggressive than what Seagate or I believe you guys have indicated in the past. And so that's what I'm checking on basically.
componenttext: My assertion is likely a lot more aggressive than what Seagate or I believe you guys have indicated in the past. And so that's what I'm checking on basically.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you for joining us today. I want to thank our employees and suppliers for their commitment and outstanding execution and our customers for their continued business. Thank you so much.
componenttext: All right. Thank you for joining us today. I want to thank our employees and suppliers for their commitment and outstanding execution and our customers for their continued business. Thank you so much.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That concludes today's conference. Thank you for participating. You may disconnect at this time.
componenttext: That concludes today's conference. Thank you for participating. You may disconnect at this time.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's third quarter financial results for fiscal year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. Sir, you
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's third quarter financial results for fiscal year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. I want to mention as we begin that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response to your questions concerning, among others, our position and opportunities in the growth of data and the storage ecosystem; the grow
componenttext:
Thank you. I want to mention as we begin that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response to your questions concerning, among others, our position and opportunities in the growth of data and the storage ecosystem; the growth areas in storage; our management of short-term market dynamics; our focus on long-term value creation; our purchase capital allocation; exabyte shipments; macro economic conditions; optimization of our infrastructure; impact of the hold separate restriction of MOFCOM; our ability to meet any unexpected increase in demand for our products and demand outlook; and our financial performance, including our financial results, expectations for the June quarter. 
These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially, including those listed in our quarterly report on Form 10-Q filed with the SEC on January 10, 2015. We undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect new information or events. 
In addition, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the historical non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. 
The non-GAAP forward-looking guidance we provide during this call excludes amortization of intangibles related to the acquisitions of HGST, sTec, VeloBit, Virident and Amplidata. Because we currently cannot fully quantify future amounts for these excluded items, we are unable to provide guidance for or our reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures. The impact of these excluded items may cause the estimated non-GAAP financial measures to differ materially from the comparable GAAP financial measures. 
[Operator Instructions] I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investors section of Western Digital's website immediately following the conclusion of this call. I will now turn the call over to President and Chief Executive Officer, Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our March quarter performance and our outlook for the June quarter. For the third fiscal quarter, we reported revenues of $3.5
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our March quarter performance and our outlook for the June quarter. 
For the third fiscal quarter, we reported revenues of $3.5 billion, non-GAAP gross margins of 30.1% and diluted earnings per share of $1.87. I am satisfied with our execution and results in light of the PC demand challenges that were largely driven by weak macroeconomic conditions. 
We delivered a solidly profitable quarter with continued strong cash generation, improved average selling price and healthy gross margins. Overall, our storage shipments for the March quarter were 61 exabytes, up 14% year-over-year. 
We continue to carefully balance the management of short-term market dynamics with a strong focus on long-term value creation. This is reflected in our balanced approach to capital allocation. 
Fiscal year-to-date, we returned $1.1 billion to our shareholders in share repurchases and dividends, while continuing to invest in high-growth markets opportunities. We continue to make strong progress on several strategic growth initiatives. Our Enterprise SSD business was accretive for the quarter and grew revenues by 67% year-over-year to $224 million. 
We also launched our new Ultrastar NVMe solutions in the enterprise space, addressing the industry transition to standards-based PCIe solutions. We surpassed 1 million Helium hard drive deployments and are now ramping our new 8-terabyte PMR Helium Seal drives. 
We shipped our first Active Archive system, a new category of high-value-added archival storage product addressing a market of approximately $15 billion. 
We completed the acquisition of Amplidata, a key building block of our vertical innovation strategy for Active Archive systems. We expanded our line of purpose-built drives for the fast-growing surveillance video recording space. And we launched 4 new models of high-performance NAS systems for the SMB space. 
These initiatives provide revenue expansion opportunities for our company as we leverage our capabilities and resources in the rapidly changing storage ecosystem. 
Turning to our outlook. We continue to see growth in exabyte shipments during calendar 2015 and beyond. However, we anticipate that global macro economic headwinds will persist in the short term, further impacting PC sales. Given this, we are cautious with regards to our near-term outlook. We believe this is prudent in the current environment and consistent with our focus on long-term value creation. That being said, we are fully prepared to meet any upside in demand that may occur as we progress through the June quarter. We are optimistic that the demand environment will improve in the second half of the year. 
We will continue to optimize our infrastructure and related investments to the current demand profile. That being said, our ability to respond to changing market dynamics is affected by the MOFCOM hold separate restriction. This is one of the central arguments that I continue to make in our regular interactions with MOFCOM. Lifting the hold separate restriction would be beneficial to consumers and our customers by promoting innovation and enhancing the competitive environment. 
Olivier will now provide a summary of our March quarter performance and outlook for the June quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the March quarter was $3.5 billion. We shipped a total of 54.5 million hard drives at an average selling price of $61. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 30.1% and operating expenses totaled $591 million. Tax expense for the M
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the March quarter was $3.5 billion. We shipped a total of 54.5 million hard drives at an average selling price of $61. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 30.1% and operating expenses totaled $591 million. Tax expense for the March quarter was $28 million or 7% of pretax income.  On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $441 million or $1.87 per share. 
Turning to the balance sheet. In the March quarter, we generated $684 million in cash from operations, and our free cash flow totaled $534 million. Our CapEx totaled $150 million or 4% of revenue. We repurchased 2.2 million shares for $240 million. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share. 
We closed Q3 with total cash and cash equivalents of $4.8 billion, of which approximately $880 million was held in the U.S. 
I will now provide our guidance for the June quarter. We expect revenue to be in the range of $3.3 billion to $3.4 billion. Excluding the amortization of intangibles, gross margin percentage to be around the midpoint of our business model of 27% to 32%. Operating expenses of approximately $590 million. Accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share of between $1.50 and $1.60 for the June quarter. 
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question. If you could just review your perspective on the TAM for us in terms of how you see that progressing in the June quarter relative to 125 million and any other comments. You said you were optimistic on the second half of the year. Then h
componenttext: My first question. If you could just review your perspective on the TAM for us in terms of how you see that progressing in the June quarter relative to 125 million and any other comments. You said you were optimistic on the second half of the year. Then how do you foresee that TAM unfolding? And then I'll ask my follow-up, please.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Keith, let me give a little bit of color on the demand environment. So you're right in terms of fiscal Q3. We think that -- we haven't seen Toshiba's numbers published as of yet. But we think that the TAM for fiscal Q3 was about 125 million units. Comi
componenttext: So Keith, let me give a little bit of color on the demand environment. So you're right in terms of fiscal Q3. We think that -- we haven't seen Toshiba's numbers published as of yet. But we think that the TAM for fiscal Q3 was about 125 million units. Coming into the quarter, we would've expected the TAM to be something in the range of 135 million. The weakness that we saw during the quarter was entirely attributable to weakness in the PC market, largely driven by weakness from a broader global macroeconomic perspective. As I indicated in my prepared remarks, we expect that those headwinds from a global macroeconomic perspective are going to persist going into the second quarter, again, affecting PC sales. And we think that the TAM will be something in around the 120 million unit range. Now one other point to indicate. From an enterprise demand perspective, whether that be enterprise demand for traditional customers or for cloud-related customers. Demand there continues to be healthy and came in pretty much along our expectations, both from an industry perspective and as well as a from a company perspective. And then going into the second half of the year, we are optimistic that the demand environment will improve, primarily due to a few things. One, we do expect that PC sales will pick up. We're optimistic in that regard. We'll begin to see a seasonal uptick related to gaming units. And then we'll also see a seasonal uptick from the demand perspective in terms of things like our branded business, those more consumer-oriented segments, coupled with continued strength in terms of the enterprise market.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Well, let me ask my follow-up then, if I could, Steve. Your employment levels in Q3 FY '12 post deal were about 106 -- a little over 106,000. The information sheet you put out this afternoon said your employment levels were about 81,000, tota
componenttext: Okay, great. Well, let me ask my follow-up then, if I could, Steve. Your employment levels in Q3 FY '12 post deal were about 106 -- a little over 106,000. The information sheet you put out this afternoon said your employment levels were about 81,000, total headcount. How is it you've been able to take headcount down so meaningfully over that period? And if you could just reiterate the incremental -- if, in fact, you're granted MOFCOM relief, the incremental cost reductions you see once relief -- if release is granted?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the -- keep in mind that most of our headcount from a total headcount perspective is concentrated in our factories. We have worked that headcount level down over time primarily through attrition, and so not replacing workers that decide to move on
componenttext: Yes. So the -- keep in mind that most of our headcount from a total headcount perspective is concentrated in our factories. We have worked that headcount level down over time primarily through attrition, and so not replacing workers that decide to move on for further employment. And if we go to the question on MOFCOM, what we have said and we continue to say is that we expect that, from an operating expense perspective, that we would realize approximately $100 million of OpEx savings a quarter. We have not quantified the savings that we would anticipate on the cost line item. But we have indicated that we would expect that to be meaningful.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.
componenttext: The next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I do have a follow-up, as well. First, looking at the outlook, when we look at the midpoint of your gross margin guidance and then also in the context of your expectation of enterprise remaining relatively healthy. I'm just trying to bridge the expectatio
componenttext: I do have a follow-up, as well. First, looking at the outlook, when we look at the midpoint of your gross margin guidance and then also in the context of your expectation of enterprise remaining relatively healthy. I'm just trying to bridge the expectation of a decline in gross margin down into the 29.5% range. What's the underlying drivers of that? And why wouldn't mix shift towards enterprise offset some of the weakness we're seeing in the PC than actually be a positive on gross margin?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me take this one. The margin decline in the quarter is going to be mainly attributed to absorption impact, that's the main driver. And as Steve has indicated, we expect the margin to pick up in the second half of the calendar year at the back of th
componenttext: So let me take this one. The margin decline in the quarter is going to be mainly attributed to absorption impact, that's the main driver. And as Steve has indicated, we expect the margin to pick up in the second half of the calendar year at the back of the PC market and then also some increased demand in the enterprise segment.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up and related to the enterprise business. It looks like you guys were down a bit more so relative to your closest competitor, which I think was flat sequentially. Can you talk about the competitive landscape, whether or not you
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up and related to the enterprise business. It looks like you guys were down a bit more so relative to your closest competitor, which I think was flat sequentially. Can you talk about the competitive landscape, whether or not you've seen any kind of changes in pricing in the enterprise market or any reasons why maybe you might have underperformed your competitor in that space?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So one thing to keep in mind in terms of, one, overall share and, in particular, enterprise share, if things are going to -- share is going to shift a little bit quarter-to-quarter. And in particular, in the enterprise space, I hate to use the word l
componenttext: Yes. So one thing to keep in mind in terms of, one, overall share and, in particular, enterprise share, if things are going to -- share is going to shift a little bit quarter-to-quarter. And in particular, in the enterprise space, I hate to use the word lumpy because it tends to be a little bit overused, but it tends to come in bigger chunks in terms of we can have a customer that we're particularly strong with that may provide a little bit of incremental volume or the flip side could be true of our largest competitor. And so share can move around a little bit more quarter-to-quarter from an enterprise perspective. But the important thing to keep in mind, there's a few important things to keep in mind. One is that we are very comfortable with our product positioning in that space and also very comfortable with the positioning from a customer perspective. And then the last comment that I will indicate is that we've also got to keep in mind that unit share is one indicator, but it is not the only indicator. You also have to look at revenue share as well as margin share. And in that regard, we're particularly pleased with how we performed in the past quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Rich Kugele with Needham & Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Rich Kugele with Needham & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just if you could talk a little bit more about the SSD business. Strong growth there this quarter. And Steve, you had mentioned, I think, in previous calls that you expected during the first half of calendar '15 to see particular growth maybe even on the
componenttext: Just if you could talk a little bit more about the SSD business. Strong growth there this quarter. And Steve, you had mentioned, I think, in previous calls that you expected during the first half of calendar '15 to see particular growth maybe even on the PCIe side in that business. So can you just elaborate a little more on what you're seeing in SSDs and where that revenue is comprised of -- what it's comprised of?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rich. The -- most of our revenue today is coming from our enterprise -- or the fast enterprise SSD offering that we have that we codeveloped with Intel. We continue to see strong receptivity to our product and good traction there. As I had in my pre
componenttext: Sure, Rich. The -- most of our revenue today is coming from our enterprise -- or the fast enterprise SSD offering that we have that we codeveloped with Intel. We continue to see strong receptivity to our product and good traction there. As I had in my prepared remarks, we've recently announced our PCIe NVMe offering. And what we're seeing in that space, which we have been anticipating for a while, is a move away from proprietary base PCIe solutions to, call it, a standards-based NVMe solution. We'll begin to see the impact of that from a revenue perspective as we will move through the balance of 2015 from a calendar year perspective. And so as of right now, that is not meaningfully indicated, at least our revenue performance, over the past quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Would you expect the SSD business to remain profitable over the balance of calendar '15 or has that moved on now?
componenttext: Would you expect the SSD business to remain profitable over the balance of calendar '15 or has that moved on now?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll even go further than that, Rich, on that. I would expect that our profitability level will improve.
componenttext: Yes. And I'll even go further than that, Rich, on that. I would expect that our profitability level will improve.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from James Kisner with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question comes from James Kisner with Jefferies.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, one quick clarification here. You talked about MOFCOM and getting your script you made another strong case for why you should be able to integrate. Is there any update at all on the feedback you're getting from MOFCOM right now?
componenttext: So I guess, one quick clarification here. You talked about MOFCOM and getting your script you made another strong case for why you should be able to integrate. Is there any update at all on the feedback you're getting from MOFCOM right now?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me provide a little bit of color on that. The -- so we continue, as I alluded to in my prepared marks, we continue to have frequent communications with MOFCOM. That includes myself, so -- and members of the management team. On the positive side,
componenttext: Sure. Let me provide a little bit of color on that. The -- so we continue, as I alluded to in my prepared marks, we continue to have frequent communications with MOFCOM. That includes myself, so -- and members of the management team. On the positive side, I am encouraged by the frequency of those communications and the substance of those communications. Where I am not pleased is with regards to the pace of decision-making or the transparency of that decision-making. And so one of the things that, in a constructive way, we continue to push is to help us understand exactly what the decision-making process is going to be and the time frame associated with that. So that's where the frustration is. It's just the timing and the nature or process surrounding that decision-making.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. And just a follow-up. Just you guys have been saying on most locations that your visibility with hyperscale is better. Is that still the case? Do you anticipate you could see a pretty meaningful uptick in hyperscale in the back half
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. And just a follow-up. Just you guys have been saying on most locations that your visibility with hyperscale is better. Is that still the case? Do you anticipate you could see a pretty meaningful uptick in hyperscale in the back half?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So relative to hyperscale demand, we feel pretty comfortable about our visibility right now through the balance of calendar 2015. And again, as I alluded to in my prepared remarks, we're expecting to see strong petabyte growth, particularly in the hy
componenttext: Yes. So relative to hyperscale demand, we feel pretty comfortable about our visibility right now through the balance of calendar 2015. And again, as I alluded to in my prepared remarks, we're expecting to see strong petabyte growth, particularly in the hyperscale accounts. The one question, which I talked about on our earnings call last quarter is the question is how will that specifically impact our unit demand, which is a function of the deployment of new capacity points as well as the acceptance of these new capacity points on behalf of our customers. So for example, as we deploy a 8-terabyte drive, what will be the take rate on that by our customers? And obviously, if you ship an 8-terabyte, you don't need 2 or 4 terabytes. And so the impact on our units is the one that is a little bit more variable. But what is we do feel very strongly about is continued growth in petabyte growth and hyperscale deployments.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question and follow-up, as well. I guess, Steve, when I look at your OpEx number, this is a long-term target of 10% to 12% that you guys have. You're running at about 16.6% or so right now. I think half of that is probably attributable to the MOF
componenttext: I have a question and follow-up, as well. I guess, Steve, when I look at your OpEx number, this is a long-term target of 10% to 12% that you guys have. You're running at about 16.6% or so right now. I think half of that is probably attributable to the MOFCOM number you talked about. But I'm curious what do you think helped you realize the other half, the 300 basis points of that operating margin? Is that leverage, is that mix? And how are you going to achieve those -- the targets, I guess, as you go forward beyond MOFCOM?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we -- you're right. I mean, a large portion of that delta is due to lack of synergies from -- related to the whole separate situation. The other thing is which is I don't mean this to sound as a cop out because I may sound like a cop out. But keep
componenttext: Yes. So we -- you're right. I mean, a large portion of that delta is due to lack of synergies from -- related to the whole separate situation. The other thing is which is I don't mean this to sound as a cop out because I may sound like a cop out. But keep in mind that our OpEx model was set back in September of 2012. One of the things that we need to do as the composition of our business changes and our investments change accordingly is a resetting of that model appropriate. I'm not suggesting that it is or it is not, it's just something that we would have to contemplate. But clearly, one of the things that we're going to have to do as we move forward is look at ways at optimizing our expenditures. And we talked about that in terms of managing short-term dynamics with longer-term value creation. And that becomes a bit more challenging, as you see -- as we did in this past quarter, a faster deceleration in the PC market, largely driven by temporal factors.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And if I could just follow up, could you just touch on pricing dynamics? There was a big discussion, I think, last quarter. But what are you seeing on the pricing side both on enterprise and the PC side and as that changes again into the June
componenttext: Fair enough. And if I could just follow up, could you just touch on pricing dynamics? There was a big discussion, I think, last quarter. But what are you seeing on the pricing side both on enterprise and the PC side and as that changes again into the June quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have not -- as I said last time on our earnings call and just to -- it was very consistent. We -- pricing was within our expectations. We did not see anything that was outside of our expectations. I will add one thing that, as we look at this quar
componenttext: Yes. We have not -- as I said last time on our earnings call and just to -- it was very consistent. We -- pricing was within our expectations. We did not see anything that was outside of our expectations. I will add one thing that, as we look at this quarter from a demand perspective, and anytime you do a demand forecast, the only thing that I know is that the demand may be higher or lower than what we expect. Right now, we are taking a cautious view because it feels like the risk factors associated with a lower demand environment are greater than it is being a higher level of demand. And we believe that it's prudent because we all know what happens when we happen to oversupply the industry.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Joe Yoo with Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question comes from Joe Yoo with Citigroup.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I wanted to ask about inventory levels, if I could. There has been some recent data points suggesting that distributors, especially in Europe and Asia, are excessively bringing down the level of hardware inventory due to currency. What's your view
componenttext: Steve, I wanted to ask about inventory levels, if I could. There has been some recent data points suggesting that distributors, especially in Europe and Asia, are excessively bringing down the level of hardware inventory due to currency. What's your view of inventory in the channel and at the ODMs relative to normal levels?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
