headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Western Digital's Fourth Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Western Digital's Fourth Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Before we begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and responses to your questions concerning, among others, our product and technology positioning; customer acceptance of our SAS SSD prod
componenttext:
Thank you. Before we begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and responses to your questions concerning, among others, our product and technology positioning; customer acceptance of our SAS SSD products; our outlook for enterprise and SSD businesses; data growth and its drivers; enterprise storage; and our ability to address the space, our non-PC businesses and the PC market demand; and our ability to respond demand changes; china's Ministry of Commerce matters; optimizing our business; anticipated contributions from our new businesses; and our financial performance, including our financial results; expectations for the September quarter; and earnings expectations for the second half of fiscal 2016. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially, including those listed in our quarterly report on Form 10-Q filed with the SEC on May 12, 2015. We undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect new information or events.
In addition, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the historical non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet that we have posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. [Operator Instructions] I also want to note, the copies of our Investors section of website immediately following the conclusion of this call. I will turn the call over to President and Chief Executive Officer, Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our June quarter performance and our outlook for the September quarter. Demand for our fourth fiscal quarter was lower than ex
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our June quarter performance and our outlook for the September quarter. 
Demand for our fourth fiscal quarter was lower than expected, given a weak PC market. In that context, I am satisfied with our performance. We reported revenues of $3.2 billion, non-GAAP gross margins of 29.8% and diluted earnings per share of $1.51. 
Our storage shipments for the June quarter were 56 exabytes, up 2% year-over-year. Our results reflect strong product and technology positioning, coupled with solid execution. 
Our Enterprise SSD revenue more than doubled year-over-year to $244 million, demonstrating the continued success and broadening customer acceptance of our leading SAS SSD products. We expanded our footprint in the Enterprise SSD space with the initial ramp of our new Ultrastar PCIe and VME offering. It has been qualified with several leading customers, and we expect revenue from this product to increase throughout fiscal 2016. 
We saw strong demand for our high-capacity Helium and 15K RPM 2.5-inch performance hard drives. Revenue from our video surveillance hard drives continued its rapid growth as we expanded our lineup of these purpose-built solutions. And we continue to see positive market reaction to the value proposition of our new Active Archive system. Our view of persistent data growth remains intact, driven by mobility and the cloud. The outlook for our enterprise storage business remains healthy, and we believe we are well positioned to address this growing market space. 
Regarding PC market demand. We believe it is prudent to remain cautious in the near term, given the timing of the Windows 10 and Skylight launches. That being said, we are seeing early signs of market stabilization, leading us to believe that PC market demand could pick up toward the end of this calendar year. A more stable PC market demand environment, coupled with continued strength in our enterprise business, provides the opportunity for improving financial performance as we move through the fiscal year. In the meantime, we will continue to be disciplined at the management of our business while being ready to address unanticipated upside if it materializes. 
I would like to comment on the status of our discussions with China's Ministry of Commerce. Since our last earnings call, we believe we have made meaningful progress. We have met with MOFCOM several times to discuss their review process and a potential timetable for them to complete their work. We have submitted a comprehensive report on the current market, which we believe shows that the storage ecosystem has evolved significantly in the last 3 years and that lifting the hold separate restriction will enhance competition, increase innovation and benefit customers. We have also met with several other stakeholders in China and shared our views on the benefits of lifting the hold separate. Based on our conversations with MOFCOM, we believe that they are working steadily on several fronts, and we are hopeful that they can conclude their valuation of our application to lift the hold separate in the near future. 
Olivier will now provide a summary of our June quarter performance and our outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the June quarter was $3.2 billion. We shipped a total of 48.5 million hard drives at an average selling price of $60. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 29.8%, and operating expenses totaled $516 million. Tax expense for the
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the June quarter was $3.2 billion. We shipped a total of 48.5 million hard drives at an average selling price of $60. 
Our non-GAAP gross margin was 29.8%, and operating expenses totaled $516 million. Tax expense for the June quarter was $27 million or 7% of non-GAAP pretax income. On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $356 million or $1.51 per share. 
In the June quarter, we generated $488 million in cash from operations, and our free cash flow totaled $332 million. 
Our CapEx totaled $156 million or 5% of revenue. We repurchased 2 million shares for $198 million. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share. 
We closed year-end with total cash and cash equivalents of $5 billion, of which approximately $700 million was held in the U.S. 
I will now provide our guidance for the September quarter. We expect revenue to be in the range of $3.2 billion to $3.3 billion. Excluding the amortization of intangibles, we expect gross margin percentage to be roughly flat with our June quarter, operating expenses of approximately $575 million, and accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share between $1.50 and $1.60. 
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question is from Ms. Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question is from Ms. Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I believe coming into the June quarter, you had expected a fixed cost absorption hit on gross margins. it doesn't look like inventory and the balance sheet came down in June. So just curious if you can walk through the gross margin drivers in September. A
componenttext: I believe coming into the June quarter, you had expected a fixed cost absorption hit on gross margins. it doesn't look like inventory and the balance sheet came down in June. So just curious if you can walk through the gross margin drivers in September. And particularly, given the high inventory, why don't we see a hit on gross margins as you go into the next quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we had to manage in the June quarter [indiscernible]. First of all, to your point, fixed cost absorption was an issue because of the lower TAM, and we were able to mitigate -- more than mitigate this negative effect through two factors: first of all, m
componenttext: So we had to manage in the June quarter [indiscernible]. First of all, to your point, fixed cost absorption was an issue because of the lower TAM, and we were able to mitigate -- more than mitigate this negative effect through two factors: first of all, mix up improvement and also management of our cost base.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on OpEx, which was down $30 million again in the June quarter. Where are those cost savings coming from in light of the restrictions around MOFCOM? And do you still see the same net savings to the extent that you get that MOFCOM app
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on OpEx, which was down $30 million again in the June quarter. Where are those cost savings coming from in light of the restrictions around MOFCOM? And do you still see the same net savings to the extent that you get that MOFCOM approval over the next couple of quarters?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So two parts in your question. On part number one, most of the saving in the quarter is due to lower existing compensation or lower compensation in total due to, obviously, the performance of the company. Vis-a-vis MOFCOM, the synergies we have announced
componenttext: So two parts in your question. On part number one, most of the saving in the quarter is due to lower existing compensation or lower compensation in total due to, obviously, the performance of the company. Vis-a-vis MOFCOM, the synergies we have announced are still intact. As a reminder, we haven't stated that synergies in OpEx will be in the range of $400 million a year and that COGS synergy will be material and on top of that number.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.
componenttext: And the next question is from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One question, one follow-up as well. Going back to Katy's question. When you look at the gross margin this quarter, which is quite impressive, considering a 120 million down to 111 million unit number for the industry, what is the impact to gross margin t
componenttext: One question, one follow-up as well. Going back to Katy's question. When you look at the gross margin this quarter, which is quite impressive, considering a 120 million down to 111 million unit number for the industry, what is the impact to gross margin that you've seen, given the inability or given the deleverage from a fixed cost absorption perspective? I mean, if it weren't for the lower TAM, I'm kind of asking, what kind of gross margin could you have attained in this last quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the impact of lack of absorption is much you're right. We're not going to give any details of how much it was, but indeed, it would have been a material increase in the margin rate.
componenttext: So the impact of lack of absorption is much you're right. We're not going to give any details of how much it was, but indeed, it would have been a material increase in the margin rate.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing, Aaron, to keep in mind, which is that obviously, the part of the business that was weaker, which is PC-related, so our client business carries a lower margin. Yes, there's an sorption impact in terms of having less units, but the effect o
componenttext: The other thing, Aaron, to keep in mind, which is that obviously, the part of the business that was weaker, which is PC-related, so our client business carries a lower margin. Yes, there's an sorption impact in terms of having less units, but the effect of having a lower amount of -- lower-margin business naturally provides, if you want to call it, accretion from a gross margin perspective because our software business, whether it be from a revenue or a unit or, for that matter, from an earnings perspective was entirely driven by a slower PC market.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up, when we look into the back half of the year, I think last quarter, we talked about kind of 40-60 split in terms of enterprise demand, particularly from the hyperscale and cloud guys. What's your current outlook relative to that f
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up, when we look into the back half of the year, I think last quarter, we talked about kind of 40-60 split in terms of enterprise demand, particularly from the hyperscale and cloud guys. What's your current outlook relative to that for the second half in the enterprise side? And is that not a positive factor to consider from a mix perspective on gross margin going forward?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the 40-60 split that, I believe, was talked about last quarter, I think, was on the CA call, that is consistently where it's run over the last several years. We would expect, generally speaking, for that pattern to hold, plus or minus a few percentage
componenttext: So the 40-60 split that, I believe, was talked about last quarter, I think, was on the CA call, that is consistently where it's run over the last several years. We would expect, generally speaking, for that pattern to hold, plus or minus a few percentage points, for this calendar year as well. And then I'll ask Olivier to comment on the puts and takes in terms of gross margin for our September quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the statement about the 40-60 [indiscernible] exabytes statement. So relative to our guidance, we are guiding to roughly flat, meaning it could be slightly up or slightly down. Obviously, we have many puts and takes, which could unfold during the quart
componenttext: So the statement about the 40-60 [indiscernible] exabytes statement. So relative to our guidance, we are guiding to roughly flat, meaning it could be slightly up or slightly down. Obviously, we have many puts and takes, which could unfold during the quarter. Enterprise could be stronger. PC demand could be stronger that could be dilutive to the margin rate. And we think that roughly flat is as good as we can guide at this stage, Aaron.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Joseph Wittine from Longbow Research.
componenttext: And the next question is from Joseph Wittine from Longbow Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I understand the PC market is rough, but your shipments are eroding faster than the industry. You're down about 30% year-over-year. PC units down about low double digits. So curious why your decelerating so much faster? What chunk of it is inventory being
componenttext: I understand the PC market is rough, but your shipments are eroding faster than the industry. You're down about 30% year-over-year. PC units down about low double digits. So curious why your decelerating so much faster? What chunk of it is inventory being taken down, therefore, you get some sort of snap back versus how much it's coming kind of the ongoing secular decline in hard drive attached rates within PCs? Any color will be helpful.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So two comments on that. You've sort of -- you've hit on them. But we're not entire visibility on those, by the way. But we believe that there has been meaningful inventory drawdown both on throughout the supply chain from a PC perspective. So -- and
componenttext: Yes. So two comments on that. You've sort of -- you've hit on them. But we're not entire visibility on those, by the way. But we believe that there has been meaningful inventory drawdown both on throughout the supply chain from a PC perspective. So -- and we certainly, from our own company perspective, have been very careful to not overdrive the market in terms of shipping too much inventory into our customers. And so we've seen a sharper decline in our client business than what we've seen from a broader PC perspective because of what we believe to be a meaningful spinning of the overall inventory supply line. That's one factor. To what extent that happened? That's difficult to determine. But clearly, our customers do not want to have or do not want to run the risk of having "obsolete inventory" in front of the Intel and the Microsoft transition. So that's clearly caused them to draw their inventory levels down. The second thing is that we naturally are going to decline faster than the broader PC market because of the increasing attached rate of solid-state devices, replacing hard drives, which is consistent, by the way, with our expectations. So that helps to explain at least some of the disconnect on our numbers versus the broader PC industry.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, Steve. And I guess, a follow-on, what does guidance assume as far as PC inventory in the third quarter? And what's the TAM baked in that as well?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, Steve. And I guess, a follow-on, what does guidance assume as far as PC inventory in the third quarter? And what's the TAM baked in that as well?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if you look at -- let me give you some data points to contemplate. Obviously, we haven't seen big eighths [ph] -- Toshiba's numbers published yet. So we don't know where they ended up. But we would expect that the TAM for last quarter to be somewhere b
componenttext: So if you look at -- let me give you some data points to contemplate. Obviously, we haven't seen big eighths [ph] -- Toshiba's numbers published yet. So we don't know where they ended up. But we would expect that the TAM for last quarter to be somewhere between 110 and 112 depending upon where Toshiba lands. The TAM that we are using for purposes of our guidance, or assuming for purposes of the guidance, would approximate $115 million. The increase from, let's just use $110 million because it's a round number, from $110 million to $115 million, that increase is driven by two factors: seasonal increase in gaming, seasonal increase in branded. That would imply that other segments of the market are flat from a unit perspective. And when you get into the PC market, we would expect that, that to be roughly flat, at least as it relates to hard drive shipments into the market. From an enterprise perspective, we believe that units will be roughly flat. Keep in mind, one of the comments that we made is that we believe that there will be meaningful increase in terms of exabyte shipments that as we're mixing up the higher capacities and shipping 6 terabyte and 8 terabyte, obviously the unit consumption gets affected by that such that the unit increase is more muted.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Rick Kugele with Needham & Company.
componenttext: And the next question is from Rick Kugele with Needham & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just my two questions will be, first and foremost, on Helium. Can you give us a sense on how much of your enterprise business today is based on Helium? And competitively, when you do come up against another offering that is more traditional-based, presuma
componenttext: Just my two questions will be, first and foremost, on Helium. Can you give us a sense on how much of your enterprise business today is based on Helium? And competitively, when you do come up against another offering that is more traditional-based, presumably you're coming in at a premium because of the -- so just competitively, when you go up against someone else for more traditional drive and air-based drive with Helium, can you just talk about your win rates there? Just understand the dynamic as we move to higher and higher capacities that are exclusively Helium-based.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The first thing, Rich, is that not going to provide any additional color on the volume of our Capacity Enterprise drives, that's Helium versus traditional in-air drives at this point. But obviously, as we indicated over time, we'll be transitioning
componenttext: Sure. The first thing, Rich, is that not going to provide any additional color on the volume of our Capacity Enterprise drives, that's Helium versus traditional in-air drives at this point. But obviously, as we indicated over time, we'll be transitioning particularly when we go to the 10 terabyte and things like that. We're -- on the 6 terabyte is tended to be our last in-air product. So as customers makes up, larger and larger percentage of our business, it's going to be Helium-based. Relative to head-to-head competition, a couple of things to keep in mind. First thing is, is that we -- the customers that we're dealing with have pretty sophisticated total cost of ownership algorithms that allow them to look at more than just simply the price of the hard drive. And we recognize the fact that clearly, the price of the hard drive is one element, but when we factor in from a total cost of ownership perspective, and we're going head-to-head at a similar capacity point, we actually have pretty good win rates. And in some cases, obviously, when we transition to the 8 terabyte right now, we got a distinct advantage from the capacity perspective, which assists us a lot in terms of winning business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the non-PC percentage of revenue, do you have a sense for what that might be exiting fiscal '16?
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the non-PC percentage of revenue, do you have a sense for what that might be exiting fiscal '16?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Rich. And I dare to speculate, to tell you the truth, because a lot of it will depend upon what happens with the PC business. And so I don't think I want to try to forecast a number at this point because I would happily have it rem
componenttext: That's a good question, Rich. And I dare to speculate, to tell you the truth, because a lot of it will depend upon what happens with the PC business. And so I don't think I want to try to forecast a number at this point because I would happily have it remain the same because that would mean that the PC business was actually looking a little bit better. And that if we don't see the PC market pick up, then obviously, our non-PC business is going to continue to increase as a percentage of the total. So that's a long nonanswer to your question, Rich.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.
componenttext: And the next question is from Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had one for each, Steve and Olivier. Steve, just kind of following up on the last question. As you think out kind of past this year into [indiscernible] '16, what is a prudent way for us to think about how you guys do normalized exabyte growth? I know i
componenttext: I had one for each, Steve and Olivier. Steve, just kind of following up on the last question. As you think out kind of past this year into [indiscernible] '16, what is a prudent way for us to think about how you guys do normalized exabyte growth? I know it might be -- there's a lot of moving parts in the current environment, but I guess, whatever your latest thought process there would be helpful. And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if you look at exabyte today, see it to be in the high single digits, with some new answers as you go by line of business. Capacity Enterprise was a big, obviously, focus. We would expect it to grow in the 50% range, which is what we have observed on a
componenttext: So if you look at exabyte today, see it to be in the high single digits, with some new answers as you go by line of business. Capacity Enterprise was a big, obviously, focus. We would expect it to grow in the 50% range, which is what we have observed on average for the last 4 quarters, a strong performance on that standpoint.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then Olivier, for you, just on the OpEx levels to sort of expect going forward. I believe, last quarter, before PC is that they did, that you were looking sort of like a 5 90 [ph] plus or minus level depending on where in the year we are. You
componenttext: Got it. And then Olivier, for you, just on the OpEx levels to sort of expect going forward. I believe, last quarter, before PC is that they did, that you were looking sort of like a 5 90 [ph] plus or minus level depending on where in the year we are. You pulled back on cost this quarter, although it sounds like maybe this was sort of a little on the prudent side. So we'd love to get how we should think about OpEx levels going forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we guided to a low number, $575 million for the next quarter. It's probably a number we would stick to for the coming 4 quarters based upon the adjustment we have to do to our cost base, based upon the time level.
componenttext: So we guided to a low number, $575 million for the next quarter. It's probably a number we would stick to for the coming 4 quarters based upon the adjustment we have to do to our cost base, based upon the time level.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Sherri Scribner from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question is from Sherri Scribner from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about your view and what you're hearing from your cloud enterprise customers at this point, given the fact that a number of the big cloud providers, Twitter, Amazon, Facebook, are all cutting their CapEx plan. You guys sound on the ca
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about your view and what you're hearing from your cloud enterprise customers at this point, given the fact that a number of the big cloud providers, Twitter, Amazon, Facebook, are all cutting their CapEx plan. You guys sound on the call to be very bullish on capacity growth, but just wanted to get your sense of what those companies' plans are, given they're cutting their CapEx.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me talk about kind of in general terms. I mean, the first thing is, which may sound like an obvious statement, but we have a number of customers. And relative to any one particular period, we may see a relative strength or relative weakness in pa
componenttext: Yes. Let me talk about kind of in general terms. I mean, the first thing is, which may sound like an obvious statement, but we have a number of customers. And relative to any one particular period, we may see a relative strength or relative weakness in particular accounts. And by the way, obviously, part of our job, from a management perspective, is to manage whatever, either call it segment or customer volatility from a demand perspective that we might happen to see. And so there's always going to be noise in that regard that we have to deal with. In general, as an overall statement, we feel very good about our positioning from a product perspective, from a technology perspective, from a customer perspective positioning standpoint. And the numbers that we're looking at are relatively consistent with our previous expectations. And we continue to expect that in the back half of the year. We're going to see pretty healthy pickup from an overall exabyte perspective, and we'll see how that translates from a unit perspective as we ship higher-capacity drives. And -- but it should also drive a pretty healthy first half to back half revenue increase in terms of its contribution to our overall business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just thinking about that exabyte growth accelerating in the back half of the year. What is driving that? Is that further builds by some of your customers? Is that something that you've seen sort of seasonally? I'm just trying to
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just thinking about that exabyte growth accelerating in the back half of the year. What is driving that? Is that further builds by some of your customers? Is that something that you've seen sort of seasonally? I'm just trying to understand that a bit better.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little bit of context. So if you look over the last roughly 3 years, particularly in that space, about 40% of exabyte shipments are in the first half of the year, about 60% in the second half of the year. We're expecting, roughly speakin
componenttext: Let me give you a little bit of context. So if you look over the last roughly 3 years, particularly in that space, about 40% of exabyte shipments are in the first half of the year, about 60% in the second half of the year. We're expecting, roughly speaking, that kind of a split to continue. And I would suggest that, that's due to normal seasonality in terms of the nature of that business. It doesn't necessarily mean that there's an acceleration per se in that segment from a year-on-year perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Wamsi Mohan of Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from Wamsi Mohan of Bank of America.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Headcount's down 8% year-on-year. Can you talk a little bit about where those adjustments were made? How much was manufacturing-related versus maybe G&A that can persist into the back half? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The majority of that is our manufacturing workers in Asia. [indiscernible] all of it. Yes.
componenttext: The majority of that is our manufacturing workers in Asia. [indiscernible] all of it. Yes.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the MOFCOM side, I mean, you sound more optimistic today versus 90 days ago. First, am I correct in assuming that? Clearly, you've been meeting them throughout this process. So what's giving you an increased confidence of a speedy resolution? And i
componenttext: And on the MOFCOM side, I mean, you sound more optimistic today versus 90 days ago. First, am I correct in assuming that? Clearly, you've been meeting them throughout this process. So what's giving you an increased confidence of a speedy resolution? And if we don't have a resolution in 6 months, would you be like negatively surprised?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the comment that I made on my prepared remarks, frankly speaking, kinds of stands on its own in terms of the commentary and the reasons why we believe that -- or that we're hopeful for a decision in the near term. So I would refer you back to my scr
componenttext: Well, the comment that I made on my prepared remarks, frankly speaking, kinds of stands on its own in terms of the commentary and the reasons why we believe that -- or that we're hopeful for a decision in the near term. So I would refer you back to my script for a detail in terms of that. Your question with regards to would I be surprised if we didn't have a decision before the end of the year is, obviously, a tricky question. I don't know if I would say surprised, but obviously, I would be surely disappointed if we didn't have a decision by then.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Steven Fox from Cross Research.
componenttext: The next question is from Steven Fox from Cross Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about your SSD business. It just had some fantastic growth over the past year. What are the key drivers? And how do you think your growth is comparing to the marketplace at this point?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about your SSD business. It just had some fantastic growth over the past year. What are the key drivers? And how do you think your growth is comparing to the marketplace at this point?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, a couple of comments on that. The first thing is that from an overall growth perspective, we do believe that we are gaining market share in that market, and so we are exceeding industry growth averages. The lion share, this is consistent with the pa
componenttext: Sure, a couple of comments on that. The first thing is that from an overall growth perspective, we do believe that we are gaining market share in that market, and so we are exceeding industry growth averages. The lion share, this is consistent with the past, the lion share of our revenue continues to be related to our SAS-based SSD product. The one really encouraging thing for my perspective is that we're beginning to see a much more meaningful contribution from our PCIe NVM product. It's still relatively small compared to the 2 44 [ph], but we saw a nice pickup from calendar Q1 into calendar Q2. We're gaining increasing momentum, and we expect, as I indicated in my prepared remarks, that revenue contribution from those products will continue to increase as we move through fiscal 2016.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just a quick follow-up. Given where units are right now and some of the average capacity you've talked about, what are the chances that you would consider writing down some capacity at certain parts of the production process in the near te
componenttext: Great. And then just a quick follow-up. Given where units are right now and some of the average capacity you've talked about, what are the chances that you would consider writing down some capacity at certain parts of the production process in the near term?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we are constantly evaluating that and constantly looking that. And you can see that we have taken, as the market has declined, I mean, let's be clear. The market has declined significantly over the last 2 to 3 years. And we have consistently evalu
componenttext: Yes. So we are constantly evaluating that and constantly looking that. And you can see that we have taken, as the market has declined, I mean, let's be clear. The market has declined significantly over the last 2 to 3 years. And we have consistently evaluated our investments and our capital levels as we've seen the market come to new different levels. We're going to continue to do that and continue to take actions to make sure we rightsize not only our manufacturing capabilities but also our investments from an OpEx perspective to make sure that we do our best to provide appropriate financial performance for shareholders.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Christian Schwab, Craig Hallum Capital Group.
componenttext: And the next question is from Christian Schwab, Craig Hallum Capital Group.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I have a follow-up similar to that line of thinking. Our non-PC revenue has been -- your revenue, I should say, has been fairly consistent at about $2 billion to $2.2 billion a quarter for the last few years. When we look at your gross profit dolla
componenttext: Great. I have a follow-up similar to that line of thinking. Our non-PC revenue has been -- your revenue, I should say, has been fairly consistent at about $2 billion to $2.2 billion a quarter for the last few years. When we look at your gross profit dollars generated, I would assume that it's higher than the non-PC revenue, meaning that, that 70% plus of your gross profit dollars are generated in non-PC products. Is that fair?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Without confirming the exact number that you quoted, the non-PC areas of our business carry a higher gross profit profile than our traditional client business. And so if 65% of our revenue contribution is non-PC, then obviously, the profit contribution of
componenttext: Without confirming the exact number that you quoted, the non-PC areas of our business carry a higher gross profit profile than our traditional client business. And so if 65% of our revenue contribution is non-PC, then obviously, the profit contribution of that is greater.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, right. So I guess, where I'm going with it is if we get MOFCOM approval and we start to write down more capacity in notebooks and PCs, we're going to print cash for as long as that non-PC revenue doesn't dissipate, right?
componenttext: Right, right. So I guess, where I'm going with it is if we get MOFCOM approval and we start to write down more capacity in notebooks and PCs, we're going to print cash for as long as that non-PC revenue doesn't dissipate, right?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we believe, yes. We would believe that there will be significant synergies as a result of the lifting of the hold separate, which will not only benefit our company, our shareholders, but will also be able to benefit consumers in the form of more comp
componenttext: Yes, we believe, yes. We would believe that there will be significant synergies as a result of the lifting of the hold separate, which will not only benefit our company, our shareholders, but will also be able to benefit consumers in the form of more competitive pricing.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: And if we look at the 76,000 people we got left working for us, what -- can you remind us the breakout of those employees roughly?

componenttext: We haven't broken that out. No.

componenttext: The next question is from Keith Bachman from Bank of Montral.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Olivier, can you help -- what was the charge for the -- there's $104 million charge this quarter that was reversed out from GAAP to non-GAAP. What was that for?
componenttext: Olivier, can you help -- what was the charge for the -- there's $104 million charge this quarter that was reversed out from GAAP to non-GAAP. What was that for?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The majority of that, all of it was due to us resizing our business in order to cope with the current time level. So all of it is the adjustment of our supply chain, end-to-end, to face the new reality.
componenttext: The majority of that, all of it was due to us resizing our business in order to cope with the current time level. So all of it is the adjustment of our supply chain, end-to-end, to face the new reality.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So is it permanent reduction on the fixed cost base? Was it -- trying to understand, was it a onetime event? Or does that carry forward and reduce your fixed costs?
componenttext: So is it permanent reduction on the fixed cost base? Was it -- trying to understand, was it a onetime event? Or does that carry forward and reduce your fixed costs?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we will -- that would be one adjustment we have done among others in the past. And this one will carry its impact going forward indeed.
componenttext: So we will -- that would be one adjustment we have done among others in the past. And this one will carry its impact going forward indeed.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Steve, one for you then. In terms of MOFCOM, is it a 0-sum game? And what I mean by that is, this has been puts and takes here, it feels like its ebbs and flows over the last year unchanged. What happens if the Chinese government just doesn't say an
componenttext: Okay. Steve, one for you then. In terms of MOFCOM, is it a 0-sum game? And what I mean by that is, this has been puts and takes here, it feels like its ebbs and flows over the last year unchanged. What happens if the Chinese government just doesn't say anything this goes on for perpetuity? And what I mean by that is a Western Digital have plans, contingency plans, whereby they can reduce costs even without the hold separate that would at least get it some of the cost savings that you've identified? Or do you need to get MOFCOM to really take your cost structure meaningfully lower from this juncture?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're going to continue evaluate all of our options. But I think it's very dangerous, Keith, for me to speculate as to what we would do if we had no response from MOFCOM.
componenttext: Well, we're going to continue evaluate all of our options. But I think it's very dangerous, Keith, for me to speculate as to what we would do if we had no response from MOFCOM.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question from Monika Garg of Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: The next question from Monika Garg of Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you maybe talk about what was like-for-like pricing in the quarter? And what do you expect in the September quarter as well?
componenttext: Could you maybe talk about what was like-for-like pricing in the quarter? And what do you expect in the September quarter as well?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Monika, nothing out of the ordinary. The market remains competitive, and we wouldn't characterize this quarter, the one we closed, very differently from the prior one. And we would expect that to prevail in the September quarter.
componenttext: Monika, nothing out of the ordinary. The market remains competitive, and we wouldn't characterize this quarter, the one we closed, very differently from the prior one. And we would expect that to prevail in the September quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Then as a follow-up, your enterprise revenue has grown significantly this year. Is it fair to think next -- in fiscal 2016, that could be greater than $1 billion business?
componenttext: Then as a follow-up, your enterprise revenue has grown significantly this year. Is it fair to think next -- in fiscal 2016, that could be greater than $1 billion business?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if we've provided a specific estimate in terms of what our revenue level will be. But we continue to expect that we're going to see nice growth in our overall enterprise business.
componenttext: I don't know if we've provided a specific estimate in terms of what our revenue level will be. But we continue to expect that we're going to see nice growth in our overall enterprise business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Bill Shope from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Bill Shope from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you give us some color on how we should think about margin transfer in your Enterprise SSD business relative to the Enterprise HDD business? I know you don't give the absolute levels, but if you could just give us some color how we should think about
componenttext: Can you give us some color on how we should think about margin transfer in your Enterprise SSD business relative to the Enterprise HDD business? I know you don't give the absolute levels, but if you could just give us some color how we should think about the trends relative, particularly on this becoming a much more significant part of the overall business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, we said in the past and continues to be true is that the gross margin, generally speaking, for our SSD business is below the corporate average, still very good margin but below corporate average. But it is clearly above the corporate average f
componenttext: Sure. Well, we said in the past and continues to be true is that the gross margin, generally speaking, for our SSD business is below the corporate average, still very good margin but below corporate average. But it is clearly above the corporate average from a return on invested capital because we don't have the same form of, call it, vertical integration investments.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, looking at your capital allocation. Obviously, you continue to give back cash to shareholders each quarter. But do you foresee any incremental change the capital allocation plans or near-term activity, given the recent selloff in the sto
componenttext: And then I guess, looking at your capital allocation. Obviously, you continue to give back cash to shareholders each quarter. But do you foresee any incremental change the capital allocation plans or near-term activity, given the recent selloff in the stock price and some of the concerns of -- that have pressured the stock relative to the market recently?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we look at capital allocation regularly, but we still believe that given at this point in time, giving back 50% [ph] of our free cash flow back to shareholders in the form of dividends and buyback is a balanced approach to reward our shareholders today
componenttext: So we look at capital allocation regularly, but we still believe that given at this point in time, giving back 50% [ph] of our free cash flow back to shareholders in the form of dividends and buyback is a balanced approach to reward our shareholders today but also to keep rewarding our shareholders tomorrow, to keep investing in a business. And we mentioned some attractive investments, helium, Enterprise SSD and Active Archive being a few examples.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Joe Yoo of Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question is from Joe Yoo of Citigroup.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I want to ask a more general question about mission-critical performance drivers, if I could. So I know you don't break out performance versus near line, but if you look industry data, mission-critical has been fairly flat, and actually, it's been
componenttext: Steve, I want to ask a more general question about mission-critical performance drivers, if I could. So I know you don't break out performance versus near line, but if you look industry data, mission-critical has been fairly flat, and actually, it's been growing in the last couple of quarters. And you're sort of in an interesting position where you can -- you sell both the SAS drives and SAS SSDs, which are largely viewed as substitutes. Can you help us understand why SAS drives remain so resilient despite such strong adoption from SSDs?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Are you talking relative to us or in general?
componenttext: Are you talking relative to us or in general?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Either. I mean, but maybe can start with WD.
componenttext: Either. I mean, but maybe can start with WD.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, if relative to us, if you remember, we had a whole in our portfolio where we did not have a competitive 2.5-inch small form factor SAS hard drive. We now have a competitive product. And so in that space, which albeit a relatively small part of the p
componenttext: Well, if relative to us, if you remember, we had a whole in our portfolio where we did not have a competitive 2.5-inch small form factor SAS hard drive. We now have a competitive product. And so in that space, which albeit a relatively small part of the performance enterprise market, we've been able to pick up some share in that space just by having a competitive product. So that's helped strengthen our relative performance from a performance standpoint. From a standpoint of SAS versus -- or not SAS, Enterprise SSD versus a small form factor hard drives, right now, we're not seeing much cannibalization per se. We do expect that there will be cannibalization over time. It tends to be workflow-driven in terms of the way the systems are configured. And so -- but like I said, there hasn't been cannibalization so far, but we do expect that, that will happen in the future and that there will be some crossover between 2.5-inch, 15K drives and SSDs in the future.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what is the critical factor and actually making that happen? Is it pricing in the cost of it?
componenttext: Okay. And what is the critical factor and actually making that happen? Is it pricing in the cost of it?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's pricing and also workflow-driven in terms of how systems are configured.Thank you again for joining us today. In closing, I want to thank all of our employees and suppliers for their commitment and outstanding execution and our customers for their
componenttext:
It's pricing and also workflow-driven in terms of how systems are configured.
Thank you again for joining us today. In closing, I want to thank all of our employees and suppliers for their commitment and outstanding execution and our customers for their continued business. Thank you so much.

componenttext: And thank you for your your participation in today's conference. All parties may now disconnect.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Western Digital's Fourth Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You ma
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Western Digital's Fourth Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As we begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response to your questions concerning, among others, our product and technology positioning; customer acceptance of our SAS SSD produc
componenttext:
Thank you. As we begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response to your questions concerning, among others, our product and technology positioning; customer acceptance of our SAS SSD products; our outlook for our enterprise and SSD businesses; data growth and its drivers; enterprise storage; and our ability to address the space, our non-PC businesses and the PC market demand; and our ability to respond demand changes; China's Ministry of Commerce matters; optimizing our business; anticipated contributions from our new businesses; and our financial performance, including our financial results; expectations for the September quarter; and earnings expectations for the second half of fiscal 2016. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially, including those listed in our quarterly report on Form 10-Q filed with the SEC on May 12, 2015. We undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect new information or events.
In addition, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet that we have posted on our Investor Relations section of our website. [Operator Instructions] I also want to note that copies of remarks of today's commentary by our Chief Executive Officer and CFO will be available on the Investors section of our website immediately following the conclusion of this call. I'll now turn the call over to President and Chief Executive Officer, Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our June quarter performance and our outlook for the September quarter.Demand for our fourth fiscal quarter was lower than exp
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our June quarter performance and our outlook for the September quarter.
Demand for our fourth fiscal quarter was lower than expected, given a weak PC market. In that context, I am satisfied with our performance. We reported revenues of $3.2 billion, non-GAAP gross margins of 29.8% and diluted earnings per share of $1.51.
Our storage shipments for the June quarter were 56 exabytes, up 2% year-over-year. Our results reflect strong product and technology positioning, coupled with solid execution.
Our Enterprise SSD revenue more than doubled year-over-year to $244 million, demonstrating the continued success and broadening customer acceptance of our leading SAS SSD products. We expanded our footprint in the Enterprise SSD space with the initial ramp of our new Ultrastar PCIe and VME offering. It has been qualified with several leading customers, and we expect revenue from this product to increase throughout fiscal 2016.
We saw strong demand for our high-capacity Helium and 15K RPM 2.5-inch performance hard drives. Revenue from our video surveillance hard drives continued its rapid growth as we expanded our lineup of these purpose-built solutions. And we continue to see positive market reaction to the value proposition of our new Active Archive system. Our view of persistent data growth remains intact, driven by mobility and the cloud. The outlook for our enterprise storage business remains healthy, and we believe we are well positioned to address this growing market space.
Regarding PC market demand, we believe it is prudent to remain cautious in the near term, given the timing of the Windows 10 and Skylake launches. That being said, we are seeing early signs of market stabilization, leading us to believe that PC market demand could pick up toward the end of this calendar year. A more stable PC market demand environment, coupled with continued strength in our enterprise business, provides the opportunity for improving financial performance as we move through the fiscal year. In the meantime, we will continue to be disciplined at the management of our business, while being ready to address unanticipated upside if it materializes.
I would like to comment on the status of our discussions with China's Ministry of Commerce. Since our last earnings call, we believe we have made meaningful progress. We have met with MOFCOM several times to discuss their review process and a potential timetable for them to complete their work. We've submitted a comprehensive report on the current market, which, we believe, shows that the storage ecosystem has evolved significantly in the last 3 years and that lifting the hold separate restriction will enhance competition, increase innovation and benefit customers. We've also met with several other stakeholders in China and shared our views on the benefits of lifting the hold separate. Based on our conversations with MOFCOM, we believe that they are working steadily on several fronts, and we are hopeful that they can conclude their evaluation of our application to lift the hold separate in the near future.
Olivier will now provide a summary of our June quarter performance and our outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the June quarter was $3.2 billion. We shipped a total of 48.5 million hard drives at an average selling price of $60.Our non-GAAP gross margin was 29.8%, and operating expenses totaled $516 million. Tax expense for the
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the June quarter was $3.2 billion. We shipped a total of 48.5 million hard drives at an average selling price of $60.
Our non-GAAP gross margin was 29.8%, and operating expenses totaled $516 million. Tax expense for the June quarter was $27 million or 7% of non-GAAP pretax income. On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $356 million or $1.51 per share.
In the June quarter, we generated $488 million in cash from operations, and our free cash flow totaled $332 million.
Our CapEx totaled $156 million or 5% of revenue. We repurchased 2 million shares for $198 million. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share.
We closed year-end with total cash and cash equivalents of $5 billion, of which approximately $700 million was held in the U.S.
I will now provide our guidance for the September quarter. We expect revenue to be in the range of $3.2 billion to $3.3 billion. Excluding the amortization of intangibles, we expect gross margin percentage to be roughly flat, with our June quarter operating expenses of approximately $575 million, and accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share between $1.50 and $1.60.
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our first question is from Ms. Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our first question is from Ms. Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I believe coming into the June quarter, you had expected a fixed cost absorption hit on gross margins. It doesn't look like inventory and the balance sheet came down in June. So just curious if you can walk through the gross margin drivers in September
componenttext: So I believe coming into the June quarter, you had expected a fixed cost absorption hit on gross margins. It doesn't look like inventory and the balance sheet came down in June. So just curious if you can walk through the gross margin drivers in September. And particularly, given the high inventory, why don't we see a hit on gross margins as you go into the next quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we had to manage in the June quarter [indiscernible]. First of all, to your point, fixed cost absorption was an issue because of the lower TAM, and we were able to mitigate -- more than mitigate this negative effect through 2 factors -- first of all, m
componenttext: So we had to manage in the June quarter [indiscernible]. First of all, to your point, fixed cost absorption was an issue because of the lower TAM, and we were able to mitigate -- more than mitigate this negative effect through 2 factors -- first of all, mix up improvement and also management of our cost base.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Katy?
componenttext: Katy?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just a quick follow-up on OpEx, which was down $30 million again in the June quarter. Where are those cost savings coming from in light of the restrictions around MOFCOM? And do you still see the same net savings to the extent that you get that MOFCO
componenttext: Yes. Just a quick follow-up on OpEx, which was down $30 million again in the June quarter. Where are those cost savings coming from in light of the restrictions around MOFCOM? And do you still see the same net savings to the extent that you get that MOFCOM approval over the next couple of quarters?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 2 parts in your question. On part #1, most of the saving in the quarter is due to lower executive compensation or lower compensation in total due to, obviously, the performance of the company. Vis-a-vis MOFCOM, the synergies we have announced are still
componenttext: So 2 parts in your question. On part #1, most of the saving in the quarter is due to lower executive compensation or lower compensation in total due to, obviously, the performance of the company. Vis-a-vis MOFCOM, the synergies we have announced are still intact. As a reminder, we have indicated that synergies in OpEx will be in the range of $400 million a year and that COGS synergies will be material and on top of that number.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.
componenttext: And the next question is from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One question, one follow-up as well. Going back to Katy's question, when you look at the gross margin this quarter, which is quite impressive, considering a 120 million down to 111 million unit number for the industry, what is the impact to gross margin t
componenttext: One question, one follow-up as well. Going back to Katy's question, when you look at the gross margin this quarter, which is quite impressive, considering a 120 million down to 111 million unit number for the industry, what is the impact to gross margin that you've seen, given the inability or given the deleverage from a fixed cost absorption perspective? I mean, if it weren't for the lower TAM, I'm kind of asking, what kind of gross margin could you have attained in this last quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the impact of lack of absorption is material, right? We're not going to give any details of how much it was, but indeed, it would have been a material increase in the margin rate.
componenttext: So the impact of lack of absorption is material, right? We're not going to give any details of how much it was, but indeed, it would have been a material increase in the margin rate.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing, Aaron, to keep in mind, which is that, obviously, the part of the business that was weaker, which is PC-related, so our client business, carries a lower margin. Yes, there's an absorption impact in terms of having less units, but the effe
componenttext: The other thing, Aaron, to keep in mind, which is that, obviously, the part of the business that was weaker, which is PC-related, so our client business, carries a lower margin. Yes, there's an absorption impact in terms of having less units, but the effect of having a lower amount of -- lower-margin business naturally provides, if you want to call it, accretion from a gross margin perspective, because our software business, whether it be from a revenue or a unit or, for that matter, from an earnings perspective, was entirely driven by a slower PC market.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up, when we look into the back half of the year, I think last quarter, we talked about a kind of 40-60 split in terms of enterprise demand, particularly from the hyperscale and cloud guys. What's your current outlook relative to that
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up, when we look into the back half of the year, I think last quarter, we talked about a kind of 40-60 split in terms of enterprise demand, particularly from the hyperscale and cloud guys. What's your current outlook relative to that for the second half in the enterprise side? And is that not a positive factor to consider from a mix perspective on gross margin going forward?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the 40-60 split that I believe was talked about last quarter, I think was on the CA call, that is consistently where it's run over the last several years. We would expect, generally speaking, to that -- for that pattern to hold, plus or minus a few per
componenttext: So the 40-60 split that I believe was talked about last quarter, I think was on the CA call, that is consistently where it's run over the last several years. We would expect, generally speaking, to that -- for that pattern to hold, plus or minus a few percentage points, for this calendar year as well. And then I'll ask Olivier to comment on the puts and takes in terms of gross margin for our September quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the statement about the 40-60 [indiscernible] exabytes statement. So relative to our guidance, we are guiding to roughly flat, meaning it could be slightly up or slightly down. Obviously, we have many puts and takes, which could unfold during the quart
componenttext: So the statement about the 40-60 [indiscernible] exabytes statement. So relative to our guidance, we are guiding to roughly flat, meaning it could be slightly up or slightly down. Obviously, we have many puts and takes, which could unfold during the quarter. Enterprise could be stronger. PC demand could be stronger that could be dilutive to the margin rate. And we think that roughly flat is as good as we can guide at this stage, Aaron.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Joe Wittine with Longbow Research.
componenttext: And the next question is from Joe Wittine with Longbow Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I understand the PC market is rough, but your shipments are eroding faster than the industry. You're down about 30% year-over-year, PC units down about low double digits. So curious why your decelerating so much faster? What chunk of it is -- is inventori
componenttext: I understand the PC market is rough, but your shipments are eroding faster than the industry. You're down about 30% year-over-year, PC units down about low double digits. So curious why your decelerating so much faster? What chunk of it is -- is inventories being taken down, therefore, you get some sort of snap back versus how much is kind of just the ongoing secular decline in hard drive attach rates within PCs? Any color would be helpful.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So 2 comments on that. I mean, you've sort of -- you've hit on them. But we don't have entire visibility of this by the way. But we believe that there has been a meaningful inventory drawdown, both on -- throughout the supply chain from a PC perspect
componenttext: Yes. So 2 comments on that. I mean, you've sort of -- you've hit on them. But we don't have entire visibility of this by the way. But we believe that there has been a meaningful inventory drawdown, both on -- throughout the supply chain from a PC perspective. So -- and we certainly, from our own company perspective, have been very careful to not overdrive the market in terms of shipping too much inventory into our customers. And so we've seen a sharper decline in our client business than what we've seen from a broader PC perspective because of what we believe to be a meaningful thinning of the overall inventory supply line, that's one factor. To what extent that's happened, that's difficult to determine. But clearly, our customers do not want to have or do not want to run the risk of having "obsolete inventory" in front of the Intel and the Microsoft transition, so that's clearly caused them to draw their inventory levels down. The second thing is that we naturally are going to decline faster than the broader PC market because of the increasing attach rate of solid-state devices replacing hard drives, which is consistent, by the way, with our expectations. So that helps to explain at least some of the disconnect on our numbers versus the broader PC industry.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful, Steve. And I guess, the follow-on would be, what does guidance assume as far as PC inventories in the third quarter? And what's the TAM baked in that as well?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful, Steve. And I guess, the follow-on would be, what does guidance assume as far as PC inventories in the third quarter? And what's the TAM baked in that as well?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if you look at -- let me give you some data points to contemplate. Obviously, we haven't seen Seagate's or Toshiba's numbers published yet, so we don't know where they ended up. But we would expect that the TAM for last quarter to be somewhere between
componenttext: So if you look at -- let me give you some data points to contemplate. Obviously, we haven't seen Seagate's or Toshiba's numbers published yet, so we don't know where they ended up. But we would expect that the TAM for last quarter to be somewhere between 110 million and 112 million, depending upon where Toshiba lands. The TAM that we are using for purposes of our guidance, or assuming for purposes of the guidance, would approximate 115 million. The increase from, let's just use 110 million because it's a round number, from $110 million to $115 million, that increase is driven by 2 factors:  seasonal increase in gaming; seasonal increase in branded. That would imply that other segments of the market are flat from a unit perspective. And when you get into the PC market, we would expect that to be roughly flat, at least as it relates to hard drive shipments into the market. From an enterprise perspective, we believe that units will be roughly flat. Keep in mind, one of the comments that we made is that we believe that there will be meaningful increase in terms of exabyte shipments that as we're mixing up the higher capacities and shipping 6 terabyte and 8 terabyte, obviously, the unit consumption gets affected by that such that the unit increase is more muted.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Rich Kugele of Needham & Company.
componenttext: And the next question is from Rich Kugele of Needham & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just my 2 questions will be, first and foremost, on Helium. Can you give us a sense on how much of your enterprise business today is based on Helium? And competitively, when you do come up against another offering that is more traditional-based, presumabl
componenttext:
Just my 2 questions will be, first and foremost, on Helium. Can you give us a sense on how much of your enterprise business today is based on Helium? And competitively, when you do come up against another offering that is more traditional-based, presumably you're coming in at a premium because of the
[Technical Difficulty]
Can you hear me all right?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, you broke up for a second, Rich.
componenttext: Yes, you broke up for a second, Rich.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just competitively, when you go up against someone else with a more traditional drive -- in-air-based drives with Helium, can you just talk about your win rates there, just to understand the dynamic as we move to higher and higher capacities that
componenttext: Okay. So just competitively, when you go up against someone else with a more traditional drive -- in-air-based drives with Helium, can you just talk about your win rates there, just to understand the dynamic as we move to higher and higher capacities that are exclusively Helium-based?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The first thing, Rich, is that -- I'm not going to provide any additional color on the volume of our Capacity Enterprise drives, that's Helium versus traditional in-air drives at this point. But obviously, as we indicated over time, we'll be transit
componenttext: Sure. The first thing, Rich, is that -- I'm not going to provide any additional color on the volume of our Capacity Enterprise drives, that's Helium versus traditional in-air drives at this point. But obviously, as we indicated over time, we'll be transitioning, particularly when we move to the 10 terabyte and things like that, where -- and the 6 terabyte is intended to be our last in-air product. So as customers mix up, a larger and larger percentage of our business is going to be Helium-based. Relative to head-to-head competition, a couple of things to keep in mind. First thing is that we -- the customers that we're dealing with have pretty sophisticated total cost of ownership algorithms that allow them to look at more than just simply the price of the hard drive. And we recognize the fact that clearly, the price of the hard drive is one element, but when we factor in from a total cost of ownership perspective, and we're going head-to-head at a similar capacity point, we actually have pretty good win rates. And in some cases, obviously, if we transition to the 8 terabyte right now, we've got a distinct advantage from that capacity perspective, which assists us a lot in terms of winning business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the non-PC percentage of revenue, do you have a sense for what that might be exiting fiscal '16?
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the non-PC percentage of revenue, do you have a sense for what that might be exiting fiscal '16?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Rich. And I dare to speculate, to tell you the truth, because a lot of it will depend upon what happens with the PC business. And so I don't think I want to try to forecast a number at this point because I would happily have it rem
componenttext: That's a good question, Rich. And I dare to speculate, to tell you the truth, because a lot of it will depend upon what happens with the PC business. And so I don't think I want to try to forecast a number at this point because I would happily have it remain the same because that would mean that the PC business was actually looking a little bit better. And -- but if we don't see the PC market pick up, then obviously, our non-PC business is going to continue to increase as a percentage of the total. So that's a long non-answer to your question, Rich.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.
componenttext: And the next question is from Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.
