componenttext: I've one for each, Steve and Olivier. Steve, just kind of following up on the last question. I know it might be -- there's a lot of moving parts in the current environment, but I guess -- but every year, your latest thought process there would be helpful. And then I have a follow-up.

componenttextpreview: So if you look at exabyte today, we see it to be in the high single digits, with some nuances as you go [indiscernible] business. Capacity Enterprise was a big, obviously, focus. We would expect it to grow in the 50% range, which is what we have observed
componenttext: So if you look at exabyte today, we see it to be in the high single digits, with some nuances as you go [indiscernible] business. Capacity Enterprise was a big, obviously, focus. We would expect it to grow in the 50% range, which is what we have observed on average for the last 4 quarters, a strong performance on that standpoint.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Got it. And then Olivier, for you, just on the OpEx levels you sort of expect going forward. I believe, last quarter, before PC [indiscernible] did that you were looking sort of like a 590, plus or minus, level depending on where in the year we are. You pulled back on cost this quarter although it sounds like maybe this was sort of a little on the prudent side. So we'd love to just get your take on how we should think about OpEx levels going forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we guided to a low number, $575 million, for the next quarter. It's probably a number we would stick to for the coming 4 quarters based upon the adjustment we had to do to our cost base, based upon the time level.
componenttext: So we guided to a low number, $575 million, for the next quarter. It's probably a number we would stick to for the coming 4 quarters based upon the adjustment we had to do to our cost base, based upon the time level.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question is from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask your view and what you're hearing from your cloud enterprise customers at this point, given the fact that a number of the big cloud providers, Twitter, Amazon, Facebook, are all cutting their CapEx plans. You guys sound on the call to
componenttext: I just wanted to ask your view and what you're hearing from your cloud enterprise customers at this point, given the fact that a number of the big cloud providers, Twitter, Amazon, Facebook, are all cutting their CapEx plans. You guys sound on the call to be very bullish on capacity growth, so just wanted to get your sense of what those companies' plans are, given they're cutting their CapEx.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me talk about kind of in general terms. I mean, the first thing is, which may sound very much like an obvious statement. But we have a number of customers and relative to any one particular period, we may see relative strength or relative weak
componenttext: Yes. So let me talk about kind of in general terms. I mean, the first thing is, which may sound very much like an obvious statement. But we have a number of customers and relative to any one particular period, we may see relative strength or relative weakness in particular accounts. And by the way, obviously, part of our job, from a management perspective, is to manage whatever, either call it segment or customer volatility from a demand perspective that we might happen to see. And so there's always going to be noise in that regard that we have to deal with. In general, as an overall statement, we feel very good about our positioning from a product perspective, from a technology perspective, from a customer perspective positioning standpoint. And the numbers that we're looking at are relatively consistent with our previous expectations, and we continue to expect that in the back half of the year. We're going to see pretty healthy pickup from an overall exabyte perspective, and we'll see how that translates from a unit perspective as we ship higher-capacity drives. And -- but it should also drive a pretty healthy first half to back half revenue increase in terms of its contribution to our overall business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And just thinking about that exabyte growth accelerating in back half of the year, what is driving that? Is that further builds by some of your customers? Is that something that you've seen sort of seasonally? I'm just trying to understand that a bit better.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little bit of context. So if you look over the last, roughly, 3 years, particularly in that space, about 40% of exabyte shipments are in the first half of the year, about 60% in the second half of the year. We're expecting, roughly speak
componenttext: Let me give you a little bit of context. So if you look over the last, roughly, 3 years, particularly in that space, about 40% of exabyte shipments are in the first half of the year, about 60% in the second half of the year. We're expecting, roughly speaking, that kind of a split to continue. And I would suggest that, that's just due to normal seasonality in terms of the nature of that business. It doesn't necessarily mean that there's an acceleration per se in that segment from a year-on-year perspective.

componenttext: Sure. A couple of comments on that. The first thing is that from an overall growth perspective, we do believe that we are gaining market share in that market and so we are exceeding industry growth averages. The lion's share -- this is consistent with the past, the lion's share of our revenue continues to be related to our SAS-based SSD product. The one really encouraging thing from my perspective is that we're beginning to see a much more meaningful contribution from our PCIe NVM product. It's still relatively small compared to the 244 million, but we saw a nice pickup from calendar Q1 into calendar Q2. We're gaining increasing momentum, and we expect, as I indicated in my prepared remarks, that the revenue contribution from those products will continue to increase as we move through fiscal 2016.

componenttext: Yes. So we are constantly evaluating that and constantly looking at that. And you can see that we have taken, as the market has declined -- I mean, let's be clear. The market has declined significantly over the last 2 to 3 years. And we have consistently evaluated our investments and our capital levels as we've seen the market come to new, different levels. We're going to continue to do that and continue to take actions to make sure we rightsize not only our manufacturing capabilities but also our investments from an OpEx perspective to make sure that we do our best to provide appropriate financial performance for our shareholders.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I wanted to ask a [indiscernible] more general question about mission-critical performance drivers, if I could. So I know you don't break out performance versus near line. But if you look industry data, mission-critical has been fairly flat, and ac
componenttext: Steve, I wanted to ask a [indiscernible] more general question about mission-critical performance drivers, if I could. So I know you don't break out performance versus near line. But if you look industry data, mission-critical has been fairly flat, and actually, it's been growing in the last couple of quarters. And you're in sort of an interesting position where you can -- you sell both the SAS drives and SAS SSDs, which are largely viewed as substitutes. So can you help us understand why SAS drives remain so resilient despite such strong adoption from SSDs?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Are you talking relative to us or in general?
componenttext: Are you talking relative to us or in general?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Either, I mean, but maybe you can start with WD.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, one of -- relative to us, if you remember, we had a hole in our portfolio where we did not have a competitive 2.5-inch, small form factor SAS hard drive. We now have a competitive product. And so in that space, which albeit a relatively small part o
componenttext: Well, one of -- relative to us, if you remember, we had a hole in our portfolio where we did not have a competitive 2.5-inch, small form factor SAS hard drive. We now have a competitive product. And so in that space, which albeit a relatively small part of the performance enterprise market, we've been able to pick up some share in that space just by having a competitive product. So that's helped strengthen our relative performance from a performance enterprise standpoint. From a standpoint of SAS versus -- or not SAS, Enterprise SSD versus a small form factor hard drive, right now, we're not seeing much cannibalization per se. We do expect that there will be cannibalization over time. It tends to be workload-driven in terms of the way the systems are configured. And so -- but like I said, there hasn't been cannibalization so far, but we do expect that, that will happen in the future and that there will be some crossover between 2.5-inch, 15K drives and SSDs in the future.

componenttext:

Thank you again for joining us today. In closing, I want to thank all of our employees and suppliers for their commitment and outstanding execution and our customers for their continued business. Thank you so much.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Western Digital's Fourth Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You ma
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Western Digital's Fourth Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2015. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As we begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response to your questions concerning, among others, our product and technology positioning; customer acceptance of our SAS SSD produc
componenttext:
Thank you. As we begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response to your questions concerning, among others, our product and technology positioning; customer acceptance of our SAS SSD products; our outlook for our enterprise and SSD businesses; data growth and its drivers; enterprise storage and our ability to address this space; our non-PC businesses and the PC market demand and our ability to respond demand changes; China's Ministry of Commerce matters; optimizing our business; anticipated contributions from our new businesses; and our financial performance, including our financial results; expectations for the September quarter; and earnings expectations for the second half of fiscal 2016. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially, including those listed in our quarterly report on Form 10-Q filed with the SEC on May 12, 2015. We undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect new information or events.
In addition, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet that we have posted on our Investor Relations section of our website. [Operator Instructions] I also want to note that copies of remarks of today's commentary by our Chief Executive Officer and CFO will be available on the Investors section of our website immediately following the conclusion of this call. I'll now turn the call over to President and Chief Executive Officer, Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our June quarter performance and our outlook for the September quarter.Demand for our fourth fiscal quarter was lower than exp
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. After my opening remarks, Olivier Leonetti will provide additional commentary on our June quarter performance and our outlook for the September quarter.
Demand for our fourth fiscal quarter was lower than expected, given a weak PC market. In that context, I am satisfied with our performance. We reported revenues of $3.2 billion, non-GAAP gross margins of 29.8% and diluted earnings per share of $1.51.
Our storage shipments for the June quarter were 56 exabytes, up 2% year-over-year. Our results reflect strong product and technology positioning, coupled with solid execution.
Our Enterprise SSD revenue more than doubled year-over-year to $244 million, demonstrating the continued success and broadening customer acceptance of our leading SAS SSD products. We expanded our footprint in the enterprise SSD space with the initial ramp of our new Ultrastar PCIe and VME offering. It has been qualified with several leading customers, and we expect revenue from this product to increase throughout fiscal 2016.
We saw strong demand for our high-capacity Helium and 15K RPM 2.5-inch performance hard drives. Revenue from our video surveillance hard drives continued its rapid growth as we expanded our lineup of these purpose-built solutions. And we continue to see positive market reaction to the value proposition of our new Active Archive system. Our view of persistent data growth remains intact, driven by mobility and the cloud. The outlook for our enterprise storage business remains healthy, and we believe we are well positioned to address this growing market space.
Regarding PC market demand, we believe it is prudent to remain cautious in the near term, given the timing of the Windows 10 and Skylake launches. That being said, we are seeing early signs of market stabilization leading us to believe that PC market demand could pick up toward the end of this calendar year. A more stable PC market demand environment, coupled with continued strength in our enterprise business, provides the opportunity for improving financial performance as we move through the fiscal year. In the meantime, we will continue to be disciplined in the management of our business, while being ready to address unanticipated upside if it materializes.
I would like to comment on the status of our discussions with China's Ministry of Commerce. Since our last earnings call, we believe we have made meaningful progress. We have met with MOFCOM several times to discuss their review process and a potential timetable for them to complete their work. We've submitted a comprehensive report on the current market, which, we believe, shows that the storage ecosystem has evolved significantly in the last 3 years and that lifting the hold separate restriction will enhance competition, increase innovation and benefit customers. We've also met with several other stakeholders in China and shared our views on the benefits of lifting the hold separate. Based on our conversations with MOFCOM, we believe that they are working steadily on several fronts, and we are hopeful that they can conclude their evaluation of our application to lift the hold separate in the near future.
Olivier will now provide a summary of our June quarter performance and our outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the June quarter was $3.2 billion. We shipped a total of 48.5 million hard drives at an average selling price of $60.Our non-GAAP gross margin was 29.8%, and operating expenses totaled $560 million. Tax expense for the
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the June quarter was $3.2 billion. We shipped a total of 48.5 million hard drives at an average selling price of $60.
Our non-GAAP gross margin was 29.8%, and operating expenses totaled $560 million. Tax expense for the June quarter was $27 million or 7% of non-GAAP pretax income. On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $356 million or $1.51 per share.
In the June quarter, we generated $488 million in cash from operations, and our free cash flow totaled $332 million.
Our CapEx totaled $156 million or 5% of revenue. We repurchased 2 million shares for $198 million. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share.
We closed year-end with total cash and cash equivalents of $5 billion, of which approximately $700 million was held in the U.S.
I will now provide our guidance for the September quarter. We expect revenue to be in the range of $3.2 billion to $3.3 billion. Excluding the amortization of intangibles, we expect gross margin percentage to be roughly flat with our June quarter, operating expenses of approximately $575 million, and accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share between $1.50 and $1.60.
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our first question is from Ms. Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our first question is from Ms. Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I believe coming into the June quarter, you had expected a fixed cost absorption hit on gross margins. It doesn't look like inventory on the balance sheet came down in June. So just curious if you can walk through the gross margin drivers in September.
componenttext: So I believe coming into the June quarter, you had expected a fixed cost absorption hit on gross margins. It doesn't look like inventory on the balance sheet came down in June. So just curious if you can walk through the gross margin drivers in September. And particularly, given the high inventory, why don't we see a hit on gross margins as you go into the next quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we had to manage in the June quarter various variables. First of all, to your point, fixed cost absorption was an issue because of the lower TAM, and we were able to mitigate -- more than mitigate this negative effect through 2 factors: first of all, m
componenttext: So we had to manage in the June quarter various variables. First of all, to your point, fixed cost absorption was an issue because of the lower TAM, and we were able to mitigate -- more than mitigate this negative effect through 2 factors: first of all, mix up improvement and also management of our cost base.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Katy?
componenttext: Katy?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just a quick follow-up on OpEx, which was down $30 million again in the June quarter. Where are those cost savings coming from in light of the restrictions around MOFCOM? And do you still see the same net savings to the extent that you get that MOFCO
componenttext: Yes. Just a quick follow-up on OpEx, which was down $30 million again in the June quarter. Where are those cost savings coming from in light of the restrictions around MOFCOM? And do you still see the same net savings to the extent that you get that MOFCOM approval over the next couple of quarters?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 2 parts in your question. On part #1, most of the saving in the quarter is due to lower executive compensation or lower compensation in total due to, obviously, the performance of the company. Vis-a-vis MOFCOM, the synergies we have announced are still
componenttext: So 2 parts in your question. On part #1, most of the saving in the quarter is due to lower executive compensation or lower compensation in total due to, obviously, the performance of the company. Vis-a-vis MOFCOM, the synergies we have announced are still intact. As a reminder, we have indicated that synergies in OpEx will be in the range of $400 million a year and that COGS synergies will be material and on top of that number.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.
componenttext: And the next question is from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One question, one follow-up as well. Going back to Katy's question, when you look at the gross margin this quarter, which is quite impressive considering a 120 million down to 111 million unit number for the industry, what is the impact to gross margin th
componenttext: One question, one follow-up as well. Going back to Katy's question, when you look at the gross margin this quarter, which is quite impressive considering a 120 million down to 111 million unit number for the industry, what is the impact to gross margin that you've seen, given the inability or given the deleverage from a fixed cost absorption perspective? I mean, if it weren't for the lower TAM, I'm kind of asking, what kind of gross margin could you have attained in this last quarter?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the impact of lack of absorption is material, right? We're not going to give any details of how much it was, but indeed, it would have been a material increase in the margin rate.
componenttext: So the impact of lack of absorption is material, right? We're not going to give any details of how much it was, but indeed, it would have been a material increase in the margin rate.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing, Aaron, to keep in mind, which is that, obviously, the part of the business that was weaker, which is PC-related, so our client business, carries a lower margin. Yes, there's an absorption impact in terms of having less units, but the effe
componenttext: The other thing, Aaron, to keep in mind, which is that, obviously, the part of the business that was weaker, which is PC-related, so our client business, carries a lower margin. Yes, there's an absorption impact in terms of having less units, but the effect of having a lower amount of -- lower-margin business naturally provides, if you want to call it, accretion from a gross margin perspective because our software business, whether it be from a revenue or a unit or, for that matter, from an earnings perspective, was entirely driven by a slower PC market.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up, when we look into the back half of the year, I think last quarter, we talked about a kind of 40-60 split in terms of enterprise demand, particularly from the hyperscale and cloud guys. What's your current outlook relative to that
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up, when we look into the back half of the year, I think last quarter, we talked about a kind of 40-60 split in terms of enterprise demand, particularly from the hyperscale and cloud guys. What's your current outlook relative to that for the second half in the enterprise side? And is that not a positive factor to consider from a mix perspective on gross margin going forward?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the 40-60 split that I believe was talked about last quarter, I think was on the CA call, that is consistently what it's run over the last several years. We would expect, generally speaking, to that -- for that pattern to hold, plus or minus a few perc
componenttext: So the 40-60 split that I believe was talked about last quarter, I think was on the CA call, that is consistently what it's run over the last several years. We would expect, generally speaking, to that -- for that pattern to hold, plus or minus a few percentage points, for this calendar year as well. And then, I'll ask Olivier to comment on the puts and takes in terms of gross margin for our September quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the statement about the 40-60 is mainly an exabytes statement. So relative to our guidance, we are guiding to roughly flat, meaning it could be slightly up or slightly down. Obviously, we have many puts and takes, which could unfold during the quarter.
componenttext: So the statement about the 40-60 is mainly an exabytes statement. So relative to our guidance, we are guiding to roughly flat, meaning it could be slightly up or slightly down. Obviously, we have many puts and takes, which could unfold during the quarter. Enterprise could be stronger. PC demand could be stronger, that could be dilutive to the margin rate. And we think that roughly flat is as good as we can guide at this stage, Aaron.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Joe Wittine with Longbow Research.
componenttext: And the next question is from Joe Wittine with Longbow Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I understand the PC market is rough, but your shipments are eroding faster than the industry. You're down about 30% year-over-year, PC units down about low double digits. So curious why your decelerating so much faster. What chunk of it is inventories bei
componenttext: I understand the PC market is rough, but your shipments are eroding faster than the industry. You're down about 30% year-over-year, PC units down about low double digits. So curious why your decelerating so much faster. What chunk of it is inventories being taken down, therefore, you get some sort of snap back versus how much is kind of just the ongoing secular decline in hard drive attach rates within PCs? Any color would be helpful.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So 2 comments on that. I mean, you've sort of -- you've hit on them, but we don't have entire visibility to this, oh by the way. But we believe that there has been a meaningful inventory drawdown, both on -- throughout the supply chain from a PC pers
componenttext: Yes. So 2 comments on that. I mean, you've sort of -- you've hit on them, but we don't have entire visibility to this, oh by the way. But we believe that there has been a meaningful inventory drawdown, both on -- throughout the supply chain from a PC perspective. So -- and we certainly, from our own company perspective, have been very careful to not overdrive the market in terms of shipping too much inventory into our customers. And so we've seen a sharper decline in our client business than what we've seen from a broader PC perspective because of what we believe to be a meaningful thinning of the overall inventory supply line. That's one factor. To what extent that's happened, that's difficult to determine. But clearly, our customers do not want to have or do not want to run the risk of having "obsolete inventory" in front of the Intel and the Microsoft transition, so that's clearly caused them to draw their inventory levels down. The second thing is that we naturally are going to decline faster than the broader PC market because of the increasing attach rate of solid-state devices replacing hard drives, which is consistent, oh by the way, with our expectations. So that helps to explain at least some of the disconnect on our numbers versus the broader PC industry.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful, Steve. Then I guess the follow-on would be, what does guidance assume as far as PC inventories in the third quarter? And what's the TAM baked in that as well?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful, Steve. Then I guess the follow-on would be, what does guidance assume as far as PC inventories in the third quarter? And what's the TAM baked in that as well?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if you look at -- let me give you some data points to contemplate. Obviously, we haven't seen Seagate's -- or Toshiba's numbers published yet, so we don't know where they ended up. But we would expect that the TAM for last quarter to be somewhere betwe
componenttext: So if you look at -- let me give you some data points to contemplate. Obviously, we haven't seen Seagate's -- or Toshiba's numbers published yet, so we don't know where they ended up. But we would expect that the TAM for last quarter to be somewhere between $110 million and $112 million, depending upon where Toshiba lands. The TAM that we are using for purposes of our guidance, or assuming for purposes of the guidance, would approximate $115 million. The increase from, let's just use 110 million because it's a round number, from $110 million to $115 million, that increase is driven by 2 factors:  seasonal increase in gaming; seasonal increase in branded. That would imply that other segments of the market are flat from a unit perspective. And when you get into the PC market, we would expect that to be roughly flat, at least as it relates to hard drive shipments into the market. From an enterprise perspective, we believe that units will be roughly flat. Keep in mind, one of the comments that we made is that we believe that there will be meaningful increase in terms of exabyte shipments that, as we're mixing up the higher capacities and shipping 6 terabyte and 8 terabyte, obviously, the unit consumption gets affected by that such that the unit increase is more muted.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Rich Kugele of Needham & Company.
componenttext: And the next question is from Rich Kugele of Needham & Company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just my 2 questions will be, first and foremost, on Helium. Can you give us a sense on how much of your enterprise business today is based on Helium? And competitively, when you do come up against another offering that is more traditional-based, presumabl
componenttext:
Just my 2 questions will be, first and foremost, on Helium. Can you give us a sense on how much of your enterprise business today is based on Helium? And competitively, when you do come up against another offering that is more traditional-based, presumably you're coming in at a premium because of the
[Technical Difficulty]
Can you hear me all right?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, you broke up for a second, Rich.
componenttext: Yes, you broke up for a second, Rich.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just competitively, when you go up against someone else with a more traditional drive -- an air-based drive with Helium, can you just talk about your win rates there, just to understand the dynamic as we move to higher and higher capacities that
componenttext: Okay. So just competitively, when you go up against someone else with a more traditional drive -- an air-based drive with Helium, can you just talk about your win rates there, just to understand the dynamic as we move to higher and higher capacities that are exclusively Helium-based?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The first thing, Rich, is that -- I'm not going to provide any additional color on the volume of our capacity enterprise drives; that's Helium versus traditional in-air drives at this point. But obviously, as we've indicated over time, we'll be tran
componenttext: Sure. The first thing, Rich, is that -- I'm not going to provide any additional color on the volume of our capacity enterprise drives; that's Helium versus traditional in-air drives at this point. But obviously, as we've indicated over time, we'll be transitioning, particularly when we move to the 10 terabyte and things like that where -- and the 6 terabyte is intended to be our last in-air product. So as customers mix up, a larger and larger percentage of our business is going to be Helium-based. Relative to head-to-head competition, a couple of things to keep in mind. First thing is that we -- the customers that we're dealing with have pretty sophisticated total cost of ownership algorithms that allow them to look at more than just simply the price of the hard drive. And we recognize the fact that clearly, the price of the hard drive is one element, but when we factor in from a total cost-of-ownership perspective, and we're going head-to-head at a similar capacity point, we actually have pretty good win rates. And in some cases, obviously, if we transition to the 8 terabyte right now, we've got a distinct advantage from that capacity perspective, which assists us a lot in terms of winning business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the non-PC percentage of revenue, do you have a sense for what that might be exiting fiscal '16?
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the non-PC percentage of revenue, do you have a sense for what that might be exiting fiscal '16?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Rich. And I dare to speculate, to tell you the truth, because a lot of it will depend upon what happens with the PC business. And so I don't think I want to try to forecast a number at this point because I would happily have it rem
componenttext: That's a good question, Rich. And I dare to speculate, to tell you the truth, because a lot of it will depend upon what happens with the PC business. And so I don't think I want to try to forecast a number at this point because I would happily have it remain the same because that would mean that the PC business was actually looking a little bit better. And -- but if we don't see the PC market pick up, then obviously, our non-PC business is going to continue to increase as a percentage of the total. So that's a long non-answer to your question, Rich.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.
componenttext: And the next question is from Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've one for each, Steve and Olivier. Steve, just kind of following up on the last question. As you think out kind of past this year into and even through '16, what is a prudent way for us to think about how you guys do normalized exabyte growth? I know i
componenttext: I've one for each, Steve and Olivier. Steve, just kind of following up on the last question. As you think out kind of past this year into and even through '16, what is a prudent way for us to think about how you guys do normalized exabyte growth? I know it might be -- there's a lot of moving parts in the current environment, but I guess -- but every year, your latest thought process there would be helpful. And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if you look at exabyte today, we see it to be in the high single digits, with some nuances as you go by line on the business. Capacity enterprise was a big, obviously, focus. We would expect it to grow in the 50% range, which is what we have observed o
componenttext: So if you look at exabyte today, we see it to be in the high single digits, with some nuances as you go by line on the business. Capacity enterprise was a big, obviously, focus. We would expect it to grow in the 50% range, which is what we have observed on average for the last 4 quarters, a strong performance on that standpoint.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, Olivier, for you, just on the OpEx levels to sort of expect going forward. I believe, last quarter, before PCs softened, as agreed that they did, that you were looking sort of like a $590 million, plus or minus, level depending on where
componenttext: Got it. And then, Olivier, for you, just on the OpEx levels to sort of expect going forward. I believe, last quarter, before PCs softened, as agreed that they did, that you were looking sort of like a $590 million, plus or minus, level depending on where in the year we are. You pulled back on costs this quarter, although it sounds like maybe this was sort of a little on the prudent side. So would love to just get your take on how we should think about OpEx levels going forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we guided to a low number, $575 million, for the next quarter. It's probably a number we would stick to for the coming 4 quarters based upon the adjustment we had to do to our cost base, based upon the time level.
componenttext: So we guided to a low number, $575 million, for the next quarter. It's probably a number we would stick to for the coming 4 quarters based upon the adjustment we had to do to our cost base, based upon the time level.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question is from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask your view and what you're hearing from your cloud enterprise customers at this point, given the fact that a number of the big cloud providers, Twitter, Amazon, Facebook, are all cutting their CapEx plans? You guys sound on the call to
componenttext: I just wanted to ask your view and what you're hearing from your cloud enterprise customers at this point, given the fact that a number of the big cloud providers, Twitter, Amazon, Facebook, are all cutting their CapEx plans? You guys sound on the call to be very bullish on capacity growth, but just wanted to get your sense of what those companies' plans are, given they're cutting their CapEx.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me talk about it kind of in general terms. I mean, the first thing is, which may sound very much like an obvious statement, but we have a number of customers, and relative to any one particular period, we may see relative strength or relative
componenttext: Yes. So let me talk about it kind of in general terms. I mean, the first thing is, which may sound very much like an obvious statement, but we have a number of customers, and relative to any one particular period, we may see relative strength or relative weakness in particular accounts. And oh, by the way, obviously, part of our job from a management perspective is to manage whatever, either call it segment or customer volatility, from a demand perspective that we might happen to see. And so there's always going to be noise in that regard that we have to deal with. In general, as an overall statement, we feel very good about our positioning from a product perspective, from a technology perspective, from a customer perspective positioning standpoint. And the numbers that we're looking at are relatively consistent with our previous expectations, and we continue to expect that in the back half of the year. We're going to see pretty healthy pickup from an overall exabyte perspective, and we'll see how that translates from a unit perspective as we ship higher-capacity drives and -- but it should also drive a pretty healthy first half to back half revenue increase in terms of its contribution to our overall business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And just thinking about that exabyte growth accelerating in back half of the year, what is driving that? Is that further builds by some of your customers? Is that something that you've seen sort of seasonally? I'm just trying to unde
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And just thinking about that exabyte growth accelerating in back half of the year, what is driving that? Is that further builds by some of your customers? Is that something that you've seen sort of seasonally? I'm just trying to understand that a bit better.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little bit of context. So if you look over the last, roughly, 3 years, particularly in that space, about 40% of exabyte shipments are in the first half of the year, about 60% in the second half of the year. We're expecting, roughly speak
componenttext: Let me give you a little bit of context. So if you look over the last, roughly, 3 years, particularly in that space, about 40% of exabyte shipments are in the first half of the year, about 60% in the second half of the year. We're expecting, roughly speaking, that kind of a split to continue. And I would suggest that, that's just due to normal seasonality in terms of the nature of that business. It doesn't necessarily mean that there's an acceleration per se in that segment from a year-on-year perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Wamsi Mohan of Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from Wamsi Mohan of Bank of America.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Headcount is down 8% year-on-year. Can you talk a little bit about where those adjustments were made? How much was manufacturing-related versus maybe G&A that can persist into the back half? And I have a follow-up.
componenttext: Headcount is down 8% year-on-year. Can you talk a little bit about where those adjustments were made? How much was manufacturing-related versus maybe G&A that can persist into the back half? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The majority of that is our manufacturing workers in Asia. I mean, all of it.
componenttext: The majority of that is our manufacturing workers in Asia. I mean, all of it.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the MOFCOM side, I mean, you sound more optimistic today versus 90 days ago. First, am I correct in assuming that? Clearly, you've been meeting them throughout this process. So what's giving you any increased confidence of a speedy resolution? And
componenttext: And on the MOFCOM side, I mean, you sound more optimistic today versus 90 days ago. First, am I correct in assuming that? Clearly, you've been meeting them throughout this process. So what's giving you any increased confidence of a speedy resolution? And if we don't have a resolution in 6 months, would you be, like, negatively surprised?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the comment that I made on my prepared remarks, frankly speaking, kind of stands on its own in terms of the commentary and the reasons why we believe that -- or that we're hopeful for a decision in the near term. So I'd refer you back to my script f
componenttext: Well, the comment that I made on my prepared remarks, frankly speaking, kind of stands on its own in terms of the commentary and the reasons why we believe that -- or that we're hopeful for a decision in the near term. So I'd refer you back to my script for a detail in terms of that. Your question with regards to, would I be surprised if we didn't have a decision before the end of the year is, obviously, a tricky question. I don't know if I would say surprised, but obviously, I would be sorely disappointed if we didn't have a decision by then.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Steven Fox from Cross Research.
componenttext: The next question is from Steven Fox from Cross Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about your SSD business. It's had some fantastic growth over the past year. What are the key drivers? And how do you think your growth is comparing to the marketplace at this point?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about your SSD business. It's had some fantastic growth over the past year. What are the key drivers? And how do you think your growth is comparing to the marketplace at this point?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. A couple of comments on that. The first thing is that from an overall growth perspective, we do believe that we are gaining market share in that market and so we are exceeding industry growth averages. The lion's share -- this is consistent with the
componenttext: Sure. A couple of comments on that. The first thing is that from an overall growth perspective, we do believe that we are gaining market share in that market and so we are exceeding industry growth averages. The lion's share -- this is consistent with the past, the lion's share of our revenue continues to be related to our SAS-based SSD product. The one really encouraging thing from my perspective is that we're beginning to see a much more meaningful contribution from our PCIe NVM product. It's still relatively small compared to the $244 million, but we saw a nice pickup from calendar Q1 into calendar Q2. We're gaining increasing momentum, and we expect, as I indicated in my prepared remarks, that the revenue contribution from those products will continue to increase as we move through fiscal 2016.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just as a quick follow-up. Given where units are right now and some of the average capacities you've talked about, what are the chances that you would consider writing down some capacity at certain parts of the production process in the ne
componenttext: Great. And then just as a quick follow-up. Given where units are right now and some of the average capacities you've talked about, what are the chances that you would consider writing down some capacity at certain parts of the production process in the near term?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we are constantly evaluating that and constantly looking at that. And you can see that we have taken, as the market has declined -- I mean, let's be clear. The market has declined significantly over the last 2 to 3 years. And we have consistently
componenttext: Yes. So we are constantly evaluating that and constantly looking at that. And you can see that we have taken, as the market has declined -- I mean, let's be clear. The market has declined significantly over the last 2 to 3 years. And we have consistently evaluated our investments and our capital levels as we've seen the market come to new, different levels. We're going to continue to do that and continue to take actions to make sure we rightsize not only our manufacturing capabilities but also our investments from an OpEx perspective to make sure that we do our best to provide appropriate financial performance for our shareholders.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Christian Schwab, Craig Hallum Capital Group.
componenttext: And the next question is from Christian Schwab, Craig Hallum Capital Group.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I have a follow-up similar to that line of thinking. Our non-PC revenue has been -- your revenue, I should say, has been fairly consistent at about $2 billion to $2.2 billion a quarter for the last few years. When we look at your gross profit dolla
componenttext: Great. I have a follow-up similar to that line of thinking. Our non-PC revenue has been -- your revenue, I should say, has been fairly consistent at about $2 billion to $2.2 billion a quarter for the last few years. When we look at your gross profit dollars generated, I would assume that it's higher than the non-PC revenue, meaning that 70% plus of your gross profit dollars are generated in non-PC products. Is that fair?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Without confirming the exact number that you quoted, the non-PC areas of our business carry a higher gross profit profile than our traditional client business. And so if 65% of our revenue contribution is non-PC, then obviously, the profit contribution of
componenttext: Without confirming the exact number that you quoted, the non-PC areas of our business carry a higher gross profit profile than our traditional client business. And so if 65% of our revenue contribution is non-PC, then obviously, the profit contribution of that is greater.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, right. So I guess, where I'm going with that is, if we get MOFCOM approval and we start to write down more capacity in notebooks and PCs, we're going to print cash for as long as that non-PC revenue doesn't dissipate, right?
componenttext: Right, right. So I guess, where I'm going with that is, if we get MOFCOM approval and we start to write down more capacity in notebooks and PCs, we're going to print cash for as long as that non-PC revenue doesn't dissipate, right?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We believe, yes. We would believe that there will be significant synergies as a result of the lifting of the hold separate, which will not only benefit our company, our shareholders, but will also be able to benefit consumers in the form of more comp
componenttext: Yes. We believe, yes. We would believe that there will be significant synergies as a result of the lifting of the hold separate, which will not only benefit our company, our shareholders, but will also be able to benefit consumers in the form of more competitive pricing.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: To Olivier, can you help -- what was the charge for -- there's a $104 million charge this quarter that was reversed out from GAAP to non-GAAP. What was that for?
componenttext: To Olivier, can you help -- what was the charge for -- there's a $104 million charge this quarter that was reversed out from GAAP to non-GAAP. What was that for?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The majority of that, all of its causing was due to us resizing our business in order to cope with the current time level. So all of it is the adjustment of our supply chain, end-to-end, to face the new reality.
componenttext: The majority of that, all of its causing was due to us resizing our business in order to cope with the current time level. So all of it is the adjustment of our supply chain, end-to-end, to face the new reality.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Steve, one for you then. In terms of MOFCOM, is it a 0-sum game? And what I mean by that is, this has been puts and takes here, or it feels like its ebbs and flows over the last year and change. What happens if the Chinese government just doesn't sa
componenttext: Okay. Steve, one for you then. In terms of MOFCOM, is it a 0-sum game? And what I mean by that is, this has been puts and takes here, or it feels like its ebbs and flows over the last year and change. What happens if the Chinese government just doesn't say anything and this goes on for perpetuity? And what I mean by that is, does Western Digital have plans, contingency plans, whereby they can reduce cost even without the hold separate that would at least get at some of the cost savings that you've identified? Or do you need to get MOFCOM to really take your cost structure meaningfully lower from this juncture?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're going to continue to evaluate all of our options. But I think it's very dangerous, Keith, for me to speculate as to what we would do if we had no response from MOFCOM.
componenttext: Well, we're going to continue to evaluate all of our options. But I think it's very dangerous, Keith, for me to speculate as to what we would do if we had no response from MOFCOM.

componenttext: Sure. Well, what we said in the past and continues to be true is that the gross margin, generally speaking, for our SSD business is below the corporate average -- I mean, still very good margin but below corporate average. But it is clearly above the corporate average from a return on invested capital because we don't have the same form of, call it, vertical integration investments.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: And then, I guess, looking at your capital allocation, obviously, you continue to give back cash to shareholders each quarter. But do you foresee any incremental change to the capital allocation plans or near-term activity, even given the recent selloff in the stock price and some of the concerns that have pressured the stock relative to the market recently?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we look at capital allocation regularly, but we still believe that, even at this point in time, giving back 50% of our free cash flow back to shareholders in the form of dividends and buyback is a balanced approach, to reward our shareholders today but
componenttext: So we look at capital allocation regularly, but we still believe that, even at this point in time, giving back 50% of our free cash flow back to shareholders in the form of dividends and buyback is a balanced approach, to reward our shareholders today but also to keep rewarding our shareholders tomorrow to keep investing in the business. And we mentioned some attractive investments: Helium, enterprise SSD and Active Archive being a few examples.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I wanted to ask a more general question about mission-critical performance drives, if I could. So I know you don't break out performance versus near line. But if you look industry data, mission-critical has been fairly flat, and actually, it's been
componenttext: Steve, I wanted to ask a more general question about mission-critical performance drives, if I could. So I know you don't break out performance versus near line. But if you look industry data, mission-critical has been fairly flat, and actually, it's been growing in the last couple of quarters. And you're in sort of an interesting position where you can -- you sell both the SAS drives and SAS SSDs, which are largely viewed as substitutes. So can you help us understand why SAS drives remain so resilient despite such strong adoption from the SSDs?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Are you talking relative to us or in general?
componenttext: Are you talking relative to us or in general?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Either, I mean, but maybe you can start with WD.
componenttext: Either, I mean, but maybe you can start with WD.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the -- relative to us, if you remember, we had a hole in our portfolio where we did not have a competitive 2.5-inch, small form factor SAS hard drive. We now have a competitive product. And so in that space, which albeit a relatively small pa
componenttext: Well, one of the -- relative to us, if you remember, we had a hole in our portfolio where we did not have a competitive 2.5-inch, small form factor SAS hard drive. We now have a competitive product. And so in that space, which albeit a relatively small part of the performance enterprise market, we've been able to pick up some share in that space just by having a competitive product. So that's helped strengthen our relative performance from a performance enterprise standpoint. From a standpoint of SAS versus -- or not SAS, enterprise SSD versus a small form factor hard drive, right now, we're not seeing much cannibalization per se. We do expect that there will be cannibalization over time. It tends to be workload-driven in terms of the way the systems are configured. And so -- but like I said, so there hasn't been cannibalization so far, but we do expect that, that will happen in the future and that there will be some crossover between 2.5-inch, 15K drives and SSDs in the future.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And what is the critical factor in actually making that happen? Is it pricing and the cost of that?

Thank you again for joining us today. In closing, I want to thank all of our employees and suppliers for their commitment and outstanding execution and our customers for their continued business. Thank you so much.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's Financial Results for the First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now, I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. Thank
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's Financial Results for the First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now, I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This conference call will contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations that include known and unknown risks, uncertainties
componenttext:
Thank you. This conference call will contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations that include known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors, many of which Western Digital is unable to predict or control, that may cause Western Digital's actual results, performance or plans to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. The call does not constitute an offer to purchase or the solicitation of an offer to sell any securities or a solicitation of any note [indiscernible] or approval in connection with the pending merger with SanDisk. 
Western Digital will file a Form S-4 registration statement that includes proxy statements of SanDisk and Western Digital, and the perspectives of Western Digital regarding the merger. Western Digital and SanDisk will know definitive joint proxy statement prospectus to their respective stockholders. Investors and shareholders should read the joint proxy statement prospectives carefully when it becomes available because it contains important information about the merger. In addition, Western Digital, SanDisk and their respective directors, executive officers and certain other members of management and employees may do solicit in proxies from their respective stockholders in favor of the proposed transaction. You can find information about Western Digital directors and executive officers in Western Digital's most recent proxy statement and about SanDisk directors and executive officers in SanDisk's most recent proxy statement. You may also obtain a copy of these documents through the SEC's website or in the Western Digital and SanDisk websites. 
Further, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the historical non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. The non-GAAP forward-looking guidance we provide during this call includes amortization of intangibles, integration and acquisition-related costs. Because we currently cannot fully quantify future amounts for these excluded items, we are unable to provide guidance for or reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures. The impact of these excluded items may cause the estimated non-GAAP financial measures to differ materially from the comparable GAAP financial measures. [Operator Instructions] I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investors section of Western Digital's website following the conclusion of this call. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Western Digital Chief Executive Officer, Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will provide additional commentary on our Septe
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. 
With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will provide additional commentary on our September quarter performance and our outlook for the December quarter. 
This is an important time for Western Digital. We have announced several transformational developments over the last few weeks, including the planned investment at our company by Unisplendour, the decision by MOFCOM and the planned acquisition of SanDisk. Coupled with our continued strong execution in the business, I'm very excited about the company's future and our ability to create long-term value for our customers, shareholders and employees. 
We are proceeding with our integration into a single company as outlined in the MOFCOM decision, and we are submitting our applications for the regulatory reviews associated with the SanDisk acquisition and Unisplendour investment. We look forward to keeping you informed of our progress. 
Turning to the September quarter. Industry demand for hard drives was moderately higher than expected, driven primarily by strength in demand for 2.5-inch devices for game consoles and notebook PCs. We reported revenues of $3.4 billion, non-GAAP gross margins of 28.9% and diluted earnings per share of $1.56. Our storage shipments for the September quarter grew to 64 exabytes from 56 exabytes in the June quarter. These results reflect continued strong product and technology positioning, coupled with solid execution. Our Enterprise SSD revenue grew significantly to $233 million, reflecting the continued success of our SAS SSD products in an increasingly competitive environment. Additionally, we continue to ramp our new Ultrastar PCIe NVMe offering. Revenue from our video surveillance hard drives also continued its rapid growth as customers embraced our expanding lineup of these multipurpose, or purpose built solutions. 
We continue to see positive market reaction to the value proposition of our now Active Archive System. We anticipate this new systems business will generate meaningful revenue next fiscal year. We saw a good demand for our enterprise hard drives, especially our high-capacity helium drives, with more than 1 million units shipped in the quarter. We are volume shipping our 8-terabyte helium drive and we'll be ramping our 10-terabyte helium drive in the year ahead. Overall, demand in the high-capacity space was somewhat softer than anticipated. This was due to absorption of previously deployed storage assets purchased earlier in the calendar year by some of our large customers. 
Notwithstanding cyclicality within a given period, growth in the Capacity Enterprise sector will continue, with a 35% CAGR and exabytes anticipated on an annualized basis through 2020. This is underpinned by the ongoing growth in data being created and stored. 
Looking to the PC market. We are continuing to see some signs of stabilization in demand, driven by innovation, refresh cycles and normalization of PC inventories. We believe we have the opportunity to improve our financial performance due to the integration synergies associated with the recent MOFCOM decision, coupled with our continued favorable mix of business. Longer-term, the acquisition of SanDisk and the investment by Unisplendour will help transform our company into a storage technology leader with a broader set of products, deeper technology base and an expanded addressable market. 
Olivier will now provide a summary of our September quarter performance and our outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Our revenue for the September quarter was $3.4 billion. We shipped a total of 51.7 million hard disk drives at an average selling price of $60. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.9% and operating expenses totaled $567 million. Tax ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. 
Our revenue for the September quarter was $3.4 billion. We shipped a total of 51.7 million hard disk drives at an average selling price of $60. 
Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.9% and operating expenses totaled $567 million. 
Tax expense for the September quarter was $31 million or 8% of non-GAAP pretax income. 
On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $366 million or $1.56 per share. 
In the September quarter, we generated $545 million in cash from operations, and our free cash flow totaled $394 million. 
Our CapEx totaled $151 million or 4% of revenue. 
We repurchased 700,000 shares for $16 million. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share. 
We closed the quarter with total cash and cash equivalent of $5.1 billion, of which, approximately $60 million was held in the U.S. 
I will now provide -- so let me go back to the comment. Cash and cash equivalent of $5.1 billion, of which, approximately $600 million was held in the U.S. 
I will now provide our guidance for the December quarter. We expect our revenue to be in the range of $3.3 billion to $3.4 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect gross margin percentage to be slightly up from the September quarter. Operating expenses of approximately $585 million and accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share between $1.50 and $1.60. 
Operator, we're now ready to open the call for questions.

componenttext: I have a question and a follow-up. I guess, to start. Could you just talk about the benefit the MOFCOM approval have on your cash generation ability as you go forward. And how do you think the time of those benefits are flowing? Would it be in sync with your P&L? And that MOFCOM will help you get within the target of your cash conversion cycle of 4 to 8 days?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll take that, and Olivier can add a little bit of color. If you -- and this is Steve. If you look at the benefits that we expect from the revised MOFCOM ruling, is that, first thing is, is that we expect to realize $400 million of annual operating ex
componenttext: So I'll take that, and Olivier can add a little bit of color. If you -- and this is Steve. If you look at the benefits that we expect from the revised MOFCOM ruling, is that, first thing is, is that we expect to realize $400 million of annual operating expense savings and then we've also commented that we'll have material cost synergies. We have not quantified what material means in terms of cost synergies. Generally speaking, the $400 million of operating expense savings would be roughly equivalent to cash savings as our OpEx. The cost savings that we would realized, which have not been quantified, would be a mixture of cash and depreciation, that sort of thing. So it be kind of a mixture. So...

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me add 2 comments. First of all, most of the cash will be generated offshore. We have commented on that, 90% of the benefit will be generated outside U.S. And from a cash conversion cycle, we believe we're going to have some improvements that I w
componenttext: Yes, let me add 2 comments. First of all, most of the cash will be generated offshore. We have commented on that, 90% of the benefit will be generated outside U.S. And from a cash conversion cycle, we believe we're going to have some improvements that I wouldn't bank on many days.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can comment on that because there's a little bit of perspective. The 4 to 8 days was -- we announced that -- I think it was in September of 2002, 2003 -- 2021, sorry, lose track of time. Shortly after the acquisition. The composition of our busines
componenttext: Yes, I can comment on that because there's a little bit of perspective. The 4 to 8 days was -- we announced that -- I think it was in September of 2002, 2003 -- 2021, sorry, lose track of time. Shortly after the acquisition. The composition of our business has changed dramatically since then, particularly a lower percentage from the PC business, which tended to have a higher cash conversion to more of an enterprise mix, which has a slower cash conversion. So we're going to need to reset, at some point, what that cash conversion cycle from a business perspective should be for our company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's really helpful. And I guess just as a follow-up. Could you talk about the gross margin dynamic in the September quarter was, I think, up 60 basis points to your plan. Mix looks like maybe a part of it, but was there anything else, especiall
componenttext: Got it. That's really helpful. And I guess just as a follow-up. Could you talk about the gross margin dynamic in the September quarter was, I think, up 60 basis points to your plan. Mix looks like maybe a part of it, but was there anything else, especially from a pricing perspective, that sort of impeded your gross margins?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The short answer is yes, Aaron. What we haven't done, which -- let's keep in mind that prior to the revised ruling from MOFCOM, we were precluded from doing any integration planning. And so we have begun detailed integration planning and all of that. And
componenttext: The short answer is yes, Aaron. What we haven't done, which -- let's keep in mind that prior to the revised ruling from MOFCOM, we were precluded from doing any integration planning. And so we have begun detailed integration planning and all of that. And so we're not prepared at this point to indicate specifically the facing or the timing of those OpEx synergies other than to indicate they'll take place over the course of the next 12 to 24 months. But clearly, we're going to be looking at how we can bring those in as much as possible from a financial perspective, while minimizing impact to our business.
