I mean, if there's like facilities that, perhaps, now, you need to keep? Or it doesn't change or could have happened in any way?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the first thing to keep in mind, Rich, is that, given the complementary nature of the SanDisk and Western Digital transaction, we're -- it's a different kind of an integration in that regard. I think that's an important thing to contemplate.
componenttext: Well, I think the first thing to keep in mind, Rich, is that, given the complementary nature of the SanDisk and Western Digital transaction, we're -- it's a different kind of an integration in that regard. I think that's an important thing to contemplate. Simplistically, the answer to your question is, is no, it doesn't really alter anything. There are some additional things that we'll have to think about that add a bit more complexity. For example, systems integrations and things like that. So we'll have to look at, not only the preexisting WD and HGST systems, but also what platform the SanDisk's on and how do we kind of manage that process. But other than a few items like that, we intend to, more or less, perceive full steam in terms of the integration on the WD/HGST side.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, on your comments about absorption on the Capacity side, can you help us think through either how much do you think incremental demand half or half migrated into the first half versus second half of the calendar year because of those purchases? Or a
componenttext: Steve, on your comments about absorption on the Capacity side, can you help us think through either how much do you think incremental demand half or half migrated into the first half versus second half of the calendar year because of those purchases? Or alternatively, how much of the absorption do you think we are through and what innings are we in, in that? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me comment it on -- in this way. One of the things that we talked about in our last earnings call and also, I believe, our largest competitor also commented on it, is typically, the -- I'll call it the mix of exabytes that get shipped. You have about
componenttext: Let me comment it on -- in this way. One of the things that we talked about in our last earnings call and also, I believe, our largest competitor also commented on it, is typically, the -- I'll call it the mix of exabytes that get shipped. You have about 40% that typically get shipped in the first half of the year and 60% in the back half of the year. And if you look back -- in that calendar year, right? Not our fiscal year. And that percentages has held kind of pretty consistent over a number of years. This year, roughly speaking, we're looking at something that's more like 45% and 55%. So that'll help kind of to mention a bit either that. And we would expect that there would continue -- that, that absorption of capacity or exabytes shipped, that absorption will continue through the balance of this calendar year and begin to, if you want to call it, abate as we begin next calendar year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, on the near line side. Clearly, you took some share over there. As you have some customers migrate to the 8-terabyte drives, can you talk about what happened with the pricing on a like-for-like basis for the 4- and 6-terabyte? And did that influ
componenttext: And then, on the near line side. Clearly, you took some share over there. As you have some customers migrate to the 8-terabyte drives, can you talk about what happened with the pricing on a like-for-like basis for the 4- and 6-terabyte? And did that influence margins?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the short answer is that, that's not something that we called out as a particular driver of our margin performance. I mean, Olivier commented on the decline that we saw on our gross margin was driven entirely by mix, and that being a stronger mix of
componenttext: Well, the short answer is that, that's not something that we called out as a particular driver of our margin performance. I mean, Olivier commented on the decline that we saw on our gross margin was driven entirely by mix, and that being a stronger mix of lower margin products, namely drives that go into gaming consoles, as well as 2.5-inch drives that go into notebooks, which, consistently, have been below the [indiscernible] average. And so, whether or not -- that's what impacted our margin. And whether or not, if other things impact it, we're not calling anything else specifically.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about the regional trends, particularly Europe, but maybe also the U.S. And European year-over-year growth, deteriorating quite a bit in the quarter to minus 15% from minus 8% last quarter. So I wonder if you guys can give us a little
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about the regional trends, particularly Europe, but maybe also the U.S. And European year-over-year growth, deteriorating quite a bit in the quarter to minus 15% from minus 8% last quarter. So I wonder if you guys can give us a little color on what's going on there? Is that just consumer demand deteriorating or there are other things happening? And then, same for the North American region, down 6% after being up 16.5%. Is this just data center, cloud-oriented stuff? Or can you give us a little bit of color on those regional trends?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if there's anything particularly to call out, other than -- I mean, Europe has been weak from, call it a broader macroeconomic perspective. It's always difficult to draw conclusions from our geographic data because so much of our product is m
componenttext: I don't know if there's anything particularly to call out, other than -- I mean, Europe has been weak from, call it a broader macroeconomic perspective. It's always difficult to draw conclusions from our geographic data because so much of our product is manufactured in Asia or is passed on to customers that manufacture in Asia. So it doesn't really speak to the end market. But we have seen some, as you know, the macroeconomic situation in Europe has kind of impacted some of our more detail-oriented business, but I'm not sure I'd call anything specific beyond that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the European drive, I guess, are more Europe linked, is that correct? Whereas, elsewhere, you get more -- especially in Asia, [indiscernible] in other regions? Or is that the wrong way to see things?
componenttext: And the European drive, I guess, are more Europe linked, is that correct? Whereas, elsewhere, you get more -- especially in Asia, [indiscernible] in other regions? Or is that the wrong way to see things?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Probably, in Europe, you're right. Because there isn't a lot of manufacturing done in Europe, right? North America, you get a little bit of a mix because there are some manufacturing or systems that may go elsewhere and, certainly, in Asia. But Europe's a
componenttext: Probably, in Europe, you're right. Because there isn't a lot of manufacturing done in Europe, right? North America, you get a little bit of a mix because there are some manufacturing or systems that may go elsewhere and, certainly, in Asia. But Europe's a little bit more of a true number. But Europe's been, from a broader perspective, weak for a while.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're not the only ones.
componenttext: Yes, you're not the only ones.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Fox with Cross Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Just one question, just switching gears. Can you talk about your solid-state drive business a little bit? I think you mentioned a little bit of capacity issues or rather competitive issues are increasing during the quarter? And then, relative to average capacities and some of the trends you mentioned in the Enterprise, how do those relate to  [indiscernible] on [indiscernible], for the rest of the calendar year? And that's all I have.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we've enjoyed, through strong product execution, et cetera, a pretty strong [indiscernible] in that Enterprise SSD business. It's a very competitive market, as I alluded to in my comments. And again, quite simply, not for any one particular issue or an
componenttext: So we've enjoyed, through strong product execution, et cetera, a pretty strong [indiscernible] in that Enterprise SSD business. It's a very competitive market, as I alluded to in my comments. And again, quite simply, not for any one particular issue or another other than just increased competition we gave back a little bit of that share in this past quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, just in terms of average capacity, is there out of business trends through the rest of the year?
componenttext: And then, just in terms of average capacity, is there out of business trends through the rest of the year?

componenttext: Overall, or Enterprise SSD?

componenttextpreview: Just Enterprise SSDs.
componenttext: Just Enterprise SSDs.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nothing surprising. We continue to see, as product generations get announced, we continue to see an upward trend in average capacity shipped.
componenttext: Nothing surprising. We continue to see, as product generations get announced, we continue to see an upward trend in average capacity shipped.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Kisner from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Kisner from Jefferies.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So my question is just regarding seasonality. I believe in the June quarter call, you guys talked about seasonality abnormal because of just the depressed natures of, I think, client demand primarily. But I'm just wondering if you'd update your thoughts.
componenttext: So my question is just regarding seasonality. I believe in the June quarter call, you guys talked about seasonality abnormal because of just the depressed natures of, I think, client demand primarily. But I'm just wondering if you'd update your thoughts. If I could comment, ideally, sort of x MOFCOM, just seasonality of earnings in this fiscal year after having couple of more quarters or just another quarter on your belt?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Again, I don't know if I'd call out. I mean, you look at seasonality, if you look at the clients business, client plus gaming, which really drove most of the increase in TAM from calendar Q2 to calendar Q3, the seasonal uptick in that regard was pretty co
componenttext: Again, I don't know if I'd call out. I mean, you look at seasonality, if you look at the clients business, client plus gaming, which really drove most of the increase in TAM from calendar Q2 to calendar Q3, the seasonal uptick in that regard was pretty consistent with what we normally see. It's normally up, anywhere from 6%, 7%, 8%, something in that kind of range. And that's kind of what we saw in those segments of the market. The other thing that's happened is, is that while we used to see further increase in volumes in calendar Q4, that's kind of dissipated or gone away as our customers generally build earlier in the year, and then they'll put those on boats or longer transport kind of things to, say, transportation costs. So the seasonality from calendar Q3 to Q4, which has been going on for a while, is much more muted. Hence, our view of a flattish TAM going into calendar Q4.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, just sort of wondering here. I mean, you're obviously massively under shipping end market demand. I think units are down 30% in the Clients side. I'm just wondering if there's any hope at all or you see kind of a more recovery to closer end marke
componenttext: I guess, just sort of wondering here. I mean, you're obviously massively under shipping end market demand. I think units are down 30% in the Clients side. I'm just wondering if there's any hope at all or you see kind of a more recovery to closer end market demand?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we'll have to see. We've said this before. We -- although we've seen some signs of stabilization on the PC market, I would not necessarily characterize us as particularly bullish on that segment. And we have seen -- there was some inventory
componenttext: Well, I mean, we'll have to see. We've said this before. We -- although we've seen some signs of stabilization on the PC market, I would not necessarily characterize us as particularly bullish on that segment. And we have seen -- there was some inventory drawdown through the whole kind of supply chain. That's impacted our business a little bit in terms of where we maybe out of sync a bit in terms of what you're seeing from an overall PC unit perspective. And then additionally, we continue to see penetration of client SSDs in those systems, consistent with our expectations, though, by the way, but that further disconnects us from the overall unit numbers that you might see from a PC perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Keith Bachman with BMO.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Keith Bachman with BMO.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry if there's any background noise, but my questions, I want to focus back on the SanDisk still. I didn't have the opportunity to ask a question. More specifically, I'm still struggling to see how the SanDisk deal is creating shareholder value. Was it
componenttext: Sorry if there's any background noise, but my questions, I want to focus back on the SanDisk still. I didn't have the opportunity to ask a question. More specifically, I'm still struggling to see how the SanDisk deal is creating shareholder value. Was it 10 multiple companies is buying a 30 multiple company. And Steve, the question I wanted to post to you, if I could, I wanted to understand what your fundamental assumption is about the SanDisk [indiscernible] revenues, as you look out over the next 2 to 3 years? And how do you reach that conclusion, particularly with some thoughts surrounding when I think of the Retail business or replacement card? And then I have a follow-up also related to SanDisk.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the short answer to your question, Keith, is, do we expect the SanDisk business to grow over time? The answer to that is yes. And we see growth opportunities. One, in helping to expand our broader footprint in terms of the enterprise [indiscernible], w
componenttext: So the short answer to your question, Keith, is, do we expect the SanDisk business to grow over time? The answer to that is yes. And we see growth opportunities. One, in helping to expand our broader footprint in terms of the enterprise [indiscernible], where we think that, not only is that an area that's outpacing overall market growth, but also a higher value opportunity for us. We also think that there's growth opportunities in terms of client SSDs as well, certainly, as it relates to our base business. And additionally, we think that there is growth opportunity in terms of Embedded Solutions, that sort of thing. So you've got tablets, cell phones, et cetera. [indiscernible] opportunity. You asked related to the removables or the Retail segment. That's a great business, but it's not a growing business. So we fully understand and acknowledge that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe, if I could ask my follow-up then on the costs side. I think you -- during the conference call last week, that I think you've articulated broader synergies, call it, $500 million. And if I look at the cost structure of SanDisk alone, I wou
componenttext: Okay. And maybe, if I could ask my follow-up then on the costs side. I think you -- during the conference call last week, that I think you've articulated broader synergies, call it, $500 million. And if I look at the cost structure of SanDisk alone, I would've thought there would've been more on OpEx. But maybe I didn't understand the characterization because you're combining -- maybe I didn't understand the characterization of the $500 million opportunity. But I would've thought, combining the companies will be frankly more opportunities to reduce costs over the next several years, beyond $500 million. But if you could just flush that out a little bit? And then, [indiscernible].

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So a couple of comments on that. So when we talk about $500 million of synergies related to the SanDisk acquisition, we were specifically talking about -- that was 18 months -- within 18 months of the close of the transaction. We did not indicate th
componenttext: Sure. So a couple of comments on that. So when we talk about $500 million of synergies related to the SanDisk acquisition, we were specifically talking about -- that was 18 months -- within 18 months of the close of the transaction. We did not indicate that, that was the total synergies. In other words, we do think that those -- there are additional opportunities. We have not quantified those -- or publicly talked about those at this point. The additional thing is that, regarding that $500 million of synergies, the lion share of that is related to the advantage that we would get by being vertically-integrated as it relates principally to our Enterprise SSD business. And there are some OpEx synergies, but we have not quantified that breakout specifically.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Sherri Scribner from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Sherri Scribner from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think you said you thought that the TAM in the fourth calendar quarter would be roughly flat. I was hoping you can provide some detail on the different markets. You mentioned that the PC market appears to be stabilizing. Can you give us some sort
componenttext: Steve, I think you said you thought that the TAM in the fourth calendar quarter would be roughly flat. I was hoping you can provide some detail on the different markets. You mentioned that the PC market appears to be stabilizing. Can you give us some sort of directional commentary on the different end markets rates should be?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll give a little bit of color on that. So we would expect -- and these are pretty small changes, though, by the way. We would expect that we'll see some softening in terms of gaming demand, as well as in notebook demand, offset by a little bit bett
componenttext: Yes. I'll give a little bit of color on that. So we would expect -- and these are pretty small changes, though, by the way. We would expect that we'll see some softening in terms of gaming demand, as well as in notebook demand, offset by a little bit better enterprise demand. And that does -- again, these are subtle changes. That drives some of our margin improvement because we'll get a little bit -- if things play out the way we expect, we'll get a little bit of mix benefit as a consequence to that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I think you also mentioned in your commentary that the Active Archive System is expected to drive meaningful revenue next year. Can you help us understand what type of TAM you think that product has, what's the revenue opportunit
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I think you also mentioned in your commentary that the Active Archive System is expected to drive meaningful revenue next year. Can you help us understand what type of TAM you think that product has, what's the revenue opportunity for that product?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we define the Active Archive TAM, we see that as a multibillion dollar total addressable market for that solution. There's both sort of a currently defined version of that, as well as we think some new greenfield opportunities to create market
componenttext: Yes. So as we define the Active Archive TAM, we see that as a multibillion dollar total addressable market for that solution. There's both sort of a currently defined version of that, as well as we think some new greenfield opportunities to create market with that solution, given its value proposition. So I would look at it as a multibillion dollar market and growing at a fairly fast cliff.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Monika Garg with Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Monika Garg with Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I have a question on the SanDisk acquisition. Running the drive business is quite different than running a leading edge memory technology business. So maybe, could you talk about the plan to retain SanDisk [indiscernible] R&D team? And any executio
componenttext: Steve, I have a question on the SanDisk acquisition. Running the drive business is quite different than running a leading edge memory technology business. So maybe, could you talk about the plan to retain SanDisk [indiscernible] R&D team? And any execution risk, any indication you see?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Monika, we -- SanDisk has got some great people. We look forward to welcoming them to the team, and we certainly intend to retain the talent that exists there. And certainly, that talent that relates to those parts of the business that we don't ne
componenttext: Yes. So Monika, we -- SanDisk has got some great people. We look forward to welcoming them to the team, and we certainly intend to retain the talent that exists there. And certainly, that talent that relates to those parts of the business that we don't necessarily have the same experience. And that's certainly the semiconductor business. So we look forward to bringing them on board.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So do you see any execution risk in the integration?
componenttext: So do you see any execution risk in the integration?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's execution risk in everything, to be perfectly honest. And the thing that I always focus the most on, and investors will ask me often, what do you worry about? I want to make sure that we, every day, as a company, got eyes and cross feet. And
componenttext: Well, there's execution risk in everything, to be perfectly honest. And the thing that I always focus the most on, and investors will ask me often, what do you worry about? I want to make sure that we, every day, as a company, got eyes and cross feet. And that's what we do better than any company on the planet and that's what we intend to do as we look to, not only execute the HGST integration, but also, as it relates to future integration of SanDisk. And so absolutely are the risks and we're going to manage that carefully and I want to keep our team intensely focused on that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, given that units [indiscernible] 15% take in WD, do you think it could add any regulatory risk for getting approval for the SanDisk acquisition?
componenttext: And then, given that units [indiscernible] 15% take in WD, do you think it could add any regulatory risk for getting approval for the SanDisk acquisition?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we are proceeding with our application. In fact, our application regarding process, that is in and has been accepted. We were very careful at to how we structured that transaction and Unisys representation on our board. And we feel pretty good about
componenttext: Well, we are proceeding with our application. In fact, our application regarding process, that is in and has been accepted. We were very careful at to how we structured that transaction and Unisys representation on our board. And we feel pretty good about that and we're proceeding with regulatory review at this point and we'll keep you posted as things progress.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: How big do you think your lead is in the 8-terabyte capacity drive space, And then how would you expect that to change, if at all, as the industry moves to 10 terabytes?
componenttext: How big do you think your lead is in the 8-terabyte capacity drive space, And then how would you expect that to change, if at all, as the industry moves to 10 terabytes?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- it's difficult to de-mention how far ahead we are because we don't have perfect visibility into where our competition is. But let me kind of make this comment. Our 10-terabyte drive, which we haven't announced exactly when that'll be available.
componenttext: Well, I -- it's difficult to de-mention how far ahead we are because we don't have perfect visibility into where our competition is. But let me kind of make this comment. Our 10-terabyte drive, which we haven't announced exactly when that'll be available. It's PRM-based solution. And that's our -- depending upon [indiscernible] third or fourth generation helium drive. There has been a lot of learnings along the way, and that we have developed. And so, when you've get a 3 or 4 generation lead on your competition, that's fairly material lead. Now that being said, we fully -- we respect our competition and we're not going to rest on our  and we're going to keep marching forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And a question on inventory. You commented on PC channel inventory coming down. I mean, obviously, we can see your balance sheet inventory that came down. But where do you think the industry is in terms of those channel inventory, which has historic
componenttext: Okay. And a question on inventory. You commented on PC channel inventory coming down. I mean, obviously, we can see your balance sheet inventory that came down. But where do you think the industry is in terms of those channel inventory, which has historically been quite low in recent quarters? And also, OEM inventory at their manufacturing hubs.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the inventory is still within our range, in the lower end of the range, nevertheless.
componenttext: So the inventory is still within our range, in the lower end of the range, nevertheless.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have any visibility into the OEM inventory at their hubs?
componenttext: Do you have any visibility into the OEM inventory at their hubs?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We think that those are within comfortable ranges. But we don't have any specific visibility as to any issues.
componenttext: We think that those are within comfortable ranges. But we don't have any specific visibility as to any issues.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Going back to your commentary regarding some share shift in the SSD, how do you see this evolving into next year? And I have a follow-up.
componenttext: Going back to your commentary regarding some share shift in the SSD, how do you see this evolving into next year? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a difficult question to answer. How do we see share evolving into next year. I mean, obviously, what we're going to continue is execute on our product plan and continue to delight our customers and share our turnout, where it'll turn out. And so we
componenttext: That's a difficult question to answer. How do we see share evolving into next year. I mean, obviously, what we're going to continue is execute on our product plan and continue to delight our customers and share our turnout, where it'll turn out. And so we're going to try to earn our business every day.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me rephrase it, as a follow-up. Do you see new technologies, like CD NAND, to become a catalyst looking to next year? Or your competitor is just giving the margin in certain at a lower price? And as a follow-up to that, do you see a change in yo
componenttext: Sure. Let me rephrase it, as a follow-up. Do you see new technologies, like CD NAND, to become a catalyst looking to next year? Or your competitor is just giving the margin in certain at a lower price? And as a follow-up to that, do you see a change in your driver strategy, especially SanDisk, selling more of a hybrid product, as a way to scale rather niche segment of the market?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me comment on that. I think we see 3D as the next-generation underlying media. We have plans to address products that are built on that in the future. So that will be part of our competitive profile and there are both, of course, economic benefits
componenttext: So let me comment on that. I think we see 3D as the next-generation underlying media. We have plans to address products that are built on that in the future. So that will be part of our competitive profile and there are both, of course, economic benefits of that, but there are also product performance benefits in that architecture. So I think we'll see the market go through a transition and we have our own internal plans in which to undertake that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So is your competition just basically selling a depressed price, is that what the competition has done?
componenttext: So is your competition just basically selling a depressed price, is that what the competition has done?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think -- we see continued competition around that market as it progresses, nothing that's sort of outside our general expectation.
componenttext: I don't think -- we see continued competition around that market as it progresses, nothing that's sort of outside our general expectation.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And quickly, on hybrid drive, is your strategy changing here, especially with SanDisk included part of your portfolio?
componenttext: Got you. And quickly, on hybrid drive, is your strategy changing here, especially with SanDisk included part of your portfolio?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this point, we don't have any specific changes we would articulate.
componenttext: At this point, we don't have any specific changes we would articulate.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I'm just wondering if you -- just back to SanDisk, just if you can explain -- the big question we get is whether this is defensive strategy or an offensive strategy. In other words, is buying SanDisk your absolute best strategy for you to take on,
componenttext: Steve, I'm just wondering if you -- just back to SanDisk, just if you can explain -- the big question we get is whether this is defensive strategy or an offensive strategy. In other words, is buying SanDisk your absolute best strategy for you to take on, given your decline in industry? Or is it more an offensive strategy and the fact that you believe exabyte growth is going to continue to grow and HDDs and solid-state drives will coexist for an extended period of time? And therefore, you're best suited to serve a customer base so that's also consolidating.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So one comment, and not to take offense to the way that the question is phrased. But I don't -- I don't know if I necessarily like the characterizing it is either offensive or defensive. This is a strategy that we thought about quite a bit. We think
componenttext: Yes. So one comment, and not to take offense to the way that the question is phrased. But I don't -- I don't know if I necessarily like the characterizing it is either offensive or defensive. This is a strategy that we thought about quite a bit. We think it is going to be good for our shareholders, good for our customers. And it's going to allow our company and our business to grow. So if you want to characterize that as offensive, then, feel free to do so.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. And then, as you look at just the disk drive business, Steve, is my follow-up question, as we look out as -- at a TAM that kind of follows a flat to low single-digit, given the mix in complexity of enterprise drives, as well as bigger c
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. And then, as you look at just the disk drive business, Steve, is my follow-up question, as we look out as -- at a TAM that kind of follows a flat to low single-digit, given the mix in complexity of enterprise drives, as well as bigger capacity branded drives being shipped, you would make great progress on non-PC revenue as a mix of our business and actually, over the last 4 years has modestly grown. Three or 4 years from now, do you believe that is the lion's share of the percentage of revenue?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Now, what percentage, we'll have to see. And we certainly haven't called anything out publicly but clearly, the mix of our business in the traditional hard drive space is improving. And as it improves and as the PC related part becomes a, frankly, sm
componenttext: Yes. Now, what percentage, we'll have to see. And we certainly haven't called anything out publicly but clearly, the mix of our business in the traditional hard drive space is improving. And as it improves and as the PC related part becomes a, frankly, small and smaller part of our business, sooner or later, there's going to be an inflection point. We'll begin to show improvement in revenues in terms of the overall hard drive market, as well as a better margin posture as it relates to that underlying business. And so, yes. So the hard drive business remains a great business. It's just a mix is shifting, right? In a favorable way.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, nothing to talk about at this point. I mean, obviously, we're going to continue to evaluate and think through our go-to market strategy in China. China, as a market -- I mean, first off, it's a huge market, it's a growing market, it's an evol
componenttext: Yes. I mean, nothing to talk about at this point. I mean, obviously, we're going to continue to evaluate and think through our go-to market strategy in China. China, as a market -- I mean, first off, it's a huge market, it's a growing market, it's an evolving market. As you see some of the hyperscale guys there, grow, or on telecom companies, et cetera, et cetera, we're going to have to look at ways that we evolve our go-to market capabilities in that market. But nothing specifically to talk about now.

componenttext: Well, the first thing is, to clarify, we haven't called any of that out in terms of what you're talking about. So I'm not going to comment specifically on that. What we have said is that the lion's share of that $500 million will be the benefit that we will get by being vertically-integrated on -- in our SSD business or existing SSD business. And there will be some OpEx synergies, but we have not quantified that. And, by the way, the other thing is, is that we've indicated, the $500 million will be 18 months after the close of the transaction, which basically means that there will be further synergies beyond that 18-month period that we've yet to quantify publicly.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's Financial Results for the First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks, uncertainties and
componenttext:
Thank you. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors, many of which Western Digital is unable to predict or control, that may cause Western Digital's actual results, performance or plans to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. The call does not constitute an offer to purchase or the solicitation of an offer to sell any securities or a solicitation of any note -- any vote or approval in connection with the pending merger with SanDisk.
Western Digital will file a Form S-4 registration statement that includes proxy statements of SanDisk and Western Digital, and the perspectives of Western Digital regarding the merger. Western Digital and SanDisk will mail the definitive joint proxy statement prospectus to their respective stockholders. Investors and shareholders should read the joint proxy statement prospectives carefully when it becomes available because it contains important information about the merger.
In addition, Western Digital, SanDisk and their respective directors, executive officers and certain other members of management and employees may be soliciting proxies from their respective stockholders in favor of the proposed transaction. You can find information about Western Digital directors and executive officers in Western Digital's most recent proxy statement and about SanDisk directors and executive officers in SanDisk's most recent proxy statement. You may also obtain a copy of these documents through the SEC's website or in the Western Digital and SanDisk websites.
Further, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the historical non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. The non-GAAP forward-looking guidance we provide during this call includes amortization of intangibles, integration and acquisition-related costs.
Because we currently cannot fully quantify future amounts for these excluded items, we are unable to provide guidance for or reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures. The impact of these excluded items may cause the estimated non-GAAP financial measures to differ materially from the comparable GAAP financial measures. [Operator Instructions] I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investors section of Western Digital's website following the conclusion of this call.
And with that, I turn the call over to Western Digital Chief Executive Officer, Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us.With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will provide additional commentary on our Septem
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us.
With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will provide additional commentary on our September quarter performance and our outlook for the December quarter.
This is an important time for Western Digital. We have announced several transformational developments over the last few weeks, including the planned investment in our company by Unisplendour, the decision by MOFCOM and the planned acquisition of SanDisk. Coupled with our continued strong execution in the business, I'm very excited about the company's future and our ability to create long-term value for our customers, shareholders and employees.
We are proceeding with our integration into a single company as outlined in the MOFCOM decision, and we are submitting our applications for the regulatory reviews associated with the SanDisk acquisition and Unisplendour investment. We look forward to keeping you informed of our progress.
Turning to the September quarter. Industry demand for hard drives was moderately higher than expected, driven primarily by strength in demand for 2.5-inch devices for game consoles and notebook PCs. We reported revenues of $3.4 billion, non-GAAP gross margins of 28.9% and diluted earnings per share of $1.56. Our storage shipments for the September quarter grew to 64 exabytes from 56 exabytes in the June quarter. These results reflect continued strong product and technology positioning, coupled with solid execution.
Our Enterprise SSD revenue grew significantly to $233 million, reflecting the continued success of our SAS SSD products in an increasingly competitive environment. Additionally, we continue to ramp our new Ultrastar PCIe NVMe offering. Revenue from our video surveillance hard drives also continued its rapid growth as customers embraced our expanding lineup of these multipurpose or purpose-built solutions.
We continue to see positive market reaction to the value proposition of our now Active Archive system. We anticipate this new systems business will generate meaningful revenue next fiscal year. We saw a good demand for our enterprise hard drives, especially our high-capacity helium drives, with more than 1 million units shipped in the quarter. We are volume shipping our 8-terabyte helium drive and we'll be ramping our 10-terabyte helium drive in the year ahead. Overall, demand in the high-capacity space was somewhat softer than anticipated. This was due to absorption of previously deployed storage assets purchased earlier in the calendar year by some of our large customers.
Notwithstanding cyclicality within a given period, growth in the Capacity Enterprise sector will continue, with a 35% CAGR and exabytes anticipated on an annualized basis through 2020. This is underpinned by the ongoing growth in data being created and stored.
Looking to the PC market. We are continuing to see some signs of stabilization in demand, driven by innovation, refresh cycles and normalization of PC inventories. We believe we have the opportunity to improve our financial performance due to the integration synergies associated with the recent MOFCOM decision, coupled with our continued favorable mix of business. Longer-term, the acquisition of SanDisk and the investment by Unisplendour will help transform our company into a storage technology leader with a broader set of products, deeper technology base and an expanded addressable market.
Olivier will now provide a summary of our September quarter performance and our outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve.Our revenue for the September quarter was $3.4 billion. We shipped a total of 51.7 million hard disk drives at an average selling price of $60.Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.9% and operating expenses totaled $567 million.Tax expen
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve.
Our revenue for the September quarter was $3.4 billion. We shipped a total of 51.7 million hard disk drives at an average selling price of $60.
Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.9% and operating expenses totaled $567 million.
Tax expense for the September quarter was $31 million or 8% of non-GAAP pretax income.
On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $366 million or $1.56 per share.
In the September quarter, we generated $545 million in cash from operations, and our free cash flow totaled $394 million.
Our CapEx totaled $151 million or 4% of revenue.
We repurchased 700,000 shares for $60 million. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share.
We closed the quarter with total cash and cash equivalent of $5.1 billion, of which approximately $60 million was held in the U.S. I will now provide -- so let me go back to the comment. Cash and cash equivalent of $5.1 billion, of which approximately $600 million was held in the U.S.
I will now provide our guidance for the December quarter. We expect our revenue to be in the range of $3.3 billion to $3.4 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect gross margin percentage to be slightly up from the September quarter. Operating expenses of approximately $585 million and accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share between $1.50 and $1.60.
Operator, we're now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question and a follow-up. I guess, to start. Could you just talk about the benefit the MOFCOM approval have on your cash generation ability as you go forward? And how do you think the timing of those benefits of flow? And would it be in sync with
componenttext: I have a question and a follow-up. I guess, to start. Could you just talk about the benefit the MOFCOM approval have on your cash generation ability as you go forward? And how do you think the timing of those benefits of flow? And would it be in sync with your P&L? And does MOFCOM will help you get within the target of your cash conversion cycle of 4 to 8 days?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll take that, and then Olivier can add a little bit of color. If you -- and this is Steve. If you look at the benefits that we expect from the revised MOFCOM ruling, is that -- first thing is, is that we expect to realize $400 million of annual opera
componenttext: So I'll take that, and then Olivier can add a little bit of color. If you -- and this is Steve. If you look at the benefits that we expect from the revised MOFCOM ruling, is that -- first thing is, is that we expect to realize $400 million of annual operating expense savings and then we've also commented that we'll have material cost synergies. We have not quantified what material means in terms of cost synergies. Generally speaking, the $400 million of operating expense savings would be roughly equivalent to cash savings as our OpEx. The cost savings that we would realize, which have not been quantified, would be a mixture of cash and depreciation, that sort of thing. So it'd be kind of a mixture. So...

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me add 2 comments. First of all, most of the cash will be generated offshore. We have commented on that, 90% of the benefit will be generated outside U.S. And from a cash conversion cycle, we believe we're going to have some improvements that I w
componenttext: Yes, let me add 2 comments. First of all, most of the cash will be generated offshore. We have commented on that, 90% of the benefit will be generated outside U.S. And from a cash conversion cycle, we believe we're going to have some improvements that I wouldn't bank on many days.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can comment on that because there's a little bit of perspective. The 4 to 8 days was -- we announced that, geez, I think it was in September of 2002 or '03 -- '12, sorry, lose track of time. But shortly after the acquisition, the composition of our
componenttext: Yes, I can comment on that because there's a little bit of perspective. The 4 to 8 days was -- we announced that, geez, I think it was in September of 2002 or '03 -- '12, sorry, lose track of time. But shortly after the acquisition, the composition of our business has changed dramatically since then, particularly a lower percentage from a PC business, which tended to have a higher cash conversion to more of an enterprise mix, which has a slower cash conversion. So we're going to need to reset at some point, what that cash conversion cycle from a business perspective should be for our company.

componenttext: Got it. That's really helpful. And I guess just as a follow-up. Could you talk about the gross margin dynamic in the September quarter was, I think, up 60 basis points to your plan. Mix looks like may be a part of it, but was there anything else, especially from a pricing perspective, that could have impeded your gross margins?
