headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: $575 million, give or take, before MOFCOM synergies. Now in terms of MOFCOM synergies, as indicated, we would expect them to materialize between the next 12 and 24 months and we'll provide you an update on where will that be.
componenttext: $575 million, give or take, before MOFCOM synergies. Now in terms of MOFCOM synergies, as indicated, we would expect them to materialize between the next 12 and 24 months and we'll provide you an update on where will that be.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The run rate OpEx pre-MOFCOM synergies is $570 million.
componenttext: The run rate OpEx pre-MOFCOM synergies is $570 million.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: But just to be fair, I mean, you are looking to drive that OpEx down, that's not going to happen. That should -- should some of that start to happen before we even get to the 12 months, is what I'm asking?
componenttext: But just to be fair, I mean, you are looking to drive that OpEx down, that's not going to happen. That should -- should some of that start to happen before we even get to the 12 months, is what I'm asking?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The short answer is yes, Aaron. What we haven't done, which -- let's keep in mind that prior to the revised ruling from MOFCOM, we were precluded from doing any integration planning. And so we have begun detailed integration planning and all of that. And
componenttext: The short answer is yes, Aaron. What we haven't done, which -- let's keep in mind that prior to the revised ruling from MOFCOM, we were precluded from doing any integration planning. And so we have begun detailed integration planning and all of that. And so we're not prepared at this point to indicate specifically the phasing or the timing of those OpEx synergies other than to indicate they'll take place over the course of the next 12 to 24 months. But clearly, we're going to be looking at how we can bring those in as much as possible from a financial perspective, while minimizing impact to our business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, as a follow-up, I'm just curious, on the capacity shipment trends, you talked a little bit about it. It looks like you were down about 2% year-over-year in terms of total capacity ship. Can you help us bridge what that capacity ship looks
componenttext: Okay. And then, as a follow-up, I'm just curious, on the capacity shipment trends, you talked a little bit about it. It looks like you were down about 2% year-over-year in terms of total capacity ship. Can you help us bridge what that capacity ship looks like between the PC business relative to your Enterprise business? And what that's trended like?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I follow what you're trying -- I'm not sure I follow that question, Aaron.
componenttext: I'm not sure I follow what you're trying -- I'm not sure I follow that question, Aaron.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, relative to the 35% compound annual growth rate that you referenced on the Enterprise side going forward, just curious of how that growth look like here -- over the past few quarters within the total capacity ship number that you report?
componenttext: So I guess, relative to the 35% compound annual growth rate that you referenced on the Enterprise side going forward, just curious of how that growth look like here -- over the past few quarters within the total capacity ship number that you report?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I got it. But Mike's going to take that question.
componenttext: I got it. But Mike's going to take that question.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, Aaron. So I think the way to think about it, we still think the year is tracking to -- the calendar year tracking to the 35% number, maybe slightly higher. We saw a little bit of front-loading in the calendar year of that. And so that's being absorbed
componenttext: Hi, Aaron. So I think the way to think about it, we still think the year is tracking to -- the calendar year tracking to the 35% number, maybe slightly higher. We saw a little bit of front-loading in the calendar year of that. And so that's being absorbed in the comments that Steve made earlier as we get into the second half. So I think that trend, we're confident in that and that's specifically around the Capacity Enterprise segment.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rich Kugele from Needham.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Kugele from Needham.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, on the Capacity Enterprise side, I mean, obviously that stands more than just cloud service providers. Can you just talk about the Capacity Enterprise cloud service provider part of your exabyte shipments? And how you would e
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, on the Capacity Enterprise side, I mean, obviously that stands more than just cloud service providers. Can you just talk about the Capacity Enterprise cloud service provider part of your exabyte shipments? And how you would expect that to trend over the next, I don't know, to whatever -- 6 to 12 months as you move, especially to 10-terabyte?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Rich, I'll take that question. I mean, as you know, we try to stay away from talking about specific either customers or types of customers. Obviously, cloud service providers are a meaningful part of exabytes shipped on our port. But the absorptio
componenttext: Yes. So Rich, I'll take that question. I mean, as you know, we try to stay away from talking about specific either customers or types of customers. Obviously, cloud service providers are a meaningful part of exabytes shipped on our port. But the absorption that I alluded to in my prepared remarks was a mixture of both traditional Enterprise customers, if you want to call it that, as well as cloud service providers.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, interesting. And then, post SanDisk now, is there anything that you were contemplating on the Hitachi integration that now needs to be altered because of the SanDisk integration? If there's like facilities that, perhaps, now you need to keep? Or doe
componenttext: Okay, interesting. And then, post SanDisk now, is there anything that you were contemplating on the Hitachi integration that now needs to be altered because of the SanDisk integration? If there's like facilities that, perhaps, now you need to keep? Or does it change or could have happened in any way?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the first thing to keep in mind, Rich, is that, given the complementary nature of the SanDisk and Western Digital transaction, we're -- it's a different kind of an integration in that regard. I think that's an important thing to contemplate.
componenttext: Well, I think the first thing to keep in mind, Rich, is that, given the complementary nature of the SanDisk and Western Digital transaction, we're -- it's a different kind of an integration in that regard. I think that's an important thing to contemplate. Simplistically, the answer to your question is, is no, it doesn't really alter anything. There are some additional things that we'll have to think about that add a bit more complexity, for example, systems integrations and things like that. So we'll have to look at, not only the preexisting WD and HGST systems, but also what platform the SanDisk on and how do we kind of manage that process. But other than a few items like that, we intend to, more or less, perceive full steam in terms of the integration of -- on the WD/HGST side.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, on your comments about absorption on the Capacity side, can you help us think through either how much do you think incremental demand half or half migrated into the first half versus second half of the calendar year because of those purchases? Or a
componenttext: Steve, on your comments about absorption on the Capacity side, can you help us think through either how much do you think incremental demand half or half migrated into the first half versus second half of the calendar year because of those purchases? Or alternatively, how much of the absorption do you think we are through and what innings are we in, in that? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me comment it on -- in this way. One of the things that we talked about in our last earnings call and also, I believe, our largest competitor also commented on it, is typically, the -- I'll call it the mix of exabytes that get shipped. You have about
componenttext: Let me comment it on -- in this way. One of the things that we talked about in our last earnings call and also, I believe, our largest competitor also commented on it, is typically, the -- I'll call it the mix of exabytes that get shipped. You have about 40% that typically get shipped in the first half of the year and 60% in the back half of the year. And if you look -- and that's calendar year, right? Not our fiscal year. And that percentages has held kind of pretty consistent over a number of years. This year, roughly speaking, we're looking at something that's more like 45% and 55%. So that'll help kind of dimension a bit that. And we would expect that there would continue -- that, that absorption of capacity or exabytes shipped, that absorption will continue through the balance of this calendar year and begin to, if you want to call it, abate as we begin next calendar year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, on the near line side. Clearly, you took some share over there. As you have some customers migrate to the 8-terabyte drives, can you talk about what happened with the pricing on a like-for-like basis for the 4- and 6-terabyte? And did that
componenttext: Okay. And then, on the near line side. Clearly, you took some share over there. As you have some customers migrate to the 8-terabyte drives, can you talk about what happened with the pricing on a like-for-like basis for the 4- and 6-terabyte? And did that influence margins?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the short answer is that, that's not something that we called out as a particular driver of our margin performance. I mean, Olivier commented on the decline that we saw on our gross margin was driven entirely by mix, and that being a stronger mix of
componenttext: Well, the short answer is that, that's not something that we called out as a particular driver of our margin performance. I mean, Olivier commented on the decline that we saw on our gross margin was driven entirely by mix, and that being a stronger mix of lower margin products, namely drives that go into gaming consoles as well as 2.5-inch drives that go into notebooks, which consistently have been below the corporate average. And so, whether or not -- that's what impacted our margin. And whether or not, if other things impact it, we're not calling anything else specifically.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about the regional trends, particularly Europe, but maybe also the U.S. And European year-over-year growth deteriorating quite a bit in the quarter to minus 15% from minus 8% last quarter. So I wonder if you guys can give us a little
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about the regional trends, particularly Europe, but maybe also the U.S. And European year-over-year growth deteriorating quite a bit in the quarter to minus 15% from minus 8% last quarter. So I wonder if you guys can give us a little color on what's going on there? Is that just consumer demand deteriorating or there are other things happening? And then, same for the North American region, down 6% after being up 16.5%. Is this just data center, cloud-oriented stuff? Or can you give us a little bit of color on those regional trends?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if there's anything particularly to call out, other than -- I mean, Europe has been weak from, call it a broader macroeconomic perspective. It's always difficult to draw conclusions from our geographic data because so much of our product is m
componenttext: I don't know if there's anything particularly to call out, other than -- I mean, Europe has been weak from, call it a broader macroeconomic perspective. It's always difficult to draw conclusions from our geographic data because so much of our product is manufactured in Asia or is passed on to customers that manufacture in Asia. So it doesn't really speak to the end market. But we have seen some, as you know, the macroeconomic situation in Europe has kind of impacted some of our more detail-oriented business, but I'm not sure I would call anything specific beyond that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the European drive, I guess, are more Europe-linked, is that correct? Whereas, elsewhere, you get more -- especially in Asia, it leaks out in other regions? Or is that the wrong way to see things?
componenttext: And the European drive, I guess, are more Europe-linked, is that correct? Whereas, elsewhere, you get more -- especially in Asia, it leaks out in other regions? Or is that the wrong way to see things?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Probably, in Europe, you're right. Because there isn't a lot of manufacturing done in Europe, right? North America, you get a little bit of a mix because there are some manufacturing or systems that may go elsewhere and, certainly, in Asia. But Europe is
componenttext: Probably, in Europe, you're right. Because there isn't a lot of manufacturing done in Europe, right? North America, you get a little bit of a mix because there are some manufacturing or systems that may go elsewhere and, certainly, in Asia. But Europe is a little bit more of a true number. But Europe has been, from a broader perspective, weak for a while.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steven Fox with Cross Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Fox with Cross Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one question, just switching gears. Can you talk about your solid-state drive business a little bit? I think you mentioned a little bit of capacity issues or rather competitive issues are increasing during the quarter? And then, relative to average c
componenttext: Just one question, just switching gears. Can you talk about your solid-state drive business a little bit? I think you mentioned a little bit of capacity issues or rather competitive issues are increasing during the quarter? And then, relative to average capacities and some of the trends you mentioned in the Enterprise, how do those relate to what's going on in SSD typically and through the rest of the calendar year? And that's all I have.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we've enjoyed, through strong product execution, et cetera, a pretty strong share position in that Enterprise SSD business. It's a very competitive market, as I alluded to in my comments. And again, quite simply, not for any one particular issue or ano
componenttext: So we've enjoyed, through strong product execution, et cetera, a pretty strong share position in that Enterprise SSD business. It's a very competitive market, as I alluded to in my comments. And again, quite simply, not for any one particular issue or another other than just increased competition we gave back a little bit of that share in this past quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, just in terms of average capacity, is -- or how the business trends through the rest of the year?
componenttext: And then, just in terms of average capacity, is -- or how the business trends through the rest of the year?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Overall or Enterprise SSD?
componenttext: Overall or Enterprise SSD?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just Enterprise SSD.
componenttext: Just Enterprise SSD.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nothing surprising. We continue to see as product generations get announced, we continue to see an upward trend in average capacity ship.
componenttext: Nothing surprising. We continue to see as product generations get announced, we continue to see an upward trend in average capacity ship.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Kisner with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Kisner with Jefferies.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So my question is just regarding seasonality. I believe, in the June quarter call, you guys talked about seasonality being abnormal because of just the depressed natures of, I think, client demand primarily. But I'm just wondering if you could update your
componenttext: So my question is just regarding seasonality. I believe, in the June quarter call, you guys talked about seasonality being abnormal because of just the depressed natures of, I think, client demand primarily. But I'm just wondering if you could update your thoughts? And I'd like you to comment, ideally, sort of ex MOFCOM, just seasonality of earnings in this fiscal year after having a couple of more quarters under your -- just another quarter under your belt?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if I call out. I mean, if you look at seasonality, if you look at the clients business, client plus gaming, which really drove most of the increase in TAM from calendar Q2 to calendar Q3. The seasonal uptick in that regard was pretty consiste
componenttext: I don't know if I call out. I mean, if you look at seasonality, if you look at the clients business, client plus gaming, which really drove most of the increase in TAM from calendar Q2 to calendar Q3. The seasonal uptick in that regard was pretty consistent with what we normally see. It's normally up, anywhere from 6%, 7%, 8%, something in that kind of range. And that's kind of what we saw in those segments of the market. The other thing that's happened is, is that while we used to see further increase in volumes in calendar Q4, that's kind of dissipated or gone away as our customers generally build earlier in the year, and then they'll put those on boats or longer transport kind of things to save transportation costs. So the seasonality from calendar Q3 to Q4, which has been going on for a while, is much more muted. Hence, our view of a flattish TAM going into calendar Q4.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'm still wondering here. I mean, you're obviously massively under shipping end market demand. I think units are down 30% on the clients side. I'm just wondering if there's any hope at all, you to see kind of a more recovery to closer to end mark
componenttext: I guess, I'm still wondering here. I mean, you're obviously massively under shipping end market demand. I think units are down 30% on the clients side. I'm just wondering if there's any hope at all, you to see kind of a more recovery to closer to end market demand?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we'll have to see. We've said this before. We -- although we've seen some signs of stabilization on the PC market, I would not necessarily characterize us as being particularly bullish on that segment. And we have seen -- there was some inve
componenttext: Well, I mean, we'll have to see. We've said this before. We -- although we've seen some signs of stabilization on the PC market, I would not necessarily characterize us as being particularly bullish on that segment. And we have seen -- there was some inventory drawdown through the whole kind of supply chain. That's impacted our business a little bit in terms of where we maybe out of sync a bit in terms of what you're seeing from an overall PC unit perspective. And then additionally, we continue to see penetration of client SSDs in those systems. Consistent with our expectations, though by the way, but that further disconnects us from the overall unit numbers that you might see from a PC perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Keith Bachman with BMO.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Keith Bachman with BMO.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry, if there's any background noise. But my questions, I want to focus back on the SanDisk deal. I didn't have the opportunity to ask a question. More specifically, I'm still struggling to see how the SanDisk deal is creating shareholder value, where t
componenttext: Sorry, if there's any background noise. But my questions, I want to focus back on the SanDisk deal. I didn't have the opportunity to ask a question. More specifically, I'm still struggling to see how the SanDisk deal is creating shareholder value, where the 10-multiple company is buying a 30-multiple company. And Steve, the question I wanted to post to you, if I could, I wanted to understand what your fundamental assumption is about the SanDisk retro [ph] revenues, as you look out over the next 2 to 3 years? And how do you reach that conclusion, particularly with some thoughts surrounding what I think that's the Retail business or the replacement card business? And then I have a follow-up also related to SanDisk.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the short answer to your question, Keith, is, do we expect the SanDisk business to grow over time? The answer to that is yes. And we see growth opportunities. One, in helping to expand our broader footprint in terms of the enterprise area, where we thi
componenttext: So the short answer to your question, Keith, is, do we expect the SanDisk business to grow over time? The answer to that is yes. And we see growth opportunities. One, in helping to expand our broader footprint in terms of the enterprise area, where we think that, not only is that an area that's outpacing overall market growth, but also a higher value opportunity for us. We also think that there's growth opportunities in terms of client SSDs as well, certainly, as it relates to our base business. And additionally, we think that there is growth opportunity in terms of embedded solutions, that sort of thing. So you've got tablets, cell phones, et cetera. We think there is good opportunity. You asked related to the removables or the Retail segment, that's a great business, but it's not a growing business. So we fully understand and acknowledge that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe, if I could ask my follow-up then on the costs side. I think you -- during the conference call last week, that I think you've articulated broader synergies, call it, $500 million. And if I look at the cost structure of SanDisk alone, I wou
componenttext: Okay. And maybe, if I could ask my follow-up then on the costs side. I think you -- during the conference call last week, that I think you've articulated broader synergies, call it, $500 million. And if I look at the cost structure of SanDisk alone, I would have thought there would have been more on OpEx. But maybe I didn't understand the characterization because you're combining -- that would have -- maybe I didn't understand the characterization of the $500 million opportunity. But I would have thought combining the companies will be frankly more opportunities to reduce costs over the next several years beyond $500 million. But if you could just flush that out a little bit? And then, I'll cede the floor.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So a couple of comments on that. So when we talked about $500 million of synergies related to the SanDisk acquisition, we were specifically talking about -- that was 18 months -- within 18 months of the close of the transaction. We did not indicate
componenttext: Sure. So a couple of comments on that. So when we talked about $500 million of synergies related to the SanDisk acquisition, we were specifically talking about -- that was 18 months -- within 18 months of the close of the transaction. We did not indicate that, that was the total synergies. In other words, we do think that those -- there are additional opportunities. We have not quantified those -- or publicly talked about those at this point. The additional thing is that, regarding that $500 million of synergies, the lion share of that is related to the advantage that we would get by being vertically integrated as it relates principally to our Enterprise SSD business. And there are some OpEx synergies, but we have not quantified that breakout specifically.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think you said, you thought that the TAM in the fourth calendar quarter would be roughly flat. I was hoping you can provide some detail on the different markets. You mentioned that the PC market appears to be stabilizing. Can you give us some sor
componenttext: Steve, I think you said, you thought that the TAM in the fourth calendar quarter would be roughly flat. I was hoping you can provide some detail on the different markets. You mentioned that the PC market appears to be stabilizing. Can you give us some sort of directional commentary on the different end markets rates should be?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll give a little bit of color on that. So we would expect -- and these are pretty small changes, though, by the way. We would expect that we'll see some softening in terms of gaming demand as well as in notebook demand, offset by a little bit bette
componenttext: Yes. I'll give a little bit of color on that. So we would expect -- and these are pretty small changes, though, by the way. We would expect that we'll see some softening in terms of gaming demand as well as in notebook demand, offset by a little bit better enterprise demand. And that -- and again, these are subtle changes. That drives some of our margin improvement, because we'll get a little bit -- if things play out the way we expect, we'll get a little bit of mix benefit as a consequence to that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And I think you also mentioned in your commentary that the Active Archive system is expected to drive meaningful revenue next year. Can you help us understand what type of TAM you think that product has? What's the revenue opportunit
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And I think you also mentioned in your commentary that the Active Archive system is expected to drive meaningful revenue next year. Can you help us understand what type of TAM you think that product has? What's the revenue opportunity for that product?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we define the Active Archive TAM, we see that as a multibillion dollar total addressable market for that solution. There's both sort of a currently defined version of that as well as we think some new greenfield opportunities to create market w
componenttext: Yes. So as we define the Active Archive TAM, we see that as a multibillion dollar total addressable market for that solution. There's both sort of a currently defined version of that as well as we think some new greenfield opportunities to create market with that solution, given its value proposition. So I would look at it as a multibillion dollar market and growing at a fairly fast cliff.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Monika Garg with Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Monika Garg with Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, question on the SanDisk acquisition. Running the drive business is quite different than running a leading-edge memory technology business. So maybe, could you talk about the plan to retain SanDisk talent R&D team? And any execution risk [indiscerni
componenttext: Steve, question on the SanDisk acquisition. Running the drive business is quite different than running a leading-edge memory technology business. So maybe, could you talk about the plan to retain SanDisk talent R&D team? And any execution risk [indiscernible] you see?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Monika, we -- SanDisk has got some great people. We look forward to welcoming them to the team, and we certainly intend to retain the talent that exists there. And certainly, that talent that relates to those parts of the business that we don't ne
componenttext: Yes. So Monika, we -- SanDisk has got some great people. We look forward to welcoming them to the team, and we certainly intend to retain the talent that exists there. And certainly, that talent that relates to those parts of the business that we don't necessarily have the same experience, and that's certainly the semiconductor business. So we look forward to bringing them on board.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So do you see any execution risk in the integration?
componenttext: So do you see any execution risk in the integration?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's execution risk in everything, to be perfectly honest. And the thing that I always focused the most on, and investors will ask me often, what do you worry about? I want to make sure that we, every day, as a company, dot eyes and cross feet. A
componenttext: Well, there's execution risk in everything, to be perfectly honest. And the thing that I always focused the most on, and investors will ask me often, what do you worry about? I want to make sure that we, every day, as a company, dot eyes and cross feet. And that's what we do better than any company on the planet and that's what we intend to do as we look to, not only execute the WD/HGST integration, but also, as it relates to future integration of SanDisk. And so absolutely, are the risks and we're going to manage that carefully and I'm going to keep our team intensely focused on that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, given that Unis has interest 15% stake in WD, do you think it could add any regulatory risk for getting approval for the SanDisk acquisition?
componenttext: And then, given that Unis has interest 15% stake in WD, do you think it could add any regulatory risk for getting approval for the SanDisk acquisition?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we are proceeding with our application. In fact, our application regarding [indiscernible] process, that is in and has been accepted. We were very careful as to how we structured that transaction and Unis' representation on our board. And we feel pr
componenttext: Well, we are proceeding with our application. In fact, our application regarding [indiscernible] process, that is in and has been accepted. We were very careful as to how we structured that transaction and Unis' representation on our board. And we feel pretty good about that and we're proceeding with regulatory review at this point and we'll keep you posted as things progress.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: How big do you think your lead is in the 8-terabyte capacity drive space? And then how would you expect that to change, if at all, as the industry moves to 10 terabytes?
componenttext: How big do you think your lead is in the 8-terabyte capacity drive space? And then how would you expect that to change, if at all, as the industry moves to 10 terabytes?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- it's difficult to de-mention how far ahead we are, because we don't have perfect visibility into where our competition is. But let me kind of make this comment. Our 10-terabyte drive, which we haven't announced exactly when that will be availab
componenttext: Well, I -- it's difficult to de-mention how far ahead we are, because we don't have perfect visibility into where our competition is. But let me kind of make this comment. Our 10-terabyte drive, which we haven't announced exactly when that will be available. It's PRM-based solution. And that's our -- depending upon how you countered our third or fourth generation helium drive. There have been a lot of learnings along the way, and that we have developed. And so, when you got a 3 or 4 generation lead on your competition, that's fairly material lead. Now that being said, we fully -- we respect our competition, and we're not going to rest on our laurels and we're going to keep marching forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a question on inventory. You commented on PC channel inventory coming down. Obviously, we can see your balance sheet inventory that came down. But where do you think the industry is in terms of those channel inventory, which has historicall
componenttext: Okay. And then a question on inventory. You commented on PC channel inventory coming down. Obviously, we can see your balance sheet inventory that came down. But where do you think the industry is in terms of those channel inventory, which has historically been quite low in recent quarters? And also, OEM inventory at their manufacturing hubs?

componenttext: So the inventory is still within our range, in the lower end of the range, nevertheless.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me rephrase it, as a follow-up. Do you see new technologies, like 3D NAND to become a catalyst looking to next year, while your competitor is just hitting the margin and selling at a lower price? And as a follow-up to that, do you see a change i
componenttext: Sure. Let me rephrase it, as a follow-up. Do you see new technologies, like 3D NAND to become a catalyst looking to next year, while your competitor is just hitting the margin and selling at a lower price? And as a follow-up to that, do you see a change in your driver strategy, especially SanDisk selling more of a hybrid product, as a way to scale rather niche segment of the market?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me comment on that. I think we see 3D as the next-generation underlying media. We have plans to address products that are built on that in the future. So that will be part of our competitive profile and there are both, of course, economic benefits
componenttext: So let me comment on that. I think we see 3D as the next-generation underlying media. We have plans to address products that are built on that in the future. So that will be part of our competitive profile and there are both, of course, economic benefits of that, but there are also product performance benefits in that architecture. So I think we'll see the market go through a transition and we have our own internal plans in which to undertake that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I'm just wondering if you -- just back to SanDisk, just if you can explain, the big question we get is whether this is defensive strategy or an offensive strategy. In other words, is buying SanDisk your absolute best strategy for you to take on, gi
componenttext: Steve, I'm just wondering if you -- just back to SanDisk, just if you can explain, the big question we get is whether this is defensive strategy or an offensive strategy. In other words, is buying SanDisk your absolute best strategy for you to take on, given your declining industry? Or is it more an offensive strategy and the fact that you believe exabyte growth is going to continue to grow and HDDs and solid-state drives will coexist for an extended period of time? And therefore, you are best suited to serve a customer base that's also consolidating.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So one comment, and not to take offense to the way that the question is phrased. But I don't know if I necessarily like the characterizing it as either offensive or defensive. This is the strategy that we thought about quite a bit. We think it is goi
componenttext: Yes. So one comment, and not to take offense to the way that the question is phrased. But I don't know if I necessarily like the characterizing it as either offensive or defensive. This is the strategy that we thought about quite a bit. We think it is going to be good for our shareholders, good for our customers. And it's going to allow our company and our business to grow. So if you want to characterize that as offensive, then feel free to do so.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. And then, as you look at just the disk drive business, Steve, as my follow-up question. As we look out as -- at a TAM that kind of follows a flat to low single digit, given the mix in complexity of enterprise drives as well as bigger ca
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. And then, as you look at just the disk drive business, Steve, as my follow-up question. As we look out as -- at a TAM that kind of follows a flat to low single digit, given the mix in complexity of enterprise drives as well as bigger capacity branded drives being shipped, it would make great progress on non-PC revenue as a mix of our business and actually over the last 4 years has modestly grown. Three or 4 years from now, do you believe that is the lion's share of the percentage of revenue?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Now what percentage, we'll have to see. And we certainly haven't called anything out publicly but clearly, the mix of our business in the traditional hard drive space is improving. And as it improves and as the PC-related part becomes a frankly small
componenttext: Yes. Now what percentage, we'll have to see. And we certainly haven't called anything out publicly but clearly, the mix of our business in the traditional hard drive space is improving. And as it improves and as the PC-related part becomes a frankly smaller and smaller part of our business, sooner or later there is going to be an inflection point. We'll begin to show improvement in revenues in terms of the overall hard drive market as well as a better margin posture as it relates to that underlying business. And so, yes. So the hard drive business remains a great business. It's just a mix is shifting, right? In a favorable way.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, nothing that will -- nothing to talk about at this point. I mean, obviously, we're going to continue to evaluate and think through our go-to-market strategy in China. But nothing specifically to talk about now.

And I know you've talked about in the past being able to sell products, especially with helium products on a TCO [ph] basis. [indiscernible] provide on pricing within segments would be helpful?

componenttext: So relative to what we saw -- I mean, again, our margin decline on a quarter-on-quarter basis was purely driven the -- was mix-related. And I don't think there's anything unusual from our perspective to call out on the pricing front.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then, this has been addressed to a certain extent, but I would like to try to tease it out a little bit more. The $500 million of OpEx synergies with SanDisk. From my understanding, there's 3 main buckets -- I'm sorry, not OpEx synergies, overall synergies. There are 3 main buckets from where this is going to come, PC express sales overlap, branded distribution and interface engineering. And if there's anything else I'm missing, please let me know but can you rank order what you believe each of these are going to be in terms of magnitude?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the first thing is, to clarify, we haven't called any of that out in terms of what you're talking about. So I'm not going to comment specifically on that. What we have said is that the lion share of that $500 million will be the benefit that we will
componenttext: Well, the first thing is, to clarify, we haven't called any of that out in terms of what you're talking about. So I'm not going to comment specifically on that. What we have said is that the lion share of that $500 million will be the benefit that we will get by being vertically integrated on -- in our SSD business or existing SSD business. And there will be some OpEx synergies, but we have not quantified that. By the way, the other thing is, is that we've indicated the $500 million will be 18 months after the close of the transaction, which basically means that there will be further synergies beyond that 18-month period that we've yet to quantify publicly.

componenttext: I want to go up on that same topic. So the $500 million in synergies, it seems like you're describing it, Steve, as these are benefits from owning the raw material in-house. So is that really a synergy, I guess? Or is that just kind of recapturing the profit that SanDisk would have brought on another wise? componenttext: Well, it's exclusive of the benefits that we'll get from the existing SanDisk business. So it's additive to whatever you might happen to estimate that the existing SanDisk business would be able to generate. It's additive.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's Financial Results for the First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded.Now, I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. Thank
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's Financial Results for the First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Mr. Bob Blair. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks, uncertainties and
componenttext:
Thank you. This conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. Such forward-looking statements are based upon management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors, many of which Western Digital is unable to predict or control, that may cause Western Digital's actual results, performance or plans to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. The call does not constitute an offer to purchase or the solicitation of an offer to sell any securities or a solicitation of any note -- any vote or approval in connection with the pending merger with SanDisk.
Western Digital will file a Form S-4 registration statement that includes proxy statements of SanDisk and Western Digital, and a prospectus of Western Digital regarding the merger. Western Digital and SanDisk will mail the definitive joint proxy statement prospectus to their respective stockholders. Investors and shareholders should read the joint proxy statement prospectives carefully when it becomes available because it contains important information about the merger.
In addition, Western Digital, SanDisk and their respective directors, executive officers and certain other members of management and employees may be soliciting proxies from their respective stockholders in favor of the proposed transaction. You can find information about Western Digital directors and executive officers in Western Digital's most recent proxy statement and about SanDisk directors and executive officers in SanDisk's most recent proxy statement. You may also obtain a copy of these documents through the SEC's website or in the Western Digital and SanDisk websites.
Further, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the historical non-GAAP measures we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the quarterly fact sheet posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. The non-GAAP forward-looking guidance we provide during this call includes amortization of intangibles, integration and acquisition-related costs.
Because we currently cannot fully quantify future amounts for these excluded items, we are unable to provide guidance for or reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures. The impact of these excluded items may cause the estimated non-GAAP financial measures to differ materially from the comparable GAAP financial measures. [Operator Instructions] I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investors section of Western Digital's website following the conclusion of this call.
And with that, I turn the call over to Western Digital Chief Executive Officer, Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us.With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will provide additional commentary on our Septem
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us.
With me today are Mike Cordano, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Olivier Leonetti, our Chief Financial Officer. After my opening remarks, Olivier will provide additional commentary on our September quarter performance and our outlook for the December quarter.
This is an important time for Western Digital. We have announced several transformational developments over the last few weeks, including the planned investment in our company by Unisplendour, the decision by MOFCOM and the planned acquisition of SanDisk. Coupled with our continued strong execution in the business, I'm very excited about the company's future and our ability to create long-term value for our customers, shareholders and employees.
We are proceeding with our integration into a single company as outlined in the MOFCOM decision, and we are submitting our applications for the regulatory reviews associated with the SanDisk acquisition and Unisplendour investment. We look forward to keeping you informed of our progress.
Turning to the September quarter. Industry demand for hard drives was moderately higher than expected, driven primarily by strength in demand for 2.5-inch devices for game consoles and notebook PCs. We reported revenues of $3.4 billion, non-GAAP gross margins of 28.9% and diluted earnings per share of $1.56. Our storage shipments for the September quarter grew to 64 exabytes from 56 exabytes in the June quarter. These results reflect continued strong product and technology positioning, coupled with solid execution.
Our Enterprise SSD revenue grew significantly to $233 million, reflecting the continued success of our SAS SSD products in an increasingly competitive environment. Additionally, we continue to ramp our new Ultrastar PCIe NVMe offering. Revenue from our video surveillance hard drives also continued its rapid growth as customers embraced our expanding lineup of these multipurpose or purpose-built solutions.
We continue to see positive market reaction to the value proposition of our new Active Archive system. We anticipate this new systems business will generate meaningful revenue next fiscal year. We saw a good demand for our enterprise hard drives, especially our high-capacity helium drives, with more than 1 million units shipped in the quarter. We are volume shipping our 8-terabyte helium drive and we'll be ramping our 10-terabyte helium drive in the year ahead. Overall, demand in the high-capacity space was somewhat softer than anticipated. This was due to absorption of previously deployed storage assets purchased earlier in the calendar year by some of our large customers.
Notwithstanding cyclicality within a given period, growth in the Capacity Enterprise sector will continue, with a 35% CAGR and exabytes anticipated on an annualized basis through 2020. This is underpinned by the ongoing growth in data being created and stored.
Looking to the PC market. We are continuing to see some signs of stabilization in demand, driven by innovation, refresh cycles and normalization of PC inventories. We believe we have the opportunity to improve our financial performance due to the integration synergies associated with the recent MOFCOM decision, coupled with our continued favorable mix of business. Longer-term, the acquisition of SanDisk and the investment by Unisplendour will help transform our company into a storage technology leader with a broader set of products, deeper technology base and an expanded addressable market.
Olivier will now provide a summary of our September quarter performance and our outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve.Our revenue for the September quarter was $3.4 billion. We shipped a total of 51.7 million hard disk drives at an average selling price of $60.Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.9% and operating expenses totaled $567 million.Tax expen
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve.
Our revenue for the September quarter was $3.4 billion. We shipped a total of 51.7 million hard disk drives at an average selling price of $60.
Our non-GAAP gross margin was 28.9% and operating expenses totaled $567 million.
Tax expense for the September quarter was $31 million or 8% of non-GAAP pretax income.
On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $366 million or $1.56 per share.
In the September quarter, we generated $545 million in cash from operations, and our free cash flow totaled $394 million.
Our CapEx totaled $151 million or 4% of revenue.
We repurchased 700,000 shares for $60 million. We also declared a dividend in the amount of $0.50 per share.
We closed the quarter with total cash and cash equivalent of $5.1 billion, of which approximately $60 million was held in the U.S. I will now provide -- so let me go back to the comment. Cash and cash equivalent of $5.1 billion, of which approximately $600 million was held in the U.S.
I will now provide our guidance for the December quarter. We expect our revenue to be in the range of $3.3 billion to $3.4 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, we expect gross margin percentage to be slightly up from the September quarter. Operating expenses of approximately $585 million and accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share between $1.50 and $1.60.
Operator, we're now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
