componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question and a follow-up. I guess, to start. Could you just talk about the benefit the MOFCOM approval will have on your cash generation ability as you go forward? And how do you think the timing of those benefits of flow? And would it be in sync
componenttext: I have a question and a follow-up. I guess, to start. Could you just talk about the benefit the MOFCOM approval will have on your cash generation ability as you go forward? And how do you think the timing of those benefits of flow? And would it be in sync with your P&L? And does MOFCOM approval help you get within the target of your cash conversion cycle of 4 to 8 days?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll take that, and then Olivier can add a little bit of color. If you -- and this is Steve. If you look at the benefits that we expect from the revised MOFCOM ruling, is that -- first thing is, is that we expect to realize $400 million of annual opera
componenttext: So I'll take that, and then Olivier can add a little bit of color. If you -- and this is Steve. If you look at the benefits that we expect from the revised MOFCOM ruling, is that -- first thing is, is that we expect to realize $400 million of annual operating expense savings and then we've also commented that we'll have material cost synergies. We have not quantified what material means in terms of cost synergies. Generally speaking, the $400 million of operating expense savings would be roughly equivalent to cash savings as our OpEx. The cost savings that we would realize, which have not been quantified, would be a mixture of cash and depreciation, that sort of thing. So it'd be kind of a mixture. So...

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me add 2 comments. First of all, most of the cash will be generated offshore. We have commented on that, 90% of the benefit will be generated outside U.S. And from a cash conversion cycle, we believe we're going to have some improvements that I w
componenttext: Yes, let me add 2 comments. First of all, most of the cash will be generated offshore. We have commented on that, 90% of the benefit will be generated outside U.S. And from a cash conversion cycle, we believe we're going to have some improvements that I wouldn't bank on many days.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can comment on that because there's a little bit of perspective. The 4 to 8 days was -- we announced that, geez, I think it was back in September of 2002 or '03 -- '12, sorry, lose track of time. But shortly after the acquisition, the composition o
componenttext: Yes, I can comment on that because there's a little bit of perspective. The 4 to 8 days was -- we announced that, geez, I think it was back in September of 2002 or '03 -- '12, sorry, lose track of time. But shortly after the acquisition, the composition of our business has changed dramatically since then, particularly a lower percentage from a PC business, which tended to have a higher cash conversion to more of an enterprise mix, which has a slower cash conversion. So we're going to need to reset at some point, what that cash conversion cycle from a business perspective should be for our company.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's really helpful. And I guess just as a follow-up. Could you talk about the gross margin dynamic in the September quarter was, I think, up 60 basis points to your plan. Mix looks like may be a part of it, but was there anything else, especial
componenttext: Got it. That's really helpful. And I guess just as a follow-up. Could you talk about the gross margin dynamic in the September quarter was, I think, up 60 basis points to your plan. Mix looks like may be a part of it, but was there anything else, especially from a pricing perspective, that could have impeded your gross margins?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: All of it was actually mix, higher mix of gaming and the higher mix of notebook and branded products.
componenttext: All of it was actually mix, higher mix of gaming and the higher mix of notebook and branded products.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: One question and one follow-up as well. Olivier, I think you had made a comment that your operating expense in the current quarter is expected to be $585 million. I just want to clarify that. And if that's true, just curious to what's the upward driver he
componenttext: One question and one follow-up as well. Olivier, I think you had made a comment that your operating expense in the current quarter is expected to be $585 million. I just want to clarify that. And if that's true, just curious to what's the upward driver here in this current quarter? And again, kind of going back to Amit's question, I mean, when can we start to actually see that OpEx come down as it relates to that MOFCOM? Is that over the next 2 or 3 quarters? Or is it further out? I think, last week, you had suggested that you should be through a lot of that by the time you get to that SanDisk closure.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the current guidance for OpEx is a bit higher than our run rate due to incentive compensation. Following the December quarter, we expect run rate OpEx to be in the range of $575 million, give or take...
componenttext: So the current guidance for OpEx is a bit higher than our run rate due to incentive compensation. Following the December quarter, we expect run rate OpEx to be in the range of $575 million, give or take...

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: $570 million.
componenttext: $570 million.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: $575 million, give or take, before MOFCOM synergies. Now in terms of MOFCOM synergies, as indicated, we would expect them to materialize between the next 12 and 24 months and we'll provide you an update on where will that be.
componenttext: $575 million, give or take, before MOFCOM synergies. Now in terms of MOFCOM synergies, as indicated, we would expect them to materialize between the next 12 and 24 months and we'll provide you an update on where will that be.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The run rate OpEx pre-MOFCOM synergies is $570 million.
componenttext: The run rate OpEx pre-MOFCOM synergies is $570 million.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: But just to be fair, I mean, you are looking to drive that OpEx down, that's not going to happen. That should -- should some of that start to happen before we even get to the 12 months, is what I'm asking?
componenttext: But just to be fair, I mean, you are looking to drive that OpEx down, that's not going to happen. That should -- should some of that start to happen before we even get to the 12 months, is what I'm asking?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The short answer is yes, Aaron. What we haven't done, which -- let's keep in mind that prior to the revised ruling from MOFCOM, we were precluded from doing any integration planning. And so we have begun detailed integration planning and all of that. And
componenttext: The short answer is yes, Aaron. What we haven't done, which -- let's keep in mind that prior to the revised ruling from MOFCOM, we were precluded from doing any integration planning. And so we have begun detailed integration planning and all of that. And so we're not prepared at this point to indicate specifically the phasing or the timing of those OpEx synergies other than to indicate they'll take place over the course of the next 12 to 24 months. But clearly, we're going to be looking at how we can bring those in as much as possible from a financial perspective, while minimizing impact to our business.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, as a follow-up, I'm just curious, on the capacity shipment trends, you talked a little bit about it. It looks like you were down about 2% year-over-year in terms of total capacity ship. Can you help us bridge what that capacity ship looks
componenttext: Okay. And then, as a follow-up, I'm just curious, on the capacity shipment trends, you talked a little bit about it. It looks like you were down about 2% year-over-year in terms of total capacity ship. Can you help us bridge what that capacity ship looks like between the PC business relative to your Enterprise business? And what that's trended like?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I follow what you're trying -- I'm not sure I follow that question, Aaron.
componenttext: I'm not sure I follow what you're trying -- I'm not sure I follow that question, Aaron.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, relative to the 35% compound annual growth rate that you referenced on the Enterprise side going forward, just curious of how that growth has looked like here -- over the past few quarters within the total capacity ship number that you report?
componenttext: So I guess, relative to the 35% compound annual growth rate that you referenced on the Enterprise side going forward, just curious of how that growth has looked like here -- over the past few quarters within the total capacity ship number that you report?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I got it. But Mike's going to take that question.
componenttext: I got it. But Mike's going to take that question.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, Aaron. So I think the way to think about it, we still think the year is tracking to -- the calendar year tracking to the 35% number, maybe slightly higher. We saw a little bit of front-loading in the calendar year of that. And so that's being absorbed
componenttext: Hi, Aaron. So I think the way to think about it, we still think the year is tracking to -- the calendar year tracking to the 35% number, maybe slightly higher. We saw a little bit of front-loading in the calendar year of that. And so that's being absorbed in the comments that Steve made earlier as we get into the second half. So I think that trend, we're confident in that and that's specifically around the Capacity Enterprise segment.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rich Kugele from Needham.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Kugele from Needham.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, on the Capacity Enterprise side, I mean, obviously that spans more than just cloud service providers. Can you just talk about the Capacity Enterprise cloud service provider part of your exabyte shipments? And how you would ex
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, on the Capacity Enterprise side, I mean, obviously that spans more than just cloud service providers. Can you just talk about the Capacity Enterprise cloud service provider part of your exabyte shipments? And how you would expect that to trend over the next, I don't know, to whatever -- 6 to 12 months as you move, especially to 10-terabyte?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Rich, I'll take that question. I mean, as you know, we try to stay away from talking about specific either customers or types of customers. Obviously, cloud service providers are a meaningful part of exabytes shipped on our part. But the absorptio
componenttext: Yes. So Rich, I'll take that question. I mean, as you know, we try to stay away from talking about specific either customers or types of customers. Obviously, cloud service providers are a meaningful part of exabytes shipped on our part. But the absorption that I alluded to in my prepared remarks was a mixture of both traditional Enterprise customers, if you want to call it that, as well as cloud service providers.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, interesting. And then, post SanDisk now, is there anything that you were contemplating on the Hitachi integration that now needs to be altered because of the SanDisk integration? If there's like facilities that, perhaps, now you need to keep? Or doe
componenttext: Okay, interesting. And then, post SanDisk now, is there anything that you were contemplating on the Hitachi integration that now needs to be altered because of the SanDisk integration? If there's like facilities that, perhaps, now you need to keep? Or does it change what could have happened in any way?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the first thing to keep in mind, Rich, is that, given the complementary nature of the SanDisk and Western Digital transaction, we're -- it's a different kind of an integration in that regard. I think that's an important thing to contemplate.
componenttext: Well, I think the first thing to keep in mind, Rich, is that, given the complementary nature of the SanDisk and Western Digital transaction, we're -- it's a different kind of an integration in that regard. I think that's an important thing to contemplate. Simplistically, the answer to your question is, is no, it doesn't really alter anything. There are some additional things that we'll have to think about that add a bit more complexity, for example, systems integrations and things like that. So we'll have to look at, not only the preexisting WD and HGST systems, but also what platform is SanDisk on and how do we kind of manage that process. But other than a few items like that, we intend to, more or less, proceed full steam in terms of the integration of -- on the WD/HGST side.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, on your comments about absorption on the Capacity side, can you help us think through either how much do you think incremental demand have or have migrated into the first half versus second half of the calendar year because of those purchases? Or a
componenttext: Steve, on your comments about absorption on the Capacity side, can you help us think through either how much do you think incremental demand have or have migrated into the first half versus second half of the calendar year because of those purchases? Or alternatively, how much of the absorption do you think we are through and what innings are we in, in that? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me comment it on -- in this way. One of the things that we talked about in our last earnings call and also, I believe, our largest competitor also commented on it, is typically, the -- I'll call it the mix of exabytes that get shipped. You have about
componenttext: Let me comment it on -- in this way. One of the things that we talked about in our last earnings call and also, I believe, our largest competitor also commented on it, is typically, the -- I'll call it the mix of exabytes that get shipped. You have about 40% that typically get shipped in the first half of the year and 60% in the back half of the year. And if you look -- and that's calendar year, right? Not our fiscal year. And that percentage has held kind of pretty consistent over a number of years. This year, roughly speaking, we're looking at something that's more like 45% and 55%. So that'll help kind of dimension a bit that. And we would expect that there would continue -- that, that absorption of capacity or exabytes shipped, that absorption will continue through the balance of this calendar year and begin to, if you want to call it, abate as we begin next calendar year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, on the near line side. Clearly, you took some share over there. As you had some customers migrate to the 8-terabyte drives, can you talk about what happened with the pricing on a like-for-like basis for the 4- and 6-terabyte? And did that
componenttext: Okay. And then, on the near line side. Clearly, you took some share over there. As you had some customers migrate to the 8-terabyte drives, can you talk about what happened with the pricing on a like-for-like basis for the 4- and 6-terabyte? And did that influence margins?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the short answer is that, that's not something that we called out as a particular driver of our margin performance. I mean, Olivier commented on the decline that we saw on our gross margin was driven entirely by mix, and that being a stronger mix of
componenttext: Well, the short answer is that, that's not something that we called out as a particular driver of our margin performance. I mean, Olivier commented on the decline that we saw on our gross margin was driven entirely by mix, and that being a stronger mix of lower margin products, namely drives that go into gaming consoles as well as 2.5-inch drives that go into notebooks, which consistently have been below the corporate average. And so, whether or not -- that's what impacted our margin. And whether or not, if other things impact it, we're not calling anything else specifically.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about the regional trends, particularly Europe, but maybe also the U.S. And European year-over-year growth deteriorating quite a bit in the quarter to minus 15% from minus 8% last quarter. So I wonder if you guys can give us a little
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about the regional trends, particularly Europe, but maybe also the U.S. And European year-over-year growth deteriorating quite a bit in the quarter to minus 15% from minus 8% last quarter. So I wonder if you guys can give us a little color on what's going on there? Is that just consumer demand deteriorating or there are other things happening? And then, same for the North American region, down 6% after being up 16.5%. Is this just data center, cloud-oriented stuff? Or can you give us a little bit of color on those regional trends?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if there's anything particularly to call out, other than -- I mean, Europe has been weak from, call it a broader macroeconomic perspective. It's always difficult to draw conclusions from our geographic data because so much of our product is m
componenttext: I don't know if there's anything particularly to call out, other than -- I mean, Europe has been weak from, call it a broader macroeconomic perspective. It's always difficult to draw conclusions from our geographic data because so much of our product is manufactured in Asia or is passed on to customers that manufacture in Asia. So it doesn't really speak to the end market. But we have seen some, as you know, the macroeconomic situation in Europe has kind of impacted some of our more detail-oriented business, but I'm not sure I would call out anything specific beyond that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the European drives, I guess, are more Europe-linked, is that correct? Whereas, elsewhere, you get more -- especially in Asia, it leaks out into other regions? Or is that the wrong way to see things?
componenttext: And the European drives, I guess, are more Europe-linked, is that correct? Whereas, elsewhere, you get more -- especially in Asia, it leaks out into other regions? Or is that the wrong way to see things?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Probably, in Europe, you're right. Because there isn't a lot of manufacturing done in Europe, right? North America, you get a little bit of a mix because there are some manufacturing or systems that may go elsewhere and, certainly, in Asia. But Europe is
componenttext: Probably, in Europe, you're right. Because there isn't a lot of manufacturing done in Europe, right? North America, you get a little bit of a mix because there are some manufacturing or systems that may go elsewhere and, certainly, in Asia. But Europe is a little bit more of a true number. But Europe has been, from a broader perspective, weak for a while.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steven Fox with Cross Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Fox with Cross Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one question, just switching gears. Can you talk about your solid-state drive business a little bit? I think you mentioned a little bit of capacity issues or rather competitive issues are increasing during the quarter? And then, relative to average c
componenttext: Just one question, just switching gears. Can you talk about your solid-state drive business a little bit? I think you mentioned a little bit of capacity issues or rather competitive issues are increasing during the quarter? And then, relative to average capacities and some of the trends you mentioned in the Enterprise, how do those relate to what's going on in SSD cyclically and through the rest of the calendar year? And that's all I have.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we've enjoyed, through strong product execution, et cetera, a pretty strong market share position in that Enterprise SSD business. It's a very competitive market, as I alluded to in my comments. And again, quite simply, not for any one particular issue
componenttext: So we've enjoyed, through strong product execution, et cetera, a pretty strong market share position in that Enterprise SSD business. It's a very competitive market, as I alluded to in my comments. And again, quite simply, not for any one particular issue or another other than just increased competition we gave back a little bit of that share in this past quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, just in terms of average capacity, is there how the business trends through the rest of the year?
componenttext: And then, just in terms of average capacity, is there how the business trends through the rest of the year?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Overall or Enterprise SSD?
componenttext: Overall or Enterprise SSD?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just Enterprise SSD.
componenttext: Just Enterprise SSD.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nothing surprising. We continue to see as product generations get announced, we continue to see an upward trend in average capacity ship.
componenttext: Nothing surprising. We continue to see as product generations get announced, we continue to see an upward trend in average capacity ship.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Kisner with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Kisner with Jefferies.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So my question is just regarding seasonality. I believe, in the June quarter call, you guys talked about seasonality being abnormal because of just the depressed natures of, I think, client demand primarily. But I'm just wondering if you could update your
componenttext: So my question is just regarding seasonality. I believe, in the June quarter call, you guys talked about seasonality being abnormal because of just the depressed natures of, I think, client demand primarily. But I'm just wondering if you could update your thoughts? And I'd like you to comment, ideally, sort of ex-MOFCOM, just seasonality of earnings in this fiscal year after having a couple of more quarters under your -- just another quarter under your belt?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if I'd call that -- I mean, if you look at seasonality, if you look at the client business, client plus gaming, which really drove most of the increase in TAM from calendar Q2 to calendar Q3. The seasonal uptick in that regard was pretty cons
componenttext: I don't know if I'd call that -- I mean, if you look at seasonality, if you look at the client business, client plus gaming, which really drove most of the increase in TAM from calendar Q2 to calendar Q3. The seasonal uptick in that regard was pretty consistent with what we normally see. It's normally up, anywhere from 6%, 7%, 8%, something in that kind of range. And that's kind of what we saw in those segments of the market. The other thing that's happened is, is that while we used to see further increase in volumes in calendar Q4, that's kind of dissipated or gone away as our customers generally build earlier in the year, and then they'll put those on boats or longer transport kind of things to save transportation costs. So the seasonality from calendar Q3 to Q4, which has been going on for a while, is much more muted. Hence, our view of a flattish TAM going into calendar Q4.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'm still wondering here. I mean, you're obviously massively under shipping end market demand. I think units are down 30% on the client side. I'm just wondering if there's any hope at all here to see kind of a more recovery to closer to end marke
componenttext: I guess, I'm still wondering here. I mean, you're obviously massively under shipping end market demand. I think units are down 30% on the client side. I'm just wondering if there's any hope at all here to see kind of a more recovery to closer to end market demand?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we'll have to see. We've said this before. We -- although we've seen some signs of stabilization on the PC market, I would not necessarily characterize us as being particularly bullish on that segment. And we have seen -- there was some inve
componenttext: Well, I mean, we'll have to see. We've said this before. We -- although we've seen some signs of stabilization on the PC market, I would not necessarily characterize us as being particularly bullish on that segment. And we have seen -- there was some inventory drawdown through the whole kind of supply chain. That's impacted our business a little bit in terms of where we may be out of sync a bit in terms of what you're seeing from an overall PC unit perspective. And then additionally, we continue to see penetration of client SSDs in those systems. Consistent with our expectations, though by the way, but that further disconnects us from the overall unit numbers that you might see from a PC perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Keith Bachman with BMO.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Keith Bachman with BMO.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry, if there's any background noise. But my questions, I want to focus back on the SanDisk deal as I didn't have the opportunity to ask a question. More specifically, I'm still struggling to see how the SanDisk deal is creating shareholder value, where
componenttext: Sorry, if there's any background noise. But my questions, I want to focus back on the SanDisk deal as I didn't have the opportunity to ask a question. More specifically, I'm still struggling to see how the SanDisk deal is creating shareholder value, where the 10-multiple company is buying a 30-multiple company. And Steve, the question I wanted to pose to you, if I could, I wanted to understand what your fundamental assumption is about the SanDisk, will it grow revenues, as you look out over the next 2 to 3 years? And how do you reach that conclusion, particularly with some thoughts surrounding what I think as the Retail business or the replacement card business? And then I have a follow-up also related to SanDisk.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the short answer to your question, Keith, is, do we expect the SanDisk business to grow over time? The answer to that is yes. And we see growth opportunities. One, in helping to expand our broader footprint in terms of the enterprise area [ph], where w
componenttext: So the short answer to your question, Keith, is, do we expect the SanDisk business to grow over time? The answer to that is yes. And we see growth opportunities. One, in helping to expand our broader footprint in terms of the enterprise area [ph], where we think that, not only is that an area that's outpacing overall market growth, but also a higher value opportunity for us. We also think that there's growth opportunities in terms of client SSDs as well, certainly, as it relates to our base business. And additionally, we think that there is growth opportunity in terms of embedded solutions, that sort of thing. So you've got tablets, cell phones, et cetera. We think there is good opportunity. You asked related to the removables or the Retail segment, that's a great business, but it's not a growing business. So we fully understand and acknowledge that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe, if I could ask my follow-up then on the costs side. I think you -- during the conference call last week, that I think you've articulated broader synergies, call it, $500 million. And if I look at the cost structure of SanDisk alone, I wou
componenttext: Okay. And maybe, if I could ask my follow-up then on the costs side. I think you -- during the conference call last week, that I think you've articulated broader synergies, call it, $500 million. And if I look at the cost structure of SanDisk alone, I would have thought there would have been more on OpEx. But maybe I didn't understand the characterization because you're combining -- that would have -- maybe I didn't understand the characterization of the $500 million opportunity. But I would have thought combining the companies would be frankly more opportunities to reduce costs over the next several years beyond $500 million. But if you could just flesh that out a little bit? And then, I'll cede the floor.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So a couple of comments on that. So when we talked about $500 million of synergies related to the SanDisk acquisition, we were specifically talking about -- that was 18 months -- within 18 months of the close of the transaction. We did not indicate
componenttext: Sure. So a couple of comments on that. So when we talked about $500 million of synergies related to the SanDisk acquisition, we were specifically talking about -- that was 18 months -- within 18 months of the close of the transaction. We did not indicate that, that was the total synergies. In other words, we do think that those -- there are additional opportunities. We have not quantified those -- or publicly talked about those at this point. The additional thing is that, regarding that $500 million of synergies, the lion's share of that is related to the advantage that we would get by being vertically integrated as it relates principally to our Enterprise SSD business. And there are some OpEx synergies, but we have not quantified that breakout specifically.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think you said, you thought that the TAM in the fourth calendar quarter would be roughly flat. I was hoping you can provide some detail on the different markets. You mentioned that the PC market appears to be stabilizing. Can you give us some sor
componenttext: Steve, I think you said, you thought that the TAM in the fourth calendar quarter would be roughly flat. I was hoping you can provide some detail on the different markets. You mentioned that the PC market appears to be stabilizing. Can you give us some sort of directional commentary on the different end markets rates should be?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll give a little bit of color on that. So we would expect -- and these are pretty small changes, though, by the way. We would expect that we'll see some softening in terms of gaming demand as well as in notebook demand, offset by a little bit bette
componenttext: Yes. I'll give a little bit of color on that. So we would expect -- and these are pretty small changes, though, by the way. We would expect that we'll see some softening in terms of gaming demand as well as in notebook demand, offset by a little bit better enterprise demand. And that -- and again, these are subtle changes. That drives some of our margin improvement, because we'll get a little bit -- if things play out the way we expect, we'll get a little bit of mix benefit as a consequence to that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And I think you also mentioned in your commentary that the Active Archive system is expected to drive meaningful revenue next year. Can you help us understand what type of TAM you think that product has? What's the revenue opportunit
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And I think you also mentioned in your commentary that the Active Archive system is expected to drive meaningful revenue next year. Can you help us understand what type of TAM you think that product has? What's the revenue opportunity for that product?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we define the Active Archive TAM, we see that as a multibillion dollar total addressable market for that solution. There's both sort of a currently defined version of that as well as we think some new greenfield opportunities to create market w
componenttext: Yes. So as we define the Active Archive TAM, we see that as a multibillion dollar total addressable market for that solution. There's both sort of a currently defined version of that as well as we think some new greenfield opportunities to create market with that solution, given its value proposition. So I would look at it as a multibillion dollar market and growing at a fairly fast clip.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Monika Garg with Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Monika Garg with Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, question on the SanDisk acquisition. Running the drive business is quite different than running a leading-edge memory technology business. So maybe, could you talk about the plan to retain SanDisk talent R&D team? And any execution risk in the inte
componenttext: Steve, question on the SanDisk acquisition. Running the drive business is quite different than running a leading-edge memory technology business. So maybe, could you talk about the plan to retain SanDisk talent R&D team? And any execution risk in the integration you see?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Monika, we -- SanDisk has got some great people. We look forward to welcoming them to the team, and we certainly intend to retain the talent that exists there. And certainly, that talent that relates to those parts of the business that we don't ne
componenttext: Yes. So Monika, we -- SanDisk has got some great people. We look forward to welcoming them to the team, and we certainly intend to retain the talent that exists there. And certainly, that talent that relates to those parts of the business that we don't necessarily have the same experience as them, and that's certainly the semiconductor business. So we look forward to bringing them on board.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So do you see any execution risk in the integration?
componenttext: So do you see any execution risk in the integration?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's execution risk in everything, to be perfectly honest. And the thing that I always focus the most on, and investors will ask me often, what do you worry about? I want to make sure that we, every day, as a company, dot Is and cross Ts. And tha
componenttext: Well, there's execution risk in everything, to be perfectly honest. And the thing that I always focus the most on, and investors will ask me often, what do you worry about? I want to make sure that we, every day, as a company, dot Is and cross Ts. And that's what we do better than any company on the planet and that's what we intend to do as we look to, not only execute the WD/HGST integration, but also, as it relates to future integration of SanDisk. And so absolutely, are there risks, and we're going to manage that carefully and I'm going to keep our team intensely focused on that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, given that Unis has interest 15% stake in WD, do you think it could add any regulatory risk for getting approval for the SanDisk acquisition?
componenttext: And then, given that Unis has interest 15% stake in WD, do you think it could add any regulatory risk for getting approval for the SanDisk acquisition?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we are proceeding with our application. In fact, our application regarding [indiscernible] process, that is in and has been accepted. We were very careful as to how we structured that transaction and Unis' representation on our board. And we feel pr
componenttext: Well, we are proceeding with our application. In fact, our application regarding [indiscernible] process, that is in and has been accepted. We were very careful as to how we structured that transaction and Unis' representation on our board. And we feel pretty good about that and we're proceeding with regulatory review at this point and we'll keep you posted as things progress.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: How big do you think your lead is in the 8-terabyte capacity drive space? And then how would you expect that to change, if at all, as the industry moves to 10 terabytes?
componenttext: How big do you think your lead is in the 8-terabyte capacity drive space? And then how would you expect that to change, if at all, as the industry moves to 10 terabytes?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- it's difficult to dimension how far ahead we are, because we don't have perfect visibility into where our competition is. But let me kind of make this comment. Our 10-terabyte drive, which we haven't announced exactly when that will be availabl
componenttext: Well, I -- it's difficult to dimension how far ahead we are, because we don't have perfect visibility into where our competition is. But let me kind of make this comment. Our 10-terabyte drive, which we haven't announced exactly when that will be available. It's PRM-based solution. And that's our -- depending upon how you counted, our third or fourth generation helium drive. There have been a lot of learnings along the way, and that we have developed. And so, when you got a 3 or 4 generation lead on your competition, that's fairly material lead. Now that being said, we fully -- we respect our competition, and we're not going to rest on our laurels and we're going to keep marching forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a question on inventory. You commented on PC channel inventory coming down. Obviously, we can see your balance sheet inventory that came down. But where do you think the industry is in terms of those channel inventory, which has historicall
componenttext: Okay. And then a question on inventory. You commented on PC channel inventory coming down. Obviously, we can see your balance sheet inventory that came down. But where do you think the industry is in terms of those channel inventory, which has historically been quite low in recent quarters? And also, OEM inventory at their manufacturing hubs?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the inventory is still within our range, in the lower end of the range, nevertheless.
componenttext: So the inventory is still within our range, in the lower end of the range, nevertheless.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have any visibility into the OEM inventory at their hubs?
componenttext: Do you have any visibility into the OEM inventory at their hubs?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We think that those are within comfortable ranges, but we don't have any specific visibility as to any issues.
componenttext: We think that those are within comfortable ranges, but we don't have any specific visibility as to any issues.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Going back to your commentary regarding some share shift in the SSD, how do you see this evolving into next year? And I have a follow-up.
componenttext: Going back to your commentary regarding some share shift in the SSD, how do you see this evolving into next year? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a difficult question to answer. How do we see share evolving into next year. I mean, obviously, what we're going to continue to do is execute on our product plan and continue to delight our customers and share will turn out where it'll turn out. An
componenttext: That's a difficult question to answer. How do we see share evolving into next year. I mean, obviously, what we're going to continue to do is execute on our product plan and continue to delight our customers and share will turn out where it'll turn out. And so we're going to try to earn our business every day.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me rephrase it, as a follow-up. Do you see new technologies, like 3D NAND to become a catalyst looking to next year, while your competitor is just hitting the margin and selling at a lower price? And as a follow-up to that, do you see a change i
componenttext: Sure. Let me rephrase it, as a follow-up. Do you see new technologies, like 3D NAND to become a catalyst looking to next year, while your competitor is just hitting the margin and selling at a lower price? And as a follow-up to that, do you see a change in your driver strategy, especially SanDisk selling more of a hybrid product, as a way to scale a rather niche segment of the market?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me comment on that. I think we see 3D as the next-generation underlying media. We have plans to address products that are built on that in the future. So that will be part of our competitive profile and there are both, of course, economic benefits
componenttext: So let me comment on that. I think we see 3D as the next-generation underlying media. We have plans to address products that are built on that in the future. So that will be part of our competitive profile and there are both, of course, economic benefits of that, but there are also product performance benefits in that architecture. So I think we'll see the market go through a transition and we have our own internal plans in which to undertake that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So is your competition just basically selling a depressed price, is that what the competition has done?
componenttext: So is your competition just basically selling a depressed price, is that what the competition has done?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think -- we see continued competition around that market as it progresses, nothing that's sort of outside our general expectations.
componenttext: I don't think -- we see continued competition around that market as it progresses, nothing that's sort of outside our general expectations.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And quickly on the hybrid drive, is your strategy changing here, especially with SanDisk included part of your portfolio?
componenttext: Got you. And quickly on the hybrid drive, is your strategy changing here, especially with SanDisk included part of your portfolio?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this point, we don't have any specific changes we would articulate.
componenttext: At this point, we don't have any specific changes we would articulate.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ananda Baruah with Brean Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ananda Baruah with Brean Capital.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two, if I could. The first is with regards to TAM. TAM and exabyte grew. Now that TAM's stabilized, do you guys expect it to remain inside sort of any particular range? And then, in that context, I guess, what is the sort of the overall exabyte growth mar
componenttext: Two, if I could. The first is with regards to TAM. TAM and exabyte grew. Now that TAM's stabilized, do you guys expect it to remain inside sort of any particular range? And then, in that context, I guess, what is the sort of the overall exabyte growth market profile you guys are looking for kind of over the next handful of years? And then, I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in terms of, Ananda, overall exabyte growth for the market, we are predicting a 15% growth as a CAGR. And particularly, as it comes to a potential price, we've commented on that earlier, we see a 35% growth in CAGR.
componenttext: So in terms of, Ananda, overall exabyte growth for the market, we are predicting a 15% growth as a CAGR. And particularly, as it comes to a potential price, we've commented on that earlier, we see a 35% growth in CAGR.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very useful. And then anything on the TAM range?
componenttext: That's very useful. And then anything on the TAM range?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Longer-term, we would expect the TAM to be flat to maybe down low single digits.
componenttext: Longer-term, we would expect the TAM to be flat to maybe down low single digits.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, just as a follow-up. I guess, our work, really since late summer has kind of pointed to PC SSD pricing, including some of your OEM grade stock becoming a little bit more aggressive than it typically had been and it most recently had been
componenttext: Got it. And then, just as a follow-up. I guess, our work, really since late summer has kind of pointed to PC SSD pricing, including some of your OEM grade stock becoming a little bit more aggressive than it typically had been and it most recently had been. Just interesting in getting your view on, if you've seen this yet? If it's impacted unit placement in any way? And if you expect it to potentially have an impact going forward? And that's it.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: You're referring to PC OEM pricing?
componenttext: You're referring to PC OEM pricing?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the SSD side. I guess -- yes, PC-related.
componenttext: Yes. On the SSD side. I guess -- yes, PC-related.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just comment that we -- I don't think we've seen anything notable from our perspective.
componenttext: I would just comment that we -- I don't think we've seen anything notable from our perspective.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Christian Schwab with Craig-Hallum Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Christian Schwab with Craig-Hallum Capital.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I'm just wondering if you -- just back to SanDisk, just if you can explain, the big question we get is whether this is defensive strategy or an offensive strategy. In other words, is buying SanDisk your absolute best strategy for you to take on, gi
componenttext: Steve, I'm just wondering if you -- just back to SanDisk, just if you can explain, the big question we get is whether this is defensive strategy or an offensive strategy. In other words, is buying SanDisk your absolute best strategy for you to take on, given your declining industry? Or is it more an offensive strategy and the fact that you believe exabyte growth is going to continue to grow and HDDs and solid-state drives will coexist for an extended period of time? And therefore, you are best suited to serve a customer base that's also consolidating.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So one comment, and not to take offense to the way that the question is phrased. But I don't know if I necessarily like the characterizing it as either offensive or defensive. This is the strategy that we thought about quite a bit. We think it is goi
componenttext: Yes. So one comment, and not to take offense to the way that the question is phrased. But I don't know if I necessarily like the characterizing it as either offensive or defensive. This is the strategy that we thought about quite a bit. We think it is going to be good for our shareholders, good for our customers. And it's going to allow our company and our business to grow. So if you want to characterize that as offensive, then feel free to do so.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. And then, as you look at just the disk drive business, Steve, as my follow-up question. As we look out as -- at a TAM that kind of follows a flat to low single digit, given the mix in complexity of enterprise drives as well as bigger ca
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. And then, as you look at just the disk drive business, Steve, as my follow-up question. As we look out as -- at a TAM that kind of follows a flat to low single digit, given the mix in complexity of enterprise drives as well as bigger capacity branded drives being shipped, we would make great progress on non-PC revenue as a mix of our business and actually over the last 4 years has modestly grown. Three, 4 years from now, do you believe that is the lion's share of the percentage of revenue?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Now what percentage, we'll have to see. And we certainly haven't called anything out publicly but clearly, the mix of our business in the traditional hard drive space is improving. And as it improves and as the PC-related part becomes a frankly small
componenttext: Yes. Now what percentage, we'll have to see. And we certainly haven't called anything out publicly but clearly, the mix of our business in the traditional hard drive space is improving. And as it improves and as the PC-related part becomes a frankly smaller and smaller part of our business, sooner or later there is going to be an inflection point. We'll begin to show improvement in revenues in terms of the overall hard drive market as well as a better margin posture as it relates to that underlying business. And so, yes. So the hard drive business remains a great business. It's just a mix is shifting, right? In a favorable way.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Delaney with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Delaney with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question was on the strategy of the company in China going forward and post the Unis deal that you've announced, should we expect any changes in how that WD plans to do business? Or any other types of partnerships you may be looking to form, especia
componenttext: First question was on the strategy of the company in China going forward and post the Unis deal that you've announced, should we expect any changes in how that WD plans to do business? Or any other types of partnerships you may be looking to form, especially, given that Xinhua [ph] has other -- has been making other investments in the U.S. in collaboration with U.S. tech companies?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, nothing that will -- nothing to talk about at this point. I mean, obviously, we're going to continue to evaluate and think through our go-to-market strategy in China. I mean, China, as a market -- I mean, first off, it's a huge market, it's a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, nothing that will -- nothing to talk about at this point. I mean, obviously, we're going to continue to evaluate and think through our go-to-market strategy in China. I mean, China, as a market -- I mean, first off, it's a huge market, it's a growing market, it's evolving market. As you see some of the hyperscale guys there grow or telecom companies, et cetera, et cetera. We're going to have to look at ways that we evolve our go-to-market capabilities in that market. But nothing specifically to talk about now.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question on the gross margin. You certainly when some of the preliminaries all started to come out from HDD companies with lower margins, there's a lot of concern in the market that there was an increase in pricing pressure. And I know you already comme
componenttext: A question on the gross margin. You certainly when some of the preliminaries all started to come out from HDD companies with lower margins, there's a lot of concern in the market that there was an increase in pricing pressure. And I know you already commented that the decline at WD was due to mix. I was actually hoping if you could just talk about pricing trends within some of the segments, because it seems like, on a quarter-to-quarter basis, there might have even been some pricing increases on some of the categories. And I know you've talked about in the past being able to sell products, especially with helium products on a TCO basis. So anything you can provide on pricing within segments would be helpful?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So relative to what we saw -- I mean, again, our margin decline on a quarter-on-quarter basis was purely driven the -- was mix-related. And I don't think there's anything unusual from our perspective to call out on the pricing front.
componenttext: So relative to what we saw -- I mean, again, our margin decline on a quarter-on-quarter basis was purely driven the -- was mix-related. And I don't think there's anything unusual from our perspective to call out on the pricing front.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Nehal Chokshi with Maxim Group.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Nehal Chokshi with Maxim Group.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a minor question, days inventory, that's been elevated for 3 quarters now over on a year-over-year basis. Are we expecting that to continue to be the case?
componenttext: Just a minor question, days inventory, that's been elevated for 3 quarters now over on a year-over-year basis. Are we expecting that to continue to be the case?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I mean, we're managing our cash flow tightly and we would expect the flow not to have been achieved. So we think we can improve further on this metric.
componenttext: Yes. So I mean, we're managing our cash flow tightly and we would expect the flow not to have been achieved. So we think we can improve further on this metric.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, this has been addressed to a certain extent, but I would like to try to tease it out a little bit more. The $500 million of OpEx synergies with SanDisk. From my understanding, there's 3 main buckets -- I'm sorry, not OpEx synergies,
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, this has been addressed to a certain extent, but I would like to try to tease it out a little bit more. The $500 million of OpEx synergies with SanDisk. From my understanding, there's 3 main buckets -- I'm sorry, not OpEx synergies, overall synergies. There are 3 main buckets from where this is going to come from, PC express sales overlap, branded distribution and interface engineering. And if there's anything else I'm missing, please let me know but can you rank order what you believe each of these are going to be in terms of magnitude?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the first thing is, just to clarify, we haven't called any of that out in terms of what you're talking about. So I'm not going to comment specifically on that. What we have said is that the lion's share of that $500 million will be the benefit that
componenttext: Well, the first thing is, just to clarify, we haven't called any of that out in terms of what you're talking about. So I'm not going to comment specifically on that. What we have said is that the lion's share of that $500 million will be the benefit that we will get by being vertically integrated on -- in our SSD business or existing SSD business. And there will be some OpEx synergies, but we have not quantified that. By the way, the other thing is, is that we've indicated the $500 million will be 18 months after the close of the transaction, which basically means that there will be further synergies beyond that 18-month period that we've yet to quantify publicly.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have one more question from the Joe Wittine with Longbow Research.
componenttext: We have one more question from the Joe Wittine with Longbow Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to go up on that same topic. So the $500 million in synergies, it seems like you're describing it, Steve, as these are benefits from owning the raw material in-house. So is that really a synergy, I guess? Or is that just kind of recapturing the pro
componenttext: I want to go up on that same topic. So the $500 million in synergies, it seems like you're describing it, Steve, as these are benefits from owning the raw material in-house. So is that really a synergy, I guess? Or is that just kind of recapturing the profit that SanDisk would have brought on otherwise? I guess my question is, when you add 1 plus 1, does it equal 2 plus $500 million, right? If you could just clarify that one more time, I think it would help.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's exclusive of the benefits that we'll get from the existing SanDisk business. So it's additive to whatever you might happen to estimate that the existing SanDisk business would be able to generate. It's additive.
componenttext: Well, it's exclusive of the benefits that we'll get from the existing SanDisk business. So it's additive to whatever you might happen to estimate that the existing SanDisk business would be able to generate. It's additive.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to be crystal clear, this includes no OpEx at all, no elimination of public company expenses, that sort of thing. It's a very conservative number?
componenttext: Okay. And then just to be crystal clear, this includes no OpEx at all, no elimination of public company expenses, that sort of thing. It's a very conservative number?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know if I used the word conservative. But it does include an estimate of some OpEx synergies. But we haven't quantified specifically what the OpEx versus the vertical integration benefits. We haven't quantified that difference. But we've als
componenttext: Well, I don't know if I used the word conservative. But it does include an estimate of some OpEx synergies. But we haven't quantified specifically what the OpEx versus the vertical integration benefits. We haven't quantified that difference. But we've also indicated that we would expect that number to increase over time beyond that 18-month period.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. At this time, we no longer have questions on queue.
componenttext: Thank you. At this time, we no longer have questions on queue.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So thank you, again, for joining us today.In closing, I want to thank all of our employees and suppliers for their commitment and outstanding execution, and our customers for their continued business. Thank you so much.
componenttext:
So thank you, again, for joining us today.
In closing, I want to thank all of our employees and suppliers for their commitment and outstanding execution, and our customers for their continued business. Thank you so much.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, sir. So that concludes today's conference call. Thank you all for participating. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you, sir. So that concludes today's conference call. Thank you all for participating. You may now disconnect.
